.<l n="b">karuhun narāryya Harimūrtti makajuru lawan Halāyudha</l>
.<l n="c">irikā narendrasuta Pārtha hinariwuwu rāmya ring sabhā</l>
.<l n="d">awuwuh [h]alĕp nira sawang Surapati hinucap ndatan waneh</l>
3090</lg>
. <!-- 7 (a) Q Yadu for ratu -->
.<lg n="8"><l n="a">wwaya têki rāmya pawirāman ing atanu hinuttamêng prabhu</l>
.<l n="b">Smarasṛṣṭhi hīra wangunanya rĕcĕp ing angajap linangwakĕn</l>
.<l n="c">kumĕñar hatĕpnya n abhirū śinaśarudhira wimba ning mirah</l>
3095<l n="d">maya ning wulan langi-langitnya sinuji kinalacyan ing cucur</l>
.</lg>
.<lg n="9"><l n="a">nya ta laryya-laryyan ika ring pamanisan i surambyan ing gṛha</l>
.<l n="b">lĕngĕng ing Taladhwaja piniṇḍa winĕḍarakĕn ing labuh kapat</l>
.<l n="c">ginĕlar ta kalpataru puṣpa pakaśaca ri rĕngga ning jinĕm</l>
3100<l n="d">mrik ikang hasĕp lĕlĕh aweh turida minging arūm nirāntara</l>
.</lg>
. <!-- 9 (a) L ikang for ika ring -->
.<lg n="10"><l n="a">irikā ta rakwa pinapak nṛpawaraduhitā gi*</l></lg>
. <!-- 10 (a) J lacuna from gi....rāga; R lacuna from (gi)no....smarāga; S inserts: ginorawa tĕkap ing para kili paḍa wruh i kagĕlaran ing pujākrama / wali ning smarāgama... -->
3105<lg n="11"><l n="a">............rāgama huwus hinĕnakĕna kabeh sumanggraha</l>
.<l n="b">abhiwāda manggala pangarccana nira ri harĕp nareśwara</l></lg>
. <!-- (11) (d) L i for ri -->
.<lg n="12"><l n="a">nda[h] aneka mukya kinĕnākĕna pangucara ning walikrama</l>
.<l n="b">araras tikang paḍahi panghariwuwu nira rāmya len gupit</l>
3110<l n="c">ulah ing hanindya tadanāntara pinisalin ing wĕngi n tĕkā</l>
.<l n="d">ndan ahĕly awās tĕkap ikang damar asĕmu samūha ning rawi</l></lg>
. <!-- (12) (a) = LQ; Q hinĕnakĕna -->
.<lg n="13"><l n="a">tan iwön masāmpunan ikang pamiḍuḍukan irân mapahyunan</l>
.<l n="b">riy ulih nirângalih i ḍampa kadi salaga karwaban riris</l>
3115<l n="c">panameni gĕṇḍing araras ri laku nira lalitya komala</l>
.<l n="d">kĕtĕb ing lumakwa kadi Karttika siniring i śabda ning patĕr</l>
.</lg>
.</div>
.<div type="canto" rend="met" n="48" met="jagaddhita">
3120<lg n="1"><l n="a">munggah ring gṛha ratna nīla pinakonggwan ira tinawung ing samāgama</l>
.<l n="b">mār mrat rūmnya sinaptagopita paragyan ika minging arūm kinumkuman</l>
.<l n="c">mrik ning karpura gandha ning jĕnu-jĕnunya makatilaka ning pasanggaman</l>
.<l n="d">byaktâmungwa ri lĕnglĕng ing manah akung lumaya-laya gatinya n anglare</l>
.</lg>
3125 <!-- 1 (a) S smarāgama (c) L kapura -->
.<lg n="2"><l n="a">ngkā sang Pārtha sirâtiharṣa mangisapwakĕn i sira narendraputrikā</l>
.<l n="b">tĕkwan sūkṣma pangumpĕt ing Manasijânguyangi hati nirân kĕnêng hunĕng</l>
.<l n="c">oyut wetnya hinöt kunĕng [r]yy ulih i sang wwang amarang i sirân hanêng jinĕm</l>
.<l n="d">mangkin lwir sĕmi ning gaḍung paḍa ni kung nira n amilĕt i teja ning wulan</l>
3130</lg>
. <!-- 2 (c) = LQ -->
.<lg n="3"><l n="a">sang hyang-hyang ning akung prapañca rumaras mingay agigu mĕhah minanwakĕn</l>
.<l n="b">śīghrângluh sumarambah ing mata nirân kadi maluy atĕmah madhudrawa</l>
.<l n="c">polah ning tikĕl ing halis nira tiki n mayat arĕngu kinol nṛpātmaja</l>
3135<l n="d">rĕmpū twas nira mepu lāgi kinisapwakĕn alara kawĕs winodanan</l>
.</lg>
. <!-- 3 (a) R minwakĕn, S pinangwakĕn -->
.<lg n="4"><l n="a">yêkângde siwuhĕn ta sang nṛpatiputra ruminga-ringa marmma pet siwi</l>
.<l n="b">kepwan bhranta sawet ni kung nira n angol tĕngah alaris amatya-matyakĕn</l>
3140<l n="c">wet ning harṣa nirân kĕdö kalawanan twas ira karaṇa ning harĕp-harĕp</l>
.<l n="d">lāgy âwah manis ing priyambada pañumbwa nira tĕmahan ing karāsikan</l>
.</lg>
.<lg n="5"><l n="a">rakryan sang kinĕñĕp ri nāla ning unang sang inapi paśarīra ning Ratih</l>
.<l n="b">sūkṣmângdadya sakêng nirātmaka ri lĕnglĕng ing angajap i sandhi ning langö</l>
3145<l n="c">pāwak ning madhu sang hyang ing kusuma lakṣmi ning asana maṇik ning angdyahi</l>
.<l n="d">śrī ning Karttika mūrtti ning prathima ratna kari kita madadya putrikā</l>
.</lg>
. <!-- 5 (b) L ing ajap -->
.<lg n="6"><l n="a">mangke pwâri katon pralabdha hiḍĕp i ngwang angisapu marĕk marê kita</l>
3150<l n="b">sang tan sah [h]inajap kunĕng karaṇa ning ḍatĕng i kita mĕne n pamangkwakĕn</l>
.<l n="c">sang sākṣāt maṇik ing hiḍĕp pinakahĕmbanan i tĕlĕng ing anggĕgö smara</l>
.<l n="d">donkwâlābha ri siddha ning bhaṣama sātmaka katĕkan amuktya sanmata</l>
.</lg>
. <!-- 6 (a) R ing ngwang (b) = Q -->
3155<lg n="7"><l n="a">epū ngwang mapa kāla ning pinuwakan wulat anahĕli kungnya tan lutur</l>
.<l n="b">ndak ton kingking ikâmĕgĕng turida yadyapi kaluputan ing priyambada</l>
.<l n="c">byaktā n māntĕna jīwitanya n apuput pati kasarik i ratna ning purī</l>
.<l n="d">manggĕh prastuti ning rarasta pakamuṣṭi ning angarang angel kĕnêng riris</l>
.</lg>
3160<lg n="8"><l n="a">nāhan cumbwa narendraputra mamanis lwir angĕtĕri hilik suputrikā</l>
.<l n="b">mambö satpada matta mangrĕngih i pangjrah ing asana minging turung mĕkar</l>
.<l n="c">pet-pet harṣa manambyakĕn wuwus arūm tĕhĕr angarĕki kĕdw angolakĕn</l>
.<l n="d">eñjuh yan pangalap kasor lĕkas irângiling-ilingi mahānggagap tĕngah</l>
.</lg>
3165 <!-- 8 (a) L cumbwana (d) S mangalap -->
.</div>
.<div type="canto" rend="met" n="49" met="Kilayu-anĕḍĕng">
.<lg n="1"><l n="a">ndan śrī nṛpawaraduhitā minge ri manis ing wuwus angari-hari</l>
.<l n="b">tapwan gĕrĕmĕ ri rĕcĕp ing prahāsana narendratanaya mangamĕr</l>
3170<l n="c">ardhâgigu winisikakĕn humingsĕr anangis tiki n inarĕkana</l>
.<l n="d">mogâkiput awĕḍi yadin kacidra padu ning tapih iningĕtakĕn</l>
.</lg>
. <!-- 1 (a) S omits minge (b) L prahasanā -->
.<lg n="2"><l n="a">tĕkwan rĕngu-rĕngu ni liring nirârĕja ñĕñĕrnya hamiṣani ng akung</l>
3175<l n="b">lāwan tikĕl i halis irângani twas amangun lĕlĕh ing angamĕra</l>
.<l n="c">lāwan panulak ira kadi pwa sinwam ing aśoka kasirir ing angin</l>
.<l n="d">himpĕr sarasija kinudang nikang bhramara matta cala-cala nira</l>
.</lg>
. <!-- 2 (a) Q amisani kung (b) S nirâ- -->
3180<lg n="3"><l n="a">āmbĕk nṛpasuta katalĕh kĕnêng manis i rūm nṛpawaraduhitā</l>
.<l n="b">mangkin raga-ragan angamĕr sirângusapi gātra lagi palĕ-palĕh</l>
.<l n="c">lāwan tangan ira tumamêng tĕngah marĕk i puṇḍutan inarĕpakĕn</l>
.<l n="d">sanyāsa manguwahi ri kapriyambadan irângucap amahi langö</l>
.</lg>
3185<lg n="4"><l n="a">rakryan sang inapi maṇik ing kalangwan anusah twas ing alara makung</l>
.<l n="b">dentângrahatakĕna manis-manista lĕwu denya sumusuk i hati </l>
.<l n="c">sa[ng] nitya cumarik i langöngku lot makaparantya ning añulu-ñuluh</l>
.<l n="d">himpĕr śaśadhara juga tan panīsi kucup ing salaga kapanasan</l>
.</lg>
3190 <!-- 4 (b) L dontâ- for dentâ- (c) = LQ; S sumarik (d) L panisi -->
.<lg n="5"><l n="a">sang kady asana kusuma rūmta munggw i wahĕl ing patah arĕja minging</l>
.<l n="b">rāmyângingin-ingin amangun hunĕng juga rarasta bisama kinĕmit</l>
.<l n="c">ngwang satpada lalita mangel angölwakĕna rāga turida malawas</l>
.<l n="d">tañ jrih mangarĕki suka mātya yan huwus acihna hamungari gĕlung</l>
3195</lg>
. <!-- 5 (a) L ing for i -->
.</div>
.<div type="canto" rend="met" n="50" met="jagaddhita">
.<lg n="1"><l n="a">hāh ndin koluyan ing langö ngwang iki denya mucapakĕna sotan ing rimang</l>
3200<l n="b">dūran yan hana mātra kampirakĕnêng kĕtĕ-kĕtĕg ika n amriyambada</l>
.<l n="c">simbantĕn ngwang atön ri denya n amĕkul tĕngah ahuyang aminta sanmata</l>
.<l n="d">wālingnya n kakĕnan karāsikan inambwakĕna kalara ning kĕnêng hunĕng</l>
.</lg>
.<lg n="2"><l n="a">lāwan toh pangamāknya lĕnglĕng inaweśa kapuritĕn i pangdan ing smara</l>
3205<l n="b">bhrantajñāna kapĕñcir ing jariji len wĕtis anuji hunĕngnya mohita</l>
.<l n="c">epū twasnya karĕngrĕngan kasarik ing gĕlung alara kĕnêng matâmanis</l>
.<l n="d">tan wring rāt kapana n ginocara pameny amapaka rika lingnya lampunĕn</l>
.</lg>
. <!-- 2 (b) Q kapĕñcĕr -->
3210<lg n="3"><l n="a">nā ling śrī nṛpaputrikâlara sinewa lagi winuwusan nṛpātmaja</l>
.<l n="b">māskw indung tarimanta pamrih ing amangkwakĕn i kita hamanghya-manghyakĕn</l>
.<l n="c">yadyastun hinilanta ring smita tĕhĕr cacahakĕn ta yêng nakâlungid</l>
.<l n="d">mon mātyāku sapadya yan kalawanan bhaṣama ning angusir Smarālaya</l>
.</lg>
3215 <!-- 3 (b) S amanḍya-manḍyakĕna -->
.<lg n="4"><l n="a">sangsiptanya dĕlönta sotan ing akung tiki n amarĕkakĕn priyambada</l>
.<l n="b">sāhityân pangajap sihanta pamawan lara turida minuṣṭi tan bĕsur</l>
.<l n="c">māntĕn tan katĕkān prayojana marambatan ing ahayu ratnakanyakā</l>
.<l n="d">anghing ganya hinūrnya tan maliha kerang i manah ika tan sinanmatan</l>
3220</lg>
. <!-- 4 (d) LQ ngganya -->
.</div>
.<div type="canto" rend="met" n="51" met="aśvalalita">
.<lg n="1"><l n="a">ling ira narendraputra sira sang narendraduhitângĕsah kaparihan</l>
3225<l n="b">gupay anukĕr sirâtulak i pangrĕmih nira ta sang narendratanaya</l>
.<l n="c">wiphala pupug tikang kuku nahan pamādhaka nirâla[h] arddha kabalik</l>
.<l n="d">yaya tan awĕh lĕkas nṛpatiputra mangkin atalĕh-talĕh mangarĕki</l>
.</lg>
. <!-- 1 (b) Q pangrĕngih; S ira (c) S pamanḍakan; = LQ -->
3230<lg n="2"><l n="a">nṛpaduhitâti kepwan atahĕr ndatan pajamuga ng twas epw angĕsĕsan</l>
.<l n="b">tuhu nikanang tangis nira ya têki rakwa pangawör nirê nṛpasuta</l>
.<l n="c">kalalu ya tan hiniṣṭi panĕpak nirâlah alisuh ndatan pangupama</l>
.<l n="d">nṛpasuta mangkin anghudanakĕn prahāsana nira lwir ārṇnawa madhu</l>
.</lg>
3235</div>
.<div type="canto" rend="met" n="52" met="jagaddhita">
.<lg n="1"><l n="a">dyah [h]iṣṭangkw ibu puṇya denta pamatanta tan arĕngu minge tuminghala</l>
.<l n="b">heman têbu rirista tan panguningêng alara turida kokalan lulut</l>
.<l n="c">tan luh tan pangĕsah lawan prihati hetu ning akalib asewa tan lining</l>
3240<l n="d">hīnganya n kapana n wiwal ngwang iki n amrih anĕkĕn awilāśa ning marĕk</l>
.</lg>
.<lg n="2"><l n="a">kenaknyân ḍawuhĕn manista ta kari ng sinawawa ring akung ndatan cala</l>
.<l n="b">āpan wyarttha rĕngihta hetu ning angel cala-cala ring apa n kasinggihan</l>
.<l n="c">singgih yan panĕpak jajângayatakĕn kuku bisama hamöm wajâmirah</l>
3245<l n="d">nistanya n pinalalwakĕn* ḍatĕng i māsku patayaśa ni panghyang i nghulun</l>
.</lg>
. <!-- 2 (a) = LQ (d) Q omits n; LQ pinalaywakĕn -->
.<lg n="3"><l n="a">nāhan byakta ni kung sang Arjjuna madadyana wacana hanorakĕñ juruh</l>
.<l n="b">kĕdw āmbĕk nira tan kumölakĕn unĕng rinĕngihan ira lot sinikwakĕn</l>
3250<l n="c">ndan sang śrī nṛpaputrikâgĕyuh alök lalu wiphala tangis nirâtulak</l>
.<l n="d">tan wring dāya sirân kinewala makin linurung i palĕkas nṛpātmaja</l>
.</lg>
. <!-- 3 (a) Q manorakĕn (b) L kumĕlakĕn (c) Q ndah (d) Q deya; R linirung -->
.<lg n="4"><l n="a">byātītan panukĕr narendraduhitângĕlih alara kacidra ring gati</l>
3255<l n="b">sah ning siñjang irân minging ndan amĕḍar tĕngah añuriga rosnya komala</l>
.<l n="c">mangkin twas nira sang Dhanañjaya girahyasĕn i pangawat ing smarê sira</l>
.<l n="d">lwir kumbang wahu kāñaran tĕkap i rūm-rūm ing asana baśânĕsĕp madhu</l>
.</lg>
. <!-- 4 (d) S anĕcĕp -->
3260</div>
.<div type="canto" rend="met" n="53" met="mālinī">
.<lg n="1">
.<l n="a">ri huwus ira pinurwânglih lume śrī suputrī</l>
.<l n="b">nṛpatanaya manambut mār mrata twas nirônĕng</l>
3265<l n="c">sang ahayu sira sākṣāt raśmi ning padma rukṣa</l>
.<l n="d">cinulu-culuh ing ojar de nirângrĕs manguṇḍĕng</l>
.</lg>
. <!-- 1 (b) Q mrat ta -->
.<lg n="2">
3270<l n="a">nṛpasuta sira mangkin tibra de śrī suputrī</l>
.<l n="b">kawuwuhan i kĕñar ning <app><lem wit="#edc #msL">ḍīpa</lem><rdg wit="#msK">ḍipa</rdg></app> molĕm ndatan krām</l>
.<l n="c">makin asĕmu tulis mās de nirânglih tar olah</l>
.<l n="d">nṛpasuta tatan aśrw ângol amangkwângajum ken</l>
.</lg>
3275 <!-- 2 (b) = L, K ḍipa -->
.<lg n="3"><l n="a">kunĕng iki nṛpaputrī śoka moruk lumungsur</l>
.<l n="b">tuwin agila tĕkap ning siñjang amlĕs karāhan</l>
.<l n="c">krama umijil inĕmban sang priyâsih tan imbā</l>
.<l n="d">kamĕna nira sinocan ring surambyan cumuntĕn</l>
3280</lg>
. <!-- 3 (b) S umĕlĕs -->
.<lg n="4"><l n="a">kaka-kaka nira tan doh kapwa sāmpun sĕnāha</l>
.<l n="b">humĕnakĕn aḍamu wruh rînggitājñân patingkah</l>
.<l n="c">paḍa-paḍa winagĕd ring lālanâtyanta pattya</l>
3285<l n="d">awicarita sinocan dewi tar sah makarwan</l>
.</lg>
.<lg n="5"><l n="a">huwus aḍamu ta kālih sang sĕḍĕng wāhw apanggih</l>
.<l n="b">pinuyu-puyur iniryyan-hiryyan ing ceṭikâsih</l>
.<l n="c">rari palalun ing āmbĕk kölakĕn duhka mātra</l>
3290<l n="d">apan iki lara rakryan ndan ya malwī lulut twas</l>
.</lg>
. <!-- 5 (d) Q maluy for malwī -->
.<lg n="6"><l n="a">kusuma sarasija mrik mwang mĕnūr nāgapuṣpa</l>
.<l n="b">mapa kari pangadeśanya ndatan len ya yogya</l>
3295<l n="c">winiru-wiru tĕkap ning kumbang onĕng wiśīrṇna</l>
.<l n="d">taham ibu panahāngkwê māsku nāhan patĕmwa</l>
.</lg>
.<lg n="7"><l n="a">maluya rari usön ring weśma tântuk haram dyah</l>
.<l n="b">ahĕla-hĕla sang onĕng mogha hāmhām sirângher</l>
3300<l n="c">nahan ujar ika maswī ndan hanêrang suputrī</l>
.<l n="d">krama hinamĕr umantuk ring jinĕm mrik [h]umunggah</l>
.</lg>
. <!-- 7 (c) L tanêrang -->
.<lg n="8"><l n="a">riy ulih ira suputrī ryy ânta ning weśma rāmya</l>
3305<l n="b">nṛpasuta sira mangkin harṣa yêkângisapwan</l>
.<l n="c">angupuk-upuk amāswās nā ng mukâlurwa molĕm</l>
.<l n="d">tĕhĕr angaras awantö rūm ning ojar sawang truh</l>
.</lg>
.</div>
3310<div type="canto" rend="met" n="54" met="jagaddhita">
.<lg n="1"><l n="a">sang sākṣāt kadang ing wulan sang apatĕr turida sang ariris-riris langö</l>
.<l n="b">sang nityângdani kingking i ngwang asĕwö hunang athawa lulutkw asinwama</l>
.<l n="c">marmângol i raras-rarasta sahajâmwatakĕna sĕkar ing karāsikan</l>
.<l n="d">tan wring rāt ri sukangkwa yan kalawanan pawilĕtana ri tatwa ning gati</l>
3315</lg>
. <!-- 1 (b) L omits i (d) L ring for wring -->
.<lg n="2"><l n="a">mangke pwêki dĕlön harebu sipi bhāgya ning angajĕng (ng)acatwa cumbana</l>
.<l n="b">rūmtêndung pinakāntya jīwita silunglung ing anĕmu sayodya ring prĕman</l>
.<l n="c">manggĕh nitya sinandhi ring mata tamolah angañuta ri kingking i nghulun</l>
3320<l n="d">ndan yan mātya manĕhta sātmya ri manista ḍawuhĕn irikang tasik madhu</l>
.</lg>
. <!-- 2 (a) L ta rêbu; = LQ -->
.</div>
.<div type="canto" rend="met" n="55" met="kāmamālā">
3325<note>Creese calls this meter Wirat Tĕbu Sol.</note>
.<lg n="1">
.<l n="a">iti nā ta lālana nirânglipurakĕn i narendraputrikā</l>
.<l n="b">araras mananghulu maweh sĕpah arĕja mahânĕsĕp laṭi</l>
.<l n="c">tĕhĕr angririh-ririhi roma nira tama hamatya-matyani</l>
3330<l n="d">amasang-masang ndatan alĕh mayat i gĕmuh ikang payodhara</l>
.</lg>
. <!-- 1 (a) L -putrīkā (b) S saha for mahâ (c) L nirā (d) R ndan atalĕh, S nda atalĕh for ndatan alĕh -->
.<lg n="2">
.<l n="a">ahirit sinambangan irêng kakawin asĕmu mombakan langö</l>
3335<l n="b">sinĕlan-sĕlān ri rĕsĕp ing mangarĕki pipi rāmya meñjuha</l>
.<l n="c">ri pamāhwa-māhwan i manis ni culu-culuh irâmriyambada</l>
.<l n="d">anusah mayang wahu mĕkar ndan amanĕhi rinĕngwa-rĕngwakĕn</l>
.</lg>
. <!-- 2 (a) S irang -->
3340<lg n="3"><l n="a">papupul nṛpātmaja lawan nṛpawaraduhitā hanêng jinĕm</l>
.<l n="b">mangunĕng mĕnur paḍa nira n katirah angaras ing wĕlas-harĕp</l>
.<l n="c">alangö hatur lĕngĕng ikang gaḍung awilĕt arok wanañjari</l>
.<l n="d">nda nahan patūt nira tiki n prasama-sama tinunggal ing langö</l>
.</lg>
3345 <!-- 3 (d) Q ndan; Q panut -->
.<lg n="4"><l n="a">nṛpaputra rāmya ri dalĕm śayana kumawaśê* karāsikan</l>
.<l n="b">sakulĕm sirârddha tan arip lalu pangamĕr irê suputrikā</l>
.<l n="c">karĕngö prahāsana nirêka tĕkap ing anawing lawan rĕngih</l>
.<l n="d">saha nopurâsring atakis marahakĕna panandhi ning gati</l>
3350</lg>
. <!-- 4 (a) LQ kumawaśêng -->
.</div>
.<div type="canto" rend="met" n="56" met="navaharṣa">
.<lg n="1"><l n="a">kalalu ng wĕngi tan dwa rahina mawa teja ning ārkka lumöng</l>
3355<l n="b">irikā ta ḍatĕng kraban ira sahananya huwus marĕpat </l>
.<l n="c">paḍa tânupamâparimita kadi sangka ring Indrapada</l>
.<l n="d">winiśeṣa tĕkap narapati Harimūrtti makon tumatā</l>
.</lg>
.<lg n="2"><l n="a">wara saptakumārika tuwi mṛganābhi sugandha sumār</l>
3360<l n="b">ya mamungwa langĕnya ri sira sang amūrwwa hanêng śayana</l>
.<l n="c">mwang ikāng asĕp angrahagi sahaja subnya tĕkânglĕngĕngi</l>
.<l n="d">amapag raras ing cawĕni jamaṇikanya minging tan arĕn</l>
.</lg>
. <!-- 2 (c) L ikang -->
3365<lg n="3"><l n="a">gupit ārjja lawan kidung ika hanameni parĕng hangawat</l>
.<l n="b">kahiḍĕp lĕngĕng ing madhumasa ri haturnya sawang bhramara</l>
.<l n="c">swang angimbuhi raśmi tan ari pasajinya n amung salulut</l>
.<l n="d">angaweśa ri rĕs nira n anawung unĕng sagawenya marūm</l>
.</lg>
3370<lg n="4"><l n="a">ndah awās ira sang rwa tumama ri surambyan ira n <hi rend="superscript">†</hi>majajar</l>
.<l n="b">krama sāmpun asoca mangĕnakĕna bhūṣaṇa pahyas ira</l>
.<l n="c">anawung halĕp ing sarasija sinawang madhu rūpa nira</l>
.<l n="d">sinara n hana<hi rend="superscript">†</hi> ning kaka-kaka sararasnya n amaṇḍaga sök</l>
.</lg>
3375 <!-- 4 (a) LQ awās sira; S ajajar -->
.<lg n="5">
.<l n="a">wĕkasan wwaya <foreign>tâmwang</foreign> ira tinuha ring pura somya tuwi</l>
.<l n="b">winiweka sulakṣaṇa mangarahakĕn ri sirân mijila</l>
.<l n="c">irikā sira sang rwa tumuluy angadĕg mijilêng pasabhān</l>
3380<l n="d">paripūrṇna ta sang Yadukula hiniwö manaḍah ri yawa</l>
.</lg>
. <!-- 5 (a) Q hana ta for wwaya ta; MSS tamwang; S para for pura -->
.<lg n="6"><l n="a">adawā n mara tingkah ira kunĕng i lingsir ikang diwasa</l>
.<l n="b">umulih sira sang rwa mangalihi hanêng gṛha rāmya sira</l>
3385<l n="c">anamar lĕngĕng ing hasana kusuma rakwa lawan bhramara</l>
.<l n="d">angamĕr juga mangrĕbu-rĕbu mangudang rahat ing salulut</l>
.</lg>
.<lg n="7"><l n="a">ndan arĕn rĕngu sang nṛpawaraduhitâsih irân pasĕwö</l>
.<l n="b">ri sawet ni manis nṛpasuta malapi twas irân masuma</l>
3390<l n="c">kadi marmma nikang gaḍing amarĕkakĕn rarab ing jalada</l>
.<l n="d">rumĕsĕp sumusuk lulut ira mapisan ri narendrasuta</l>
.</lg>
. <!-- 7 (d) S nira -->
.<lg n="8"><l n="a">nṛpaputra samangkana papupul irêka mahâmirati</l>
3395<l n="b">ri kaśaktan i kung nira pinahayu de nira ring śayana</l>
.<l n="c">luru ning liring oma nira pasagi laipana suswa tĕnĕng</l>
.<l n="d">pangamĕr pinakārcana putus i sanidhya nirân saharas</l>
.</lg>
.<lg n="9"><l n="a">sumilih tikanang surasa ya ta bhinukti nirân sumaji</l>
3400<l n="b">mwang ikāng upabhoga ataca paribhoga taya ng kahala</l>
.<l n="c">wara sarwwa wiśeṣa hinabhimata de nira kapwa hana</l>
.<l n="d">apan uttama wīryya haji sakala pāwak ing āṣṭaguṇa</l>
.</lg>
.</div>
3405<div type="canto" rend="met" n="57" met="praharṣiṇī">
.<lg n="1"><l n="a">ndah yan mangkana papupul nirâtirāmya</l>
.<l n="b">tan warsih samanah irâhurup lulut kung</l>
.<l n="c">lunghā ng lek ata malawas [h]ulah nirâtūt</l>
.<l n="d">solur harṣa ta masĕwö hunĕng nirâbwat</l>
3410</lg>
.<lg n="2"><l n="a">sangsiptan patĕmu nira ndatan wiwākṣan</l>
.<l n="b">prāptā ng dwādaśa tikanang tahun linakwan</l>
.<l n="c">de sang Phalguṇa matutur sirê samangkā</l>
.<l n="d">an sang kāri mapa kunĕng mĕne n kawuntat</l>
3415</lg>
. <!-- 2 (b) S praptêng (c) L mangkā for samangkā -->
.<lg n="3"><l n="a">jātī ning dadi tamatan wĕnang wiyoga</l>
.<l n="b">tṛṣṇâgöng ya ta marumah malit rikang twas</l>
.<l n="c">yêkângde lara baribin kaweśa denya</l>
3420<l n="d">moghā n wismṛti ya pawehnya bhāwacakra</l>
.</lg>
. <!-- 3 (d) Q moga wismṛti -->
.<lg n="4"><l n="a">ngkā rakwân pangadĕhakĕn ri buddhi Pārtha</l>
.<l n="b">hetunya n mawara-warah sirê sang antĕn</l>
3425<l n="c">māskw indung kita rari jīwitangkwa sākṣāt</l>
.<l n="d">kingkingkw îbu pahalilang ta māryya śoka</l>
.</lg>
.<lg n="5"><l n="a">mangke pwâḍṛdha manamantarêng swacitta</l>
.<l n="b">göng ning bhakti ning ayayah lawan kakâsih</l>
3430<l n="c">sangkā yan [h]ati malawas sirân tinambang</l>
.<l n="d">ndah kāngĕn mapa ta wĕkas nirêng kaḍatwan</l>
.</lg>
. <!-- 5 (c) Q sangkê; = LQ -->
.<lg n="6"><l n="a">nghing rakryan panuluya bhakti ni nghulun dyah</l>
3435<l n="b">sihtângālihana umilwa ring swadeśa</l>
.<l n="c">rîndrapraṣṭha pahalawön humer kitântĕn</l>
.<l n="d">kesyan tang manah anulus swadharmma rakryan</l>
.</lg>
.<lg n="7"><l n="a">ndah yêki n patayaśa sanghulun harêbu</l>
3440<l n="b">prah-prahkw âniwi ri lĕbū ni jöng narendra</l>
.<l n="c">tan len māskw ibu dulurangkwa satyabhakti</l>
.<l n="d">ngkā rakryan pamahayu seccha Dharmmaputra</l>
.</lg>
. <!-- 7 (a) L arêbu (c) L îbu -->
3445<lg n="8"><l n="a">nā ling sang nṛpatanayângamĕr manantwa</l>
.<l n="b">ngkā dewī sira sumahur wuwus nirâsrĕt</l>
.<l n="c">swāmi wruhku bapa hiḍĕpta sādhu yogya</l>
.<l n="d">ndi ngwang tan tumuta purih nikang maniwya</l>
.</lg>
3450 <!-- 8 (c) Q omits bapa -->
.<lg n="9"><l n="a">anghing mohita tumukĕl larangkwa monĕng</l>
.<l n="b">ngkānêng raiṇa muwah i sang nariśwarâgöng</l>
.<l n="c">kintu pwa ng sanak angawe hunĕng ya manghrĕt</l>
.<l n="d">lud tapwan mamalĕs asih waśânglare twas</l>
3455</lg>
.<lg n="10"><l n="a">bhaktingkw î bapa bibi ta pwa tan wiwākṣan</l>
.<l n="b">sākṣāt parwwata Himawān lawan Sumeru</l>
.<l n="c">sih-sihkw î kita yadiyan hiwön winarṇna</l>
.<l n="d">sākṣāt sāgara paramâdhikāra ring lwā</l>
3460</lg>
. <!-- 10 (a) S omits ta pwa (c) L yadyan -->
.<lg n="11"><l n="a">tan warṇnan pangucap-ucap nirâta kālih</l>
.<l n="b">sāmpun māyu pasamayan narendraputra</l>
.<l n="c">ratry âmrĕm ta sira sarāmya ning jinĕm mrik</l>
3465<l n="d">tamtam twas nira manawung hunĕng sarāga</l>
.</lg>
. <!-- 11 (a) S yan for tan -->
.</div>
.<div type="canto" rend="met" n="58" met="jagaddhita">
3470<lg n="1"><l n="a">eñjing sang nṛpaputra karwa kalulut nira mawungu mijil sakêng jinĕm</l>
.<l n="b">ndah yêkā n tumuluy marêng makara rāmya sira tiki parĕng macāmana</l>
.<l n="c">ngkā n mĕntas sira kālih ing bañu silih tusapi muka paḍĕmwan ing mata</l>
.<l n="d"><hi rend="superscript">†</hi>lāgy âhyas tumatā patah mrik anĕcĕk-nĕcĕki sira narendraputrikā</l>
.</lg>
3475<lg n="2"><l n="a">sāmpun maywan atūt parĕng mijil<hi rend="superscript">† </hi>atuntunan angalihi de nirân laku</l>
.<l n="b">mambö Manmatha sang hyang ing śayana munggw i pamatan ira len wajâmanis</l>
.<l n="c">ngkānê tumpyaṭak ing surambyan irikā sira parĕng aśilâtitih pupū</l>
.<l n="d">hyang ning rāsika rakwa ling ning umulat ri pangisapu nirân maweh sĕpah</l>
.</lg>
3480 <!-- 2 (d) R inserts (lagya hyas tumata patah mrik) after pupu -->
.<lg n="3"><l n="a">yak mātyāku mapêki rāmya nika yapwan umaluya marêng madhubrata</l>
.<l n="b">eñjuh tan sah amuktya rūmta yan adadya ring asana minging hanêng taman</l>
.<l n="c">lĕnglĕngku n yadiyan kawantus irikang gaḍing angani linañcaran madhu</l>
.<l n="d">swarggā n mātya sinambyakĕñ juga lamun tĕlas aciri sukangkw añumbana</l>
3485</lg>
. <!-- 3 (d) S sinambwakĕn; L añumbani -->
.<lg n="4"><l n="a">nāhan de nira Pārtha mojar amanis sinamakĕna pamiṇḍa ning kilang</l>
.<l n="b">harṣâtön angĕluk-hĕluk jariji aṣṭa nira tĕhĕr ajambatan tĕngah</l>
.<l n="c">janggângol laris ing pupus gaḍing ulah nira lalita suminghitêng kapö</l>
3490<l n="d">nghing dewī mingay angrĕngih lagi lumĕnghay inarĕkan i sang nṛpātmaja</l>
.</lg>
.<lg n="5"><l n="a">tan warṇnan sawilāśa sang rwa wĕkasan sira mijil adulur marê dalĕm</l>
.<l n="b">ngkānê jöng nira sang narendra Basudewa hana sira lawan Halāyudha</l>
.<l n="c">mwang sang śrī naranātha Keśawa ḍatĕng nṛpasuta nguniweh suputrikā</l>
3495<l n="d">kapwâṇamya ri jöng narādhipa katanggama ta sira ri sang Dhanañjaya</l>
.</lg>
. <!-- 5 (c) S Krĕṣṇa ri for Keśawa -->
.<lg n="6"><l n="a">sĕmbah sang nṛpaputra sajña naranātha huningan iki panghyang i nghulun</l>
.<l n="b">amwīt mantuka têkihĕn manĕ-manĕhta narapati* humusap ri jöng haji</l>
3500<l n="c">manggĕh tan hiḍĕpan kṛtaghna makalis humilangakĕna puṇya sang prabhu</l>
.<l n="d">kady âdharmma ri denya sis bisama sang kaluputana sakêng prabandhana</l>
.</lg>
. <!-- 6 (a) Q ning for sang (b) L amwit (d) S hidĕpnya for ri denya -->
.<lg n="7"><l n="a">sāmpunya n pamuhun Dhanañjaya kinolakĕna sira tĕkap nareśwara</l>
3505<l n="b">bhoh rakryan wihikan nghulun bapa manahta taya cala gatinya don mami</l>
.<l n="c">yadyastun kawĕkas kitân tĕhĕr aparwakĕna nagara bhūmi punpunan</l>
.<l n="d">mwang têkang wara rājayogya sahanêng nagara kita mamuktya rumpwana</l>
.</lg>
.<lg n="8"><l n="a">manggĕh pwântusakĕnta māsku mulatêng kawiguṇan ing anātha kāsyasih</l>
3510<l n="b">haywêwĕh winuruk nda haywa pinalĕh tan alalisa ri sihta nistura</l>
.<l n="c">prihtêndung nyata dharmma ning kadi kitâniwi lawan ayayah pahaywana</l>
.<l n="d">mwang penâgraja yêka kawruhana sih nira katuturakĕn giṇâraray</l>
.</lg>
. <!-- 8 (c) Q kitâwini -->
3515<lg n="9"><l n="a">ndah mangkā pitutur nirâmṛta hiḍĕp nṛpatanaya tĕhĕr <foreign>kṛtāñjali</foreign></l>
.<l n="b">ngkā śrī Kṛṣṇa sirâwuwus tumuturê sira muliha sawet nirâlulut</l>
.<l n="c">mangkā śrī Baladewa nora kawĕkas manah ira tumutê nṛpātmaja</l>
.<l n="d">nghing manggĕh tak asung narendrasuta ling nira niyata hĕlĕm sirânglawad</l>
.</lg>
3520 <!-- 9 (a) MSS kṛtañjali (d) L ya ta for niyata -->
.</div>
.<div type="canto" rend="met" n="59" met="bhramaravilasita">
.<lg n="1"><l n="a">byātītan lwir nira n angucap-ucap</l>
.<l n="b">lunghā ng dūtâmawa wacana haji</l>
3525<l n="c">ri śrī Dharmātmaja yugala nira</l>
.<l n="d">rājyêndrapraṣṭha ya ta paran ikā</l>
.</lg>
.<lg n="2"><l n="a">ryy ângkat ning bhṛtya haji tan ucapĕn</l>
.<l n="b">tingkah sang Pārtha ta sira waluyan</l>
3530<l n="c">mantuk ri sthāna nira ta ri dalĕm</l>
.<l n="d">akweh tang Wṛṣṇikula lumawada</l>
.</lg>
.<lg n="3"><l n="a">enak pāwwat niki marĕk i sira</l>
.<l n="b">kapwângluh denya paḍa kamasihĕn</l>
3535<l n="c">jātī tṛṣṇângawaśa manaputi</l>
.<l n="d">kāngĕn sihnyê nṛpawaraduhitā</l>
.</lg>
. <!-- 3 (a) L pāwat -->
.<lg n="4"><l n="a">ndan dewy āmbĕk nira pinitangisan</l>
3540<l n="b">mogângluh nāla nira kawĕlasĕn</l>
.<l n="c">glānângaṇḍĕh sira mayat apasah</l>
.<l n="d">tan wring kwān ring kṣaṇa sira n asĕkĕl</l>
.</lg>
. <!-- 4 (d) Q anĕsĕl for asĕkĕl -->
3545</div>
.<div type="canto" rend="met" n="60" met="śārdūlavikrīḍita">
.<lg n="1"><l n="a">wwang ring rājya parĕng madandan umiwö wyāpāra munggw ing dalĕm</l>
.<l n="b">ewör <foreign>denya</foreign> samângarĕp madadakan kapwâsipĕt wruh kabeh</l>
.<l n="c">tan wāktan tikanang tumūt mara ring Indrapraṣṭha magyā parĕng</l>
3550<l n="d">somah kapwa humung gatinya sakulĕm mwang hyas tinūnyê hati</l>
.</lg>
. <!-- 1 (b) MSS denyā -->
.</div>
.<div type="canto" rend="met" n="61" met="śikhariṇī">
3555<lg n="1"><l n="a">wiwākṣan ring heñjing śubhadiwasa tang deśa wimala</l>
.<l n="b">lumampah Pārtha mwang kalulut ira māmwīt sira huwus</l>
.<l n="c">parĕng munggah munggw ing ratha sira n akarwan winulatan</l>
.<l n="d">tĕlas rabdha mwang Dāruki lari nira n rāmya mahalĕp</l>
.</lg>
3560 <!-- 2 (a) S pamarakṣa (c) S omits ning -->
.<lg n="2"><l n="a">samāpta pwêkang Wṛṣṇi bala pamarākṣê laku nira </l>
.<l n="b">wawang lunghā sangkêng nagara lari ning syandana huwus</l>
.<l n="c">manah ning kāryy āśā paḍa kamadĕlön lot hali-halin</l>
.<l n="d">mangö monĕng cittanya kadi tĕhĕr ānglimbangângiring</l>
3565</lg>
.<lg n="3"><l n="a">ndan akweh kingkingnya nda tucapa ta sang Paṇḍutanaya</l>
.<l n="b">makin mintar lampah nira atita tang wanwa kalakun</l>
.<l n="c">sakāmbah rāmyâsring ta manginĕpa samby âmĕng-amĕnga</l>
.<l n="d">liniśyan[-liśyan] manglalaha lumipur kung sang araras</l>
3570</lg>
. <!-- 3 (b) L atīta (c) S anamby; Q -amĕngan (d) = LQ -->
.<lg n="4"><l n="a">aneka lwir ning deśa tinĕmu nira n kapwa ya mawit</l>
.<l n="b">sĕnāhâwwat pawwatnya tuhu sira yan śreṣṭhi guṇamān*</l>
.<l n="c">yayā tan swang-swang de nira n amalĕs ing tuṣṭa dĕmakan</l>
3575<l n="d">paḍâsrah ryy āmbĕknya praṇamadara mangkwêng nṛpasuta</l>
.</lg>
. <!-- 4 (b) R gunawan -->
.<lg n="5"><l n="a">asowe yadyan warṇnana lawas irân lampah anginĕp</l>
.<l n="b">ḍatĕng rîndrapraṣṭhâta sira pinapag ning wwang i dalĕm</l>
3580<l n="c">makādi [ng] Kuntī Paṇḍusuta karuhun Dharmmatanaya</l>
.<l n="d">hatur tejândhākāra manahan ikang wwang sanagara</l>
.</lg>
. <!-- 5 (c) = L (d) S manah -->
.<lg n="6"><l n="a">wawang śrī Kuntī harṣa sira n amĕkul Pārthamahiṣī</l>
3585<l n="b">sawet ning göng ny āmbĕk nira gĕrĕmĕ de sang wahu ḍatĕng</l>
.<l n="c">sahôjar māskw indungku bapa ling irângrĕs kawĕtu luh</l>
.<l n="d">ya rakwânlĕs ngkānê gĕlungan ira sang karwa mararĕm</l>
.</lg>
. <!-- 6 (a) L Pārthamahārṣi (b) Q sawetnya for sawet ning (c) S awĕtu (d) S rwa for karwa -->
3590<lg n="7"><l n="a">kunang sang śrī Dharmātmaja sira tikin n arddha magirang</l>
.<l n="b">lawan Bhīma mwang wīra Nakula sang antĕn paḍa suka</l>
.<l n="c">tumon Pārthâpan wāhu maluy apupul digjaya tuwi</l>
.<l n="d">makolih hyang-hyang ning Yadu nagara sākṣāt kṛtayaśa</l>
.</lg>
3595 <!-- 7 (c) Q waluy -->
.<lg n="8"><l n="a">tangeh lwir ning tuṣṭi nrĕpati sakaḍatwan yan ujarĕn</l>
.<l n="b">parĕng mantuk ri jro kalima sira sang Paṇḍutanaya</l>
.<l n="c">makêring Kuntī tan kari sang ahajöng Pārthawanitā</l>
.<l n="d">tĕkap dewī Kṛṣṇâmwangi sira tĕlas marmma malulut</l>
3600</lg>
. <!-- 8 (c) S Pṛthadayita for Pārthawanitā -->
.<lg n="9"><l n="a">apūrwwa lwir ning pūja paḍa sumĕnehâta ri sira</l>
.<l n="b">śinantyan de sang brāhmaṇa nagara wiprâdi kuśala</l>
.<l n="c">pĕnuh pwêkang pānotsawa sahana ning manggala kabeh</l>
3605<l n="d">samanta strī kryan-kryan ta manguyut-uyut harṣa maniwi</l>
.</lg>
. <!-- 9 (c) L pannotsawa -->
.<lg n="10"><l n="a">samangkā ryy ântuk Phalguṇa makin agöng tang kasuyaśan</l>
.<l n="b">makin swastā ng rājyādhika pinahajöng tan pawaraṇa</l>
3610<l n="c">śubhikṣa pwa ng warṇnāśrama sahana ning pora mapulih</l>
.<l n="d">pratāpa śrī Dharmātmaja parama diwyâmayungi rāt</l>
.</lg>
.</div>
.<div type="canto" rend="met" n="62" met="jagaddhita">
3615<lg n="1"><l n="a">sāmpūrṇnân kadi sang hyang Indra mapa hanglĕwihi wibhawa anglyab ing hajöng</l>
.<l n="b">erang māryya kĕta[ng] durātmaka wiśīrṇna sulabha sira sang mahājana</l>
.<l n="c">ndin panglwang pitutur mahārṣi mawarah patayaśa śapa tanggwan indriya</l>
.<l n="d">sangkṣepanya kapat sapanggajaha sang ṛṣi kumĕmit i sang kaka sthiti</l>
.</lg>
3620 <!-- 1 (a) S sapa for mapa (b) S wiśirana; = LQ -->
.<lg n="2"><l n="a">śuddha bhyāṣa nirêng prajā mahayu dharmma makasuluh ing aṇḍa maṇḍala</l>
.<l n="b">kyāti ng rāt warawīryya kaprabhun irânulusakĕna surākṣa ning jagat</l>
.<l n="c">tāwat dharmma ri sang kṣinatriya tan ora kahala nira sang pinaṇḍita</l>
.<l n="d">wṛddhy ânūt kajanapriyan sira pangöban ing agati mahāt pakāśrayan</l>
3625</lg>
. <!-- 2 (b) S ira manulusakĕna (c) S yawat -->
.<lg n="3"><l n="a">anghing mangkana tântya ning carita kastawan ira hana ring jagaddhita</l>
.<l n="b">ngkā Pārthāyaṇa sangjña antuk ing angatpada kumawih anirwa-nirwakĕn</l>
.<l n="c">olugnyân palalun tĕkap sujana tan katugĕṭakĕna mon dinuryyaśa</l>
3630<l n="d">panggil śrī Surawīryya māsiha sirânganumata hamĕngānya pet langö</l>
.</lg>
. <!-- 3 (b) L sajña; LQ kumawi -->
.</div>
. </div>
3635 <div type="translation">
.<div><p>May there be no hindrance! </p></div>
.<div type="canto" n="1">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">The supreme truth that flows from flawless aesthetic experience is brought to fulfilment by the existence of the poet.</l>
.<l n="b">Absorbed in meditation, he finds harmony in the innermost part of his mind through unity with the rapturous beauty of the Lotus of Non-duality,</l>
3640<l n="c">And gives it visible form* in a <foreign>kakawin</foreign>, arranging it in lines, as the essence in the grooves [of the writing board] of the temple he builds with tendrils of beauty.</l>
.<l n="d">Indeed, it is the subtle form of the spell which renders invisible the rising of love* and finally becomes inconceivable formlessness.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">For if the deity is praised according to the prescriptions, He becomes embodied in the beauty of sea and mountain.</l>
.<l n="b">Clearly He merges with them, vanishing without trace into nothingness, inspiring the poetic sentiments that reach the ear.</l>
3645<l n="c">When the point of the stylus is completely worn away in the letters which form the black marks* on the writing board,</l>
.<l n="d">In this way he, who in performing his act of worship, falls at His feet, frames his first praises.*</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">Now I am enraptured, suddenly burdened with the desire to compose a poem* in homage to Beauty.</l>
.<l n="b">But how can I possibly succeed? It can only bring great trouble. How can it be considered apposite?*</l>
3650<l n="c">For so deeply does the rumbling of the clouds stir me that I am compelled to take up writing board and stylus, </l>
.<l n="d">Not cowering before the ignorance in my heart, but shamelessly and recklessly, longing only for skilfulness.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">When I ponder the evil nature of my fruitless existence, how cruel it seems. What can bring me contentment?</l>
.<l n="b">Because wickedness is ever-present, filling me with sorrow, I have renounced the hope of ever being free of it.</l>
3655<l n="c">I secretly conceal my bewilderment and confusion, for there is no one to whom I can cry out for help, as I encounter the disfavour of fate.</l>
.<l n="d">I want only to flee and dwell in a forest hermitage. There, alone, I may find peace.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">For any who seek such an end to wretchedness, there is the example* of the noble Arjuna,</l>
.<l n="b">Who, when Dropadī was together with Yudhiṣṭhira, entered the inner chamber.</l>
3660<l n="c">This deed caused him such anguish that he, too, wanted nothing more than to go away and dwell in the forest, </l>
.<l n="d">And seeking leave of the king, received his blessing before departing.</l></p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">The next morning, just as the rising sun shone forth in the eastern sky, the prince made ready.</l>
.<l n="b">Having completed his devotions, he then went out of the city,</l>
.<l n="c">His only companions his arrows, bow and armour, for these were the excellent weapons he bore,</l>
3665<l n="d">As is in accordance with the code of the warrior and is the way of those who seek to serve the world through valour.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">As he journeyed swiftly and without hindrance away from the kingdom, he was welcomed* by the beauties of nature.</l>
.<l n="b">He came upon many splendid gardens on the outskirts of the palace.</l>
.<l n="c">The trees, wrapped in mist, seemed to weep sorrowfully, as they cried aloud in their grief,* overwhelmed with longing.</l>
3670<l n="d">The young leaves of the beautiful sugar palms hung down in profusion, spreading outwards as if sighing with longing, giving free rein to their flowing tears.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">The prince continued on his way, journeying further and further from the town.</l>
.<l n="b">When he looked back, the place he had left behind had a dismal appearance and seemed despondent.</l>
.<l n="c">Without lustre, dejectedly hiding its charms, it seemed to want to keep itself hidden under a veil of grey.</l>
3675<l n="d">The glow of the half-risen sun was a red haze, like the bright glance of a girl dulled by yearning.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">Furthermore, the beauty along the delightful path he travelled, was the beauty of spring-time.</l>
.<l n="b">Their freshness fading*, becoming limp, the tree branches tossed feverishly in the wind,</l>
.<l n="c">Their rustling, the sighing plaint of a lover’s grief, their love for him unrequited.</l>
3680<l n="d">Their flowers, hanging down in abundance, fell to the ground all withered and lay scattered everywhere.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">There was* a young banyan tree and a number of fig trees rising on high, as well as <foreign>prih</foreign> and <foreign>bulu</foreign> trees.</l>
.<l n="b">Everywhere, pecking birds thronged together, while yet others came flying through the air, darting to and fro amongst the trees.</l>
.<l n="c">The mynah birds pretended to tease the parrots that joined them and drew near them respectfully.</l>
3685<l n="d">The voice of the <foreign>kuwong</foreign> sounded tremulously and was answered by the <foreign>walik,</foreign> lamenting that it had been abandoned by its mate, the <foreign>cucur.</foreign></l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">He arrived at the outlying districts where, in the fields on the mountain-slopes,</l>
.<l n="b">Herders were tending their cattle, resting peacefully there, where land had been cleared for fields along the mountain ridges.</l>
.<l n="c">Others were milking cows, for, since time immemorial, milk had been the produce that they took in homage to the palace</l>
3690<l n="d">At Indraprastha. Indeed, it is well known that this had always been their tribute and their prescribed duty.*</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="12"><l n="a">A rain-filled cloud had just loosed its rain, sprinkling it down on the settlements in the ravines.</l>
.<l n="b">Little by little, the breeze drove away the mist, leaving behind only the glow of the sun.</l>
.<l n="c">The love-sick <foreign>cātaka</foreign> bird became so steeped in melancholy, as the clouds dispersed and went away to the beauty of the hills, </l>
3695<l n="d">That it moved the prince to join with it, in looking dejectedly at the sky.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="13"><l n="a">Unhurriedly, he travelled on, passing by the forest pavilions.</l>
.<l n="b">The many hermitages and holy places he came upon were, in his view, all magnificent,</l>
.<l n="c">As indeed were all the religious abodes, foundations, monasteries and fine temples, quite splendid.</l>
3700<l n="d">Some time later, as the sun was setting, he came to the River Saraswatī.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="14"><l n="a">Truly spotless were its excellent and sacred waters used as the means of purification in these forest hermitages.</l>
.<l n="b">Moreover, within the enclosing walls of the artificial ponds they had formed a shallow <foreign>madraka</foreign> lake* that was without fault.</l>
.<l n="c">Its beautiful inlets formed a sculpted perimeter,* presenting to the beholder a vast array of lotus blossoms.</l>
3705<l n="d">As proof that its deep waters were without defect, they seemed to proclaim its perfection.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="15"><l n="a">The prince’s heart was filled with delight as he looked at the beauty of the great river.</l>
.<l n="b">Reminiscent of the charms of the tossing ocean was the rippling of the water, lapping and billowing.</l>
.<l n="c">A breeze gently touching them and lifting them into flashes of light,</l>
3710<l n="d">The waves danced gaily, full of joy at meeting the noble Arjuna.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="16"><l n="a">White swans glided here and there in the middle of the river* seeming to wander in pursuit of beauty.</l>
.<l n="b">Charmed, they listened intently to the buzzing of the bees, gaily courting [the flowers].</l>
.<l n="c">As if to tell them of the purity of the river, the wind held them captive, teasing them, tossing and turning them from side to side,</l>
3715<l n="d">But they just continued bathing, quite indifferent to the profusion of lotuses there, where they were wading.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="17"><l n="a">Across the pond in the shallow water, moving with studied grace,* </l>
.<l n="b">A duck and its mate moved off whispering endearments to each other.</l>
.<l n="c">They stayed there among the lotuses, happy in their love-making, causing a shower of pollen* to fall.</l>
3720<l n="d">How sad* that the blue lotuses, shaken to and fro, were crushed by their beating wings.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="18"><l n="a">The green banks seemed to have been beautifully adorned and ornamented</l>
.<l n="b">With moss,* which looked as though it had been scratched and seemed, appropriately, to imitate a dusting of powder,</l>
.<l n="c">And, like the shaved eyebrows of a beautiful girl, clearly aroused desire,</l>
3725<l n="d">While the <foreign>pakis ĕndah</foreign> fern in the water was like fragrant musk,* its perfume melting* away.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="19"><l n="a">Bees flew in circles in search of virgin delights in the entrancing beauty of the lotus.</l>
.<l n="b">Eagerly swarming to and fro, going longingly from flower to flower* to caress them, brushed gently by the pollen.</l>
.<l n="c">Their buzzing was like thunder in the fourth month, and their tender cries of victory were as gentle and graceful</l>
3730<l n="d">As the murmuring of sacred syllables, their gift of homage to the prince, to bring him constant delight.*</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="20"><l n="a">So he descended there, to wash his face and rinse his mouth in the ritual worship of the sun.</l>
.<l n="b">His weariness vanished and when he had completed his devotions, his heart became all the more tranquil.</l>
.<l n="c">Thereupon, he arose from the water, and again gave himself up to enjoyment, lying on a flat rock, </l>
3735<l n="d">And with delight, observed the shrimps that hid themselves behind the rocks and peeked out enticingly.*</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="21"><l n="a">Amused he watched the <foreign>pingul</foreign>-fish* playing far out in the water.</l>
.<l n="b">They teased each other, darting so swiftly back and forth that some sought shelter* under the rocks.</l>
.<l n="c">There was great confusion in the river when, with great caution, the timid catfish came out, one after the other,</l>
3740<l n="d">But then, startled, dashed for cover* into the marsh-land as the birds swooped down on them.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="22"><l n="a">Even more enchanting was the wondrous mountain stream, which seemed to merge* into the sky,</l>
.<l n="b">And, in the setting sun, with wilted flowers scattered on the rippling water, </l>
.<l n="c">It took on* the beauty of embroidered cloth, like a blanket of brilliant stars,</l>
3745<l n="d">And seemed to make a perfect flower obeisance, as if to say this is our offering* to you - or so he thought.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="23"><l n="a">And the brightness of the <foreign>aśoka,</foreign>*<foreign> asana </foreign>and <foreign>bāṇa</foreign> flowers paled in the reflected light along the river-banks.</l>
.<l n="b">The charms of the honey trees* faded and dimmed as their flower buds* were swept away,*</l>
.<l n="c">Thinking only of how delightful it would be, never losing hope* that they might be sought out as the flower-ornaments* of lovers happening by.</l>
3750<l n="d">At peace, now that the bees had abandoned them and no longer sipped their perfume, they waited to fall.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="24"><l n="a">In all its beauty, it was a perfect bower for lovers to worship at the shrine of the pleasures of love.</l>
.<l n="b">There were <foreign>tañjung</foreign> flowers, poignantly casting the message of the hidden perfume of their petals on the wind,*</l>
.<l n="c">Giving forth such delightful fragrance that the blossoming <foreign>śikhari</foreign> could do nothing but seek cover behind the <foreign>wungū.</foreign></l>
3755<l n="d">Moreover,* arching over, flowers unfurled, they stood ready to watch over those tormented by pangs of love.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="25"><l n="a">Even as the sun began to set and the beauty of that place became dim and melancholy, still it was enchanting.</l>
.<l n="b">It seemed a pity that no poet came wandering by on his journey, to tell of its charms on his writing board.</l>
.<l n="c">When lo, a peacock appeared and stopped to rest there, for all the world like just such a wanderer in pursuit of beauty,</l>
3760<l n="d">So aptly storing in its poetic cries the delights of the Saraswatī River.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="26"><l n="a">With tranquil mind [Arjuna] lost himself in contemplation, as, preparing for what lay ahead,* he pondered thus:</l>
.<l n="b">‘Successful are they who attain freedom from passion and think only of the ultimate goal of becoming a supreme sage.</l>
.<l n="c">Yet because of the extent of the ten senses,* crushing the innermost recesses of the heart,* subjecting it to their will, </l>
3765<l n="d">Meditation on Śiwa is destroyed and annihilated and there is the risk that passion and darkness* will rise up.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="27"><l n="a">‘Only excellence of mind should be practised in order to reach the essence of existence.</l>
.<l n="b">Clearly it is like the wheel of a chariot, which, if loosened, has no purpose at all.</l>
.<l n="c">For the true nature of corporeal existence is nothing less than offering oneself up in sacrifice through excellent meritorious deeds.</l>
3770<l n="d">And so, clearly, in this life, the best course is to be willing to face the arduous task* of living virtuously.’</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="28"><l n="a">This was the essence of his reflections on mastering the injunctions of the holy seers.</l>
.<l n="b">As if in confusion the heart, subject as it is to the ten senses, turns this way and that, in every direction, when meditating.</l>
.<l n="c">Disunity of mind then allows troubles to enter and brings aversion to the innermost secrets of meditation.</l>
3775<l n="d">And so, soothed by the rumbling voice of the <foreign>kuwong</foreign>, he then fell silent<foreign>.</foreign></l>
.</p>
.</div>
.<div type="canto" n="2">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">In the late afternoon he set off again,</l>
3780<l n="b">With his heart firmly fixed on his goal of reaching the Himālaya mountains.</l>
.<l n="c">And as his journey took him to the east, effortlessly, along a flat valley road,</l>
.<l n="d">He was entranced at the sight of the birds, flying in formation, then vanishing from sight.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">The faint fragrance of the forest flowers* wafting in the breeze, was delightful.</l>
3785<l n="b">His heart aflutter,* he hearkened to the buzzing of the bees.</l>
.<l n="c">To him, their murmurs were the whisperings of those who know love for the first time,</l>
.<l n="d">And the intermittent cries of the magnificent peacocks delighted him.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">From* clusters of forest flowers, fragrance spread like falling rain,</l>
3790<l n="b">As the gentle breeze hunted them out, enhancing their radiant beauty.</l>
.<l n="c">Flowers lay scattered, some like fallen arrows,* others intertwined </l>
.<l n="d">In the thickets of <foreign>luruk-luruk, </foreign>like flowers in a hair-knot.*</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">In the heat, the <foreign>suḍa,</foreign>* its creepers unfurling, wilted too, sad and downcast.</l>
3795<l n="b">A profusion of <foreign>katirah</foreign> hung down, its aerial shoots* throwing themselves to the ground,* moving to and fro imploringly.</l>
.<l n="c"><foreign>Pakis haji </foreign>ferns shook and in frenzied longing hid themselves away,</l>
.<l n="d">While <foreign>wĕlas-harĕp</foreign> creepers formed a concealing curtain for a lover’s retreat.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">The buds of the <foreign>mangunĕng</foreign> creeper* hung limply and seemed dull as the sun’s rays beat down on them.</l>
3800<l n="b">Weary, sighing plaintively, their supple boughs bending low without strength, they waited for the thunder.</l>
.<l n="c">Huddled in their sheaths, the <foreign>gĕsing</foreign> bamboos rustled in the awesome grip of passion,</l>
.<l n="d">Restive, as the <foreign>prabhu sanmata</foreign> enclosed them in its soft embrace.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">The dense thickets were hidden from view* under a tangle of fearful creepers,</l>
3805<l n="b">That hung upside down, covering* the pendant <foreign>halikukun,</foreign> unfurling there.</l>
.<l n="c">The <foreign>kayĕn</foreign> trees which rose up in the valleys, burst into blossom and held themselves in readiness.</l>
.<l n="d">In the stillness, a <foreign>cĕb luput</foreign> bird opened wide its eyes, as a mouse scuttled by.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">Let us pass over the time when the prince wound his way through the forest. </l>
3810<l n="b">Here he traversed a deep water-course, there ravines and rugged mountains, difficult of access,* </l>
.<l n="c">But he was content as he sought his destination – the source of that river of flawless purity,</l>
.<l n="d">And there, in a welcoming hermitage, he found shelter for the night.*</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">Faithful to his [vow] of striving for detachment,* the prince again sought solitude,</l>
3815<l n="b">The wooded hills* his sole companions as he travelled on.</l>
.<l n="c">And they, determined to receive him with joy as an honoured guest, offered their many fruits to him.</l>
.<l n="d">While, nearby, a splendid waterfall readied itself to be his holy bathing place.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">He came at last to the Hima mountain, with its splendid settlements.</l>
3820<l n="b">It was as resplendent as the abode of the gods in the glow of the setting sun.</l>
.<l n="c">White clouds enshrouded it like magnificent battlements,</l>
.<l n="d">And it seemed to have exchanged its beauty* for that of the heavens.</l>
.</p>
.</div>
3825<div type="canto" n="3">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">The beautiful mountain scenery seemed to be in restless motion.</l>
.<l n="b">As if calling to him, the casurinas rustled, tossing and turning in the wind.</l>
.<l n="c">Waiting expectantly, the dancing branches* whispered,</l>
.<l n="d">Their graceful, overhanging shoots ever reaching out to him.</l>
3830</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">On the densely-forested slopes were gardens, </l>
.<l n="b">All the more beautiful for they were shafted with bands* of golden sunlight.</l>
.<l n="c">With infinite care, they had adorned themselves delightfully with flowers, their blossoms agleam, </l>
.<l n="d">And seemed to have decorated themselves for joy that Arjuna, the son of Pāṇḍu, was visiting* there.</l>
3835</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">On reflection, it seemed the forest had prepared a welcome for its guest:</l>
.<l n="b">The gift it offered was the profusion of blossoming flowers so beautifully spread before him.</l>
.<l n="c">With wavering fronds* and red petals, the flame trees,</l>
.<l n="d">Like lips eagerly seeking pleasure, awaited him.</l>
3840</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">With its many valleys, it was as grand and idyllic as the Nandana grove.*</l>
.<l n="b">Its delightful caves, quite extraordinary in their perfection, were its ornaments.</l>
.<l n="c">Among its trees of many kinds were the heavenly coral-trees,* fresh and blossoming,</l>
.<l n="d">With a canopy of trailing,* leafy fronds unfurling.</l>
3845</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">A river flowed delightfully into the crevices of the craggy peaks.</l>
.<l n="b">Streams spouted from the rocks, forming a pond like a small sea.</l>
.<l n="c">The rock face was of such brilliance that it challenged the beauty of the ocean,</l>
.<l n="d">With scattered, flowering pandanus draped* everywhere over its lovely stones.</l>
3850</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">Pārtha’s heart was captivated as he climbed higher and higher up Mount Hima.</l>
.<l n="b">He became ever more amazed as he gazed upon its celestial beauty.</l>
.<l n="c">It towered over the realm of the Bhāratas,</l>
.<l n="d">Looking down on the steep valleys of the eastern mountain with its one hundred holy bathing pools.</l>
3855</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">Over a ravine so deep and impenetrable* that it was lost to view, clouds gathered,</l>
.<l n="b">To merge into its gleaming sulphur, caressing it, veiling it,</l>
.<l n="c">Forming a bright shining halo of light,*</l>
.<l n="d">Pregnant with the soft rain that is always betokened* by the voice of the thunder.</l>
3860</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">A gleam of water marked the location of the spotless river.*</l>
.<l n="b">Indeed here was the ‘Gateway of the Ganges’,* guarding the secret of its purity.</l>
.<l n="c">‘I will go* there’, he thought, and set off, making his way down</l>
.<l n="d">Along a narrow, rugged path, strewn with boulders, through the sharp and jagged ravines.</l>
3865</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">So arduous was it, that it hardly seemed possible a mere mortal could penetrate its depths and reach the bottom,</l>
.<l n="b">Unless he were a perfect sage or an excellent priest who had put aside worldly concerns.*</l>
.<l n="c">Thus it was proof of the true excellence of this son of Pāṇḍu,</l>
.<l n="d">That, engaged as he was in striving for the welfare of the world, he came there with ease.</l>
3870</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">And so it was that Pārtha came there to that remote river,*</l>
.<l n="b">And beheld the well-spring of the River Ganges, utterly flawless and without stain,</l>
.<l n="c">Flowing from a fissure in its unfathomable depths, its eddying waters gushed forth,</l>
.<l n="d">Like the emanation of the moon, giving life to all the world.</l>
3875</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a"> On reaching it, the prince was filled with great peace,*</l>
.<l n="b">As he gazed upon the clear water of the Ganges, the water of life,</l>
.<l n="c">For indeed it was ever the means to assuage the despairing heart.</l>
.<l n="d">Descending to the source* of holy water, he bathed in its waters and purified himself.</l>
3880</p>
.</div>
.<div type="canto" n="4">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">Thus Pārtha came to those sacred waters.*</l>
.<l n="b">As he immersed himself in the waters of the source of that river, possessed of sanctifying power.</l>
3885<l n="c">Its full-flowing waters truly cleansed his mind, </l>
.<l n="d">As he recited incantations and performed his devotions.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">He concentrated his mind on the immaterial presence of Śiwa,*</l>
.<l n="b">Arising from the eight-petalled lotus, and firmly established* in the river.</l>
3890<l n="c">The essence of the sun* was invoked into the firmament,</l>
.<l n="d">As, absorbed* in meditation, he became one in union with the sacred symbol.*</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">A beautiful woman appeared in the presence of the prince.</l>
.<l n="b">Her perfection was such that she seemed to be the younger sister of Beauty itself, bringing love.</l>
3895<l n="c">She was indeed the month of spring, the embodiment of all that is lovely.</l>
.<l n="d">Her sweetness held the longed-for charms of the moon.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">Clearly she would arouse the bemused poet, wandering in pursuit of beauty, from his reverie.*</l>
.<l n="b">Like the fall of a fine misty rain, her enchanting hair-knot diffused its fragrance.</l>
3900<l n="c">Her ear-rings shone all the while, revealing sudden flashes of lightning,</l>
.<l n="d">And the glow of her shining face ever enhanced her radiance.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">Pārtha had now finished his dawn worship,*</l>
.<l n="b">And his heart seemed to stop as he saw her appear as if from nowhere.</l>
3905<l n="c">None other than the Goddess of the Hima mountain and the River Jāhnawī was she,</l>
.<l n="d">And now he became more convinced that she was a vision.*</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">‘Where are you bound, little sister? gently he asked,</l>
.<l n="b">‘In journeying to this mountain, where I travel on pilgrimage to the sacred waters,</l>
3910<l n="c">I had not thought it would also be the destination of those who wish to abandon themselves to the pursuit of Beauty.</l>
.<l n="d">Yet you are a jewel, Beauty itself, my wondrous one.*</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a"> ‘How foolish I am, making bold to presume that you could only be properly*</l>
.<l n="b">Depicted as the riches of a garden offering its beauty:</l>
3915<l n="c">Your teeth gleam with the allure of <foreign>śrīdanta</foreign> flowers,</l>
.<l n="d">And [red] <foreign>handul</foreign> flowers are always as one with your gums.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">‘The striking beauty of the <foreign>katirah</foreign> flower finds refuge in your lips,</l>
.<l n="b">And in your eyes rests the dark beauty of the blue lotus.</l>
3920<l n="c">In your neck is the slenderness of the fresh <foreign>jangga</foreign> vine, its shoots unfurling,</l>
.<l n="d">And I cannot but think, my lady, that the <foreign>mangunĕng</foreign> has taken on the form of your lovely hair-band.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">‘Your slender body is a blossoming <foreign>priyaka.</foreign> </l>
.<l n="b">Your arms put to shame the tendrils of the delightful <foreign>aśoka,</foreign></l>
3925<l n="c">Your calves disturb the fragrant pandanus,</l>
.<l n="d">While your full breasts imitate* the rounded, ivory coconuts.’</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">Thus did Pārtha sing her praises with sweet words.</l>
.<l n="b">Understanding his allusion, the maiden said:</l>
3930<l n="c">‘O my Lord! Your perfection* indeed exceeds that of mortal men.</l>
.<l n="d">For you have come here to this place, where I have never before seen a soul.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">‘Your mighty deed is great, even incomparable, </l>
.<l n="b">You have succeeded in penetrating the inaccessible Hima mountain.</l>
3935<l n="c">It is the highest degree of excellence, and </l>
.<l n="d">You are fitting to be the refuge of those who seek the prosperity of the world.’</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="12"><l n="a">Thus she said, soothingly addressing kind and friendly words to him.</l>
.<l n="b">And Phalguṇa, with gentle words respectfully replied:</l>
3940<l n="c">‘Dear maiden, who are you, O beautiful one, who comes here?</l>
.<l n="d">Tell me truthfully, great is my concern [for you]!</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="13"><l n="a">‘Dear maiden, are you, little sister, a goddess in immaterial form?</l>
.<l n="b">Because all that is charming waits upon you,</l>
3945<l n="c">The flowers all seek refuge with you.*</l>
.<l n="d">Clearly they lie in wait here to scratch you, that you might see how they long to attend upon you.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="14"><l n="a">‘Truly the incarnation of the entrancing beauty of the fourth month, are you,</l>
.<l n="b">The ethereal deity of the sea of honey in bodily form.</l>
3950<l n="c">It is as if to seek to express the marvels of the ocean in poetry</l>
.<l n="d">Or to ascribe beauty to the mountains, would cause confusion.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="15"><l n="a">‘Further, my dear, is it not fruitless for you to stay so pitifully </l>
.<l n="b">In this inaccessible, remote place, all alone?</l>
3955<l n="c">Though you seem undaunted, are you not fearful to stay in these wooded hills,</l>
.<l n="d">Where lions, elephants, snakes and tigers lie in wait?’</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="16"><l n="a">In this way the prince questioned her closely.</l>
.<l n="b">The one addressed so sweetly, answered him truthfully:</l>
3960<l n="c">‘My lord, listen to me, your servant,</l>
.<l n="d">I am a woman, called Ulupuy, beset by love.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="17"><l n="a">‘I will tell you why I have taken on the form of a woman.</l>
.<l n="b">There is a king, His Majesty, Korawya, a renowned and illustrious mighty serpent,</l>
3965<l n="c">Who alone is so awesome in his power</l>
.<l n="d">That his irresistible valour is without equal in the three worlds.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="18"><l n="a">‘His kingdom too is of extraordinary, outstanding splendour</l>
.<l n="b">Because of the lustre of its countless gems and jewels.</l>
3970<l n="c">Like Indra’s heaven, its beauty is without flaw,</l>
.<l n="d">And by dint of its very nature, <foreign>parijāta</foreign> and <foreign>kalpawṛkṣa</foreign> trees grow there.*</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="19"><l n="a">‘Moreover, even heaven is inferior to it, its beauty rivalled</l>
.<l n="b">By the unique fashioning of the underworld.*</l>
3975<l n="c">Truly, it is a creation of Lord Brahma himself,</l>
.<l n="d">Unparalleled, for he has given his full attention to its creation.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="20"><l n="a">‘This then is where the foremost king of the snakes dwells in contentment.</l>
.<l n="b">All vassal snakes are loyal to him,</l>
3980<l n="c">And as for me, I am the daughter of the snake king,</l>
.<l n="d">And from time immemorial, I have never known the least sorrow.</l>
.</p>
.</div>
.<div type="canto" n="5">
3985<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">‘My father has so lavished upon me the quintessence of supreme happiness,</l>
.<l n="b">That I found myself unable to take any pleasure in anything, so sated* was I by such infinite bliss.</l>
.<l n="c">I could not resist searching out the peace of this lonely, secluded place,</l>
.<l n="d">But upon reaching here, suddenly I came upon you, seeking union with the god in the River Jāhnawī.</l>
.</p>
3990<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">‘And thus I was smitten by violent passions, wounded by Smara’s fiery arrow.</l>
.<l n="b">It is only by tasting* the flow of your sweetness that my desire and longing can find respite.</l>
.<l n="c">For the goddess Ratih, Goddess of Love, has so enflamed the feelings of this yearning, lovesick woman,</l>
.<l n="d">Who hopes for the excellent ambrosia of your love, for you are the embodiment of the God of Love himself.</l>
.</p>
3995<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">‘Moreover, could it possibly be fitting for you to live in the forest, staying in the undergrowth in such a pitiable condition,</l>
.<l n="b">Eager to conceal yourself, seeking shelter under overhanging rocks, emaciated, unkempt and lack-lustre?</l>
.<l n="c">How can you find enjoyment, resting on a bed of dry, withered, fallen leaves?</l>
.<l n="d">Words cannot describe how your body has wasted away, and has lost its strength and become wrinkled from long contact* with them.</l>
.</p>
4000<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">‘In short, my lord, please come with me now to the kingdom of the serpent king and seek </l>
.<l n="b">To enjoy the happiness that my great devotion will afford you. I beg of you, please accept my offer.</l>
.<l n="c">There is no doubt you will be accorded the devotion of all the snakes. Their only wish will be to serve you</l>
.<l n="d">With food and refreshments, caring for your every wish, joining with you in sexual union.’*</l>
.</p>
4005<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">Thus implored Ulupuy, overcome by passion. Pārtha answered lovingly and sweetly:</l>
.<l n="b">‘O most excellent jewel among women! My dear! By stealth you have captivated my very heart.</l>
.<l n="c">Alas, though, the charm of your seductive words cuts me to the quick, cruelly breaking my heart into little pieces,</l>
.<l n="d">My dear, I must ask you to accept that I must refuse your love, O little sister.</l>
.</p>
4010<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">‘For I am now bound by the agreement that Nārada has ordained,</l>
.<l n="b">To live as a <foreign>brāhmācārya</foreign>, holding to chastity. That is the reason I wander here in the Himālaya, seeking solitude.</l>
.<l n="c">Only after twelve years will it end and I must wait until that time has elapsed.</l>
.<l n="d">But how it casts me down, now that I, too, am filled with the desire to enjoy sexual union anew.’*</l>
.</p>
4015<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">Thus Arjuna gave her answer, and again the girl spoke:</l>
.<l n="b">‘O my lord, you are mistaken in taking so much to heart the words of the seer.</l>
.<l n="c">I understand what he meant in urging you to comply with his instruction.</l>
.<l n="d">But surely your solemn and abiding vow was intended only to apply to the Lady Dropadī?</l>
.</p>
4020<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">‘With another, how could it be wrong for you to devote yourself to love-making?</l>
.<l n="b">It would not be adultery if you were to accept my words that speak of seeking sensual pleasure.*</l>
.<l n="c">The purpose of assiduously performing the yoga of love is the prosperity of your lineage,</l>
.<l n="d">So that in practising it and becoming steadfastly absorbed in it, you may achieve the Absolute.’*</l>
.</p>
4025</div>
.<div type="canto" n="6">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">How could the prince do other than accept her words, seeking to woo him?</l>
.<l n="b">He tried to curb his doubts then, for her words, asking to be accepted, rang true.</l>
.<l n="c">And so he sanctioned* them, receiving them favourably, for they were so meet.</l>
4030<l n="d">Moreover, their sweetness was without flaw. ‘No harm* can come of this’, he thought.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">And so he decided to follow his desires,* as is the nature of hearts that share love.</l>
.<l n="b">The prince stood up, made ready, and followed the snake girl.</l>
.<l n="c">Through a split in the earth’s surface, they took the road to the underworld.</l>
4035<l n="d">But even as they walked on together, without stopping to rest, he took pleasure in the features of the path that she pointed out to him.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">They came to her home, a place* where the buildings were of incomparable splendour.</l>
.<l n="b">The houses were made of gold and all the gateways and fences were of gold and jewels.</l>
.<l n="c">With its adornments radiating a shimmering glow, it looked like an orb of light, </l>
4040<l n="d">And its dazzling beauty seemed to emanate* from heaven.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">The world of the gods is made radiant by the sun, that most excellent of brilliant jewels.</l>
.<l n="b">It is impossible* for it to grow dim there, even when daylight passes and night falls.</l>
.<l n="c">As for the underworld, when night comes there, the darkness is diminished,</l>
4045<l n="d">For there is constant light from the ever-gleaming crystal and jewels.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">The snake girl led the prince within,</l>
.<l n="b">And presented to him the beauty of the place: its golden encircling walls* were indeed perfect.</l>
.<l n="c">Beautiful women sat there, like scattered jewels loosened from a string. Sweet were their charms,</l>
4050<l n="d">Their side-ways glances arousing desire, their supple bodies the very embodiment of young boughs.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">There were some who drew near, ready to receive him, eager to provide all that is due to a guest,</l>
.<l n="b">Sweetly displaying the fire of their natures in their subtle gestures.*</l>
.<l n="c">Delightfully bespattered with a dusting of flower-pollen, fragrantly perfumed with musk,</l>
4055<l n="d">Their loveliness was enough to render him speechless, as they seemed to offer their sweetness to his gaze.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">There was a pavilion of crystal, its roof a <foreign>madana-</foreign>lotus* of chased gold,</l>
.<l n="b">With a wonderful arrangement of flower-shaped adornments, formed of brilliant jewels.</l>
.<l n="c">There was, as well, a couch awaiting there, the visible manifestation of a hymn to love.*</l>
4060<l n="d">Its painted cloths were decorated with clusters of rays, so that it seemed to be the moon’s secret hide-away.*</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">And so the beautiful girl and the prince mounted the curtained bedstead.</l>
.<l n="b">Under the ineluctable force of their love, they found harmony at once, their feelings as one.</l>
.<l n="c">Their union there on that lovely couch was full of joy, the essence of sweet delight,</l>
4065<l n="d">And they seemed the incarnation of the beautiful jasmine, intertwined with the <foreign>gaḍung.</foreign></l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">Or their union was perhaps that of flower buds seeking to draw near to the beauty of the river.</l>
.<l n="b">Clearly the two on the couch were Ratih and Manasija, goddess and god of Love.</l>
.<l n="c">The entwining of their souls* in sexual congress formed a temple for the innermost expression of the art of love.*</l>
4070<l n="d">Suddenly they could no longer resist tasting the welcome delights* of love-making.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">Later, when they had been united together in the raptures of love there on the bed,</l>
.<l n="b">Their sudden delight knew no bounds, their very hearts were touched in their new-found mastery.*</l>
.<l n="c">Together they came out and sat side by side outside the pavilion,</l>
4075<l n="d">Where their waiting retinue approached them to wait upon them and offer them all that had been prepared.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">As they sat outside the crystal pavilion it was as if they had descended from Smara’s heaven.</l>
.<l n="b">Again and again they partook of the many delicacies of exquisite flavour that stood ready.</l>
.<l n="c">After they had eaten they again withdrew and together climbed onto the couch,</l>
4080<l n="d">Tirelessly seeking union there on the bed, never wearying of love-making.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="12"><l n="a">Blissfully, these enamoured lovers dallied together there on the couch.</l>
.<l n="b">Then, they wandered together out into the garden, wanting to be alone.</l>
.<l n="c">Inseparable, they again sought bliss there in the moonlight,</l>
4085<l n="d">Even resting together on a bed of flowers and leaves.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="13"><l n="a">The joyful harbinger of the fourth month, the thunder, brought the promise of soft rain.</l>
.<l n="b">They wandered here and there, happily stopping from time to time at a hermitage.</l>
.<l n="c">Moreover on the bank of the river that descended into the ravines near the most inaccessible gullies,</l>
4090<l n="d">There was a spring where they disported together, constant companions, taking with them as provisions only their love and desire.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="14"><l n="a">For a long time they lived together in love, delighting in their passion and love-making,</l>
.<l n="b">Adept at devoting* themselves to love, ever-willing to surrender to pleasure,</l>
.<l n="c">Joyfully tasting* the doctrine of love perfected by Dhanañjaya,</l>
4095<l n="d">Striving after union with the deity of love in immaterial form, abandoning themselves to the delights of bliss.*</l>
.</p>
.</div>
.<div type="canto" n="7">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">For a long time he stayed in the underworld,*</l>
4100<l n="b">And before long an excellent and perfect child was born,</l>
.<l n="c">Who was later acknowledged as a hero in battle,</l>
.<l n="d">And was called Irawan, the renowned.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">The prince had not forgotten</l>
4105<l n="b">His mission, bearing it constantly in mind,</l>
.<l n="c">And so he prepared to set off again,</l>
.<l n="d">Gently explaining to his beloved.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a"> He went on his way to other places,</l>
4110<l n="b">And came finally to the Hima mountain.</l>
.<l n="c">Travelling easily wherever he wished, he made his way</l>
.<l n="d">Through the many hills and valleys.</l>
.</p>
.</div>
4115<div type="canto" n="8">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">He reached a wondrous, rugged mountain range of unearthly beauty,</l>
.<l n="b">The renowned Nilaśṛngga.* The thick undergrowth of its foothills was difficult to traverse.</l>
.<l n="c">Its winding gullies were deep, its peak towered over the ravines.</l>
.<l n="d">Rushing streams welled up from their source and plummeted down into the valleys.</l>
4120</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">Pure mountain brooks whirled and gushed* from the crevices in the hills,</l>
.<l n="b">Shining silver-bright, for all the world like the milk of the earth.</l>
.<l n="c">Merrily a dove bathed and fluttered its wings, sporting and playing in the water,*</l>
.<l n="d">Accompanied by its entire family, all of whom had joined in this visit to the holy bathing pool of the seers.</l>
4125</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">The beauty spots towering high above were a delight to see.</l>
.<l n="b">On the hillsides, hermitages nestled at the edges of the ravines.</l>
.<l n="c">Dotted here and there, in delightful clusters,</l>
.<l n="d">Were <foreign>puṣpadeha*</foreign> trees, all aflame, like carefully tended fires* that are never allowed to go out.</l>
4130</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">Enchanting was the sight of all the accomplished, charming anchoresses.</l>
.<l n="b">The sweetness they presented to his gaze, as he beheld them, was that of <foreign>campaka</foreign> flowers.</l>
.<l n="c">With veiled looks,* as is only to be expected, they threatened him with their quivering eyebrows,</l>
.<l n="d">But their sidelong glances, with hidden smiles, were as sweet as syrup.</l>
4135</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">There, in the outer gardens, they gaily gathered vegetables and mushrooms,</l>
.<l n="b">As well as <foreign>lalab</foreign>,* which they wrapped in their breast cloths, with never a thought to their [bare] breasts.</l>
.<l n="c">Their sweet chorus, rising up faintly as they sang there on the side of the ravines, was a joy,</l>
.<l n="d">As the frogs answered in soft counterpoint from the gullies.</l>
4140</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">In the forest hermitage, love-smitten, they offered their beauty to the seers.*</l>
.<l n="b">Some gathered flowers and bunches of grass which they then arranged, carefully protecting them from their [sharp] nails;</l>
.<l n="c">Others walked carefully, gracefully into the pond to scoop up water,</l>
.<l n="d">And as he watched them closely and they feigned displeasure, they seemed just as sweet as heavenly nymphs.</l>
4145</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">From above, the water [of the pond] lapped at the waters of the sea lying below.</l>
.<l n="b">A fountain spouted up from a fissure, its water thrown up in the centre.</l>
.<l n="c">The misty, glistening spray, lit by the sun’s rays, formed a rainbow,</l>
.<l n="d">With jets of water that looked like a line of slithering snakes flying through the air.</l>
4150</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">The buds of the woodland trees sighed with longing for the fine river mist.</l>
.<l n="b">And seemed to draw near its beauty humbly, to ask that they might be placed in a hair-knot.</l>
.<l n="c">As Dhanañjaya came without warning on the delights of the hermitage,</l>
.<l n="d">The sound of the <foreign>kuwong</foreign> seemed to call them to come forward now that the prince had arrived.</l>
4155</p>
.</div>
.<div type="canto" n="9">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">Completely absorbed, the noble Phalguṇa gazed with delight upon</l>
.<l n="b">The scenic beauty of that mountain hermitage as it rose into view,</l>
4160<l n="c">And because he felt so weary, now that the sun’s heat had utterly sapped his strength,</l>
.<l n="d">In the end he did not hurry past at all, so tired was he.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">At times the path climbed upwards and he could look with delight, as far as the horizon.</l>
.<l n="b">The beauty was enhanced by the lovely birds on their homeward journey.</l>
4165<l n="c">Gracefully flying in formation, they faded from sight,</l>
.<l n="d">While with breathtaking beauty, the hills seemed to flash.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">The delightful path went step-by-step downwards along the side of the deep ravine.</l>
.<l n="b">The undergrowth came right* to the ledge, hidden* beneath the overhanging creepers.</l>
4170<l n="c">By leaning over a long way, he could see the shoots of the <foreign>galing</foreign> creeper* far down in the gully,</l>
.<l n="d">Some were entwined around the betel trees, others stood tall and straight.*</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">The new leaves of the <foreign>walik-aḍĕp</foreign> on the outskirts of the hermitage, flickered.</l>
.<l n="b">Wild banana leaves hung limply as if deprived of strength,</l>
4175<l n="c">Then, as the wind caught them, stood straight out like pennants,*</l>
.<l n="d">Alternating with the fluttering shoots of the <foreign>anḍuru</foreign>* beckoning constantly.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">Just then, the clear cry of the barking deer rang out. How sweet its gaze*</l>
.<l n="b">As it came to rest on the merry monkeys bustling about in the trees.</l>
4180<l n="c">Some were lazily nibbling the many fruits, chattering the while.</l>
.<l n="d">Others, the long-tailed monkeys, rested, just squatting in the branches, oblivious to everything.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">It would take too long to describe* this scene. Soon after, he came to a hermitage.</l>
.<l n="b">The trees all shimmered as if to welcome him.</l>
4185<l n="c">Coquettishly they let their flowers fall to the ground like a rain of jewels,</l>
.<l n="d">Releasing their fragrant perfume without pause as they lay scattered there, enchantingly.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">Time passed and in the quiet of evening the sun took its course.*</l>
.<l n="b">Its rays lost their splendour as dusk fell.</l>
4190<l n="c">As if dyed crimson-red, the heavens shone brightly,</l>
.<l n="d">Wisps of cloud spattered here and there like drops of blood.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">The magnificent design of that sacred hermitage enhanced the beauty even more.</l>
.<l n="b">It was shrouded in webs of cloud that settled over all,</l>
4195<l n="c">And were absorbed* into the smoke of the sacrificial fires of the seers,</l>
.<l n="d">In evidence that impurity and darkness of mind had been destroyed, burnt up in the fire.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">The fragrance of the oblations within wafted out and spread far and wide.</l>
.<l n="b">Their perfumes, mingling together with the scent of aromatic smoke from the lamps, covered everything.</l>
4200<l n="c">Cymbals clashed, bells tinkled together in unison</l>
.<l n="d">With the recitation of prayers - all served to captivate his heart and bring him peace.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">Birds billed and cooed all the while as they roosted in the hermitage,</l>
.<l n="b">In tumultuous discourse, ever discussing and interpreting the sacred syllables,</l>
4205<l n="c">To the delightful accompaniment of the bees whose voices could be heard in the fragrant garlands,*</l>
.<l n="d">As if expert in gracefully leading the gentle, mellifluous singing.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">So many delights did the prince see in the hermitage,</l>
.<l n="b">And so astonished and enraptured was he, that his weariness vanished.</l>
4210<l n="c">Lost in thought, he observed closely, resting on a flat, broad rock</l>
.<l n="d">And determined, instead, to spend the night in the hermitage.</l>
.</p>
.</div>
.<div type="canto" n="10">
4215<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">But let us now turn our attention to the seers who all came quickly to welcome their guest.</l>
.<l n="b">All the anchoresses who dwelt in the hermitage and who had been dressing themselves came forth,</l>
.<l n="c">Rushing out, leaving behind their clothing of bark cloth, unable to wait.</l>
.<l n="d">So full of joy were they to see a man of such beauty that they were quite overwhelmed.</l>
.</p>
4220<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">They ran toward the prince who, as if summoned by the power of their meditation,* sat there</l>
.<l n="b">Charmingly, underneath an <foreign>aśoka</foreign> tree, holding on his lap a garland of flowers.</l>
.<l n="c">The ascetics gazed at him open-mouthed,* for his appearance so far surpassed all others in excellence,</l>
.<l n="d">That they could only think that he was the God of Love Kāma, the sight of him rendering them speechless.</l>
.</p>
4225<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">The nuns too were so dazed that they seemed to have lost their senses,</l>
.<l n="b">Displaying their thoughts and longings as if they were quite incapable of hiding the desire in their eyes.</l>
.<l n="c">The seers greeted him: ‘Fortunate are we who dwell in this hermitage!</l>
.<l n="d">By your arrival, O Prince, we have now reaped the rewards of those* who have achieved indifference to the world.</l>
.</p>
