4230<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">‘What is it you seek in wandering these forested regions, O Prince?</l>
.<l n="b">It is as if you are the origin* of all that is excellent, and will bring to an end the barren state of us who dwell in this forest.</l>
.<l n="c">Through steadfast meditation, the felicity of our ascetic practices has been restored,</l>
.<l n="d">And now, by your kind favour, we will go on to attain our goals.’</l>
.</p>
4235<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">Thus said the great sages and the prince told the holy men,</l>
.<l n="b">Serenely, of the true reason he had come to the holy bathing place,</l>
.<l n="c">Relating also the tale of his deeds in the underworld.</l>
.<l n="d">Happy were the seers to hear [his story] which so heartened them.</l>
.</p>
4240<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">At last, the ascetics escorted the prince into the hermitage.</l>
.<l n="b">On his arrival they treated him with great care and attention,</l>
.<l n="c">Providing him with water for washing his face and feet, as well as roots, fruits and efficacious herbs and potions.</l>
.<l n="d">Dhanañjaya was delighted, his heart captivated by the seers.</l>
.</p>
4245<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">During the time the prince spent in the hermitage,</l>
.<l n="b">Many ascetics came to him,* longing to draw near him.</l>
.<l n="c">He wandered in the hermitage and was welcomed wherever he went by great sages,</l>
.<l n="d">Bringing joy to the holy men of these communities.</l>
.</p>
4250<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">For a long time he sojourned with the seers,</l>
.<l n="b">As if he had no other thought in his mind* but the constant well-being of others.</l>
.<l n="c">At last he begged leave to depart from the holy abbot,</l>
.<l n="d">Who, pleased to consent, embraced the prince:</l>
.</p>
4255<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">‘O Sir, place of refuge of the defenceless, who cares for the welfare of religious communities throughout the kingdom!</l>
.<l n="b">We have been able to share in the joy of one such as you, who is endowed with true excellence, my lord.</l>
.<l n="c">Clearly, you are a great man in choosing to dwell in the mountains.</l>
.<l n="d">May you show compassion and continue to travel the path of virtue* as the support of righteousness!’</l>
.</p>
4260<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">Thus said the priestly sage. The prince then set off,</l>
.<l n="b">Making his way through the groves of the hermitage towards the rolling hills.</l>
.<l n="c">Devoted as he was to spiritual purity, he bathed there in the river and was cleansed of all impurities.</l>
.<l n="d">He then set off for another realm, where too he was received with joy.</l>
.</p>
4265<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">For there was a most excellent king, famed throughout the land for his meritorious deeds and exceptional qualities,</l>
.<l n="b">Who reigned in Mayūra, the marvellous capital of his kingdom.</l>
.<l n="c">The name of Citradahana was truly renowned as world-protector,</l>
.<l n="d">He was ever the benefactor of those without recourse, never seeking victory when he saw others fail.</l>
.</p>
4270</div>
.<div type="canto" n="11">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">King Citradahana had a daughter of such flawless beauty,</l>
.<l n="b">It seemed the Goddess of Beauty had taken residence in her body.</l>
.<l n="c">The very perfume of the flowers seemed diminished as they held their breath in awe of her, </l>
4275<l n="d">And therefore the princess was known as Citragandhā, ‘The Fragrant One.’</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">But it was well-known that the king’s mind was indeed troubled, </l>
.<l n="b">His heart dwelled only on his plight.</l>
.<l n="c">For he knew there was a danger he would have no one to succeed him in the future,</l>
4280<l n="d">And was full of concern for the protection of his realm.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">The king thought constantly of his coming need for a son-in-law,</l>
.<l n="b">And thus he sought a perfect man of good character,</l>
.<l n="c">That he might beget an heir who would succeed to the throne and rule the land,</l>
4285<l n="d">But his heart knew only despair as he reflected on his desire.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">For what worthy man would really allow such a thing,</l>
.<l n="b">And be willing to marry without force or command?*</l>
.<l n="c">‘To act in such a way would certainly be wrong’, he thought, ‘truly base conduct.</l>
4290<l n="d">It is not the proper way of upright men to embark on an evil course.*</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">‘For girls ripe for marriage, it should be like this:</l>
.<l n="b">A flower at the peak of beauty attracts the bee itself </l>
.<l n="c">And so it is fitting that she should be carried off by force to find satisfaction.</l>
4295<l n="d">Such is the analogy for young people who obtain their partners without coercion.’</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">Thus the king grieved, with nothing to solace his heart,</l>
.<l n="b">He forgot everything but his fervent longing, finding it impossible to conquer* his wandering thoughts.</l>
.<l n="c">His advisors too, seemed helpless,</l>
4300<l n="d">‘Such has never happened before’ they thought, every one of them moaning with distress.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">But in the web of existence, two forces ebb and flow -</l>
.<l n="b">Good and evil - both are encountered, both are ever-present,</l>
.<l n="c">In equal measure, always part of the life of every creature.</l>
4305<l n="d">Rich and poor, coarse and fine, there is none who is not held in their thrall.*</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">Those who forget the meaning of religion and neglect the eternal worship of Śiwa,</l>
.<l n="b">Surely will encounter difficulties in their life and will never reach liberation.</l>
.<l n="c">But the King of Mayūra was faithful in his religious observances and always adhered firmly to them.</l>
4310<l n="d">He, who had known joy, now found it was sorrow that drew near and trailed him.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">So he hid in his heart the great burden of his sorrow,</l>
.<l n="b">And always allowed himself to be amused and seemingly untroubled.</l>
.<l n="c">He diverted himself on the shore and in forest hermitages,</l>
4315<l n="d">Again and again, as a means of distracting himself from his misery.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">For a long time, the king had been in torment, filled with longing,</l>
.<l n="b">Guided by the dictates of his heart, thinking only of the resolution of his dilemma,</l>
.<l n="c">And now the intervention of the gods had brought about the arrival of Pārtha,</l>
4320<l n="d">Who would clearly dispel the king’s misery.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">For the beauty of the most excellent princess was so renowned</l>
.<l n="b">That even the loveliness of the mountains trembled, their power to entrance vanquished.</l>
.<l n="c">The charm of poems seemed to peter out, their beauty just floating away,</l>
4325<l n="d">And so, borne along by what he had heard, the prince came there.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="12"><l n="a">It was heard far and wide that Arjuna, the excellent son of Pāṇḍu, was visiting the king.</l>
.<l n="b">How delighted he was to welcome this guest.</l>
.<l n="c">His officials dared to place all their hopes in him,</l>
4330<l n="d">Like flower buds taking sustenance* from the arrival of the gentle rain from the clouds.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="13"><l n="a">All at once the country resembled a mighty ocean.</l>
.<l n="b">It shook with the thundering of the people as they poured forth from the palace.</l>
.<l n="c">The prince was like the full moon shining down upon them</l>
4335<l n="d">And so, beset by love-pangs, they whispered to each other, sighing continually.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="14"><l n="a">They stared and stared at the extraordinary beauty of the prince.</l>
.<l n="b">He encompassed the arrival of the God of Love, the season of flowers and the sweetness of the season of honey at once.</l>
.<l n="c">Moreover he was irresistible, mighty, splendid and virtuous in battle.</l>
4340<l n="d">And thus all they could talk of was this handsome prince.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="15"><l n="a">And so, the king approached the prince,</l>
.<l n="b">His countenance sweet with welcome, his every gesture friendly.</l>
.<l n="c">His kind and warm greeting went straight to the heart of the newly-arrived guest:</l>
4345<l n="d">‘Great is our good fortune that you have come here, my son.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="16"><l n="a">‘We were like withered grass and trees that have given up hope, </l>
.<l n="b">Denied access to rain, terrible indeed was our longing, weary were we with craving,</l>
.<l n="c">Our restlessness plumbing the very depths. But now, suddenly, inexplicably, we have burst into bud.</l>
4350<l n="d">For we think, you have brought the mercy of god Suranatha within our reach.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="17"><l n="a">‘This realm has been so arid and fruitless,</l>
.<l n="b">As if through its own misdeeds it has become barren and lustreless.</l>
.<l n="c">It may now come to know good fortune,</l>
4355<l n="d">For your virtue and excellence will bring it prosperity.’</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="18"><l n="a">These were the king’s happy words. The prince replied:</l>
.<l n="b">‘Indeed no, O King! You go too far in praising me thus.</l>
.<l n="c">Your wisdom is all-surpassing. You are pure, concerned for the good of others, your power is over-reaching.</l>
4360<l n="d">And therefore, Your Majesty, I pay homage to you, you who makes my heart soar.’*</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="19"><l n="a">And he then asked for the hand of the excellent princess.</l>
.<l n="b">The king of Mayūra was willing to grant his request:</l>
.<l n="c">‘My dear boy, take my beloved daughter to serve you as your wife. You may be her husband.</l>
4365<l n="d">May you know joy! But there is a promise I must exact from you.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="20"><l n="a">‘Formerly Mayūra was an excellent realm, as you have no doubt heard.</l>
.<l n="b">Its king, my own forefather, was Prabhākara.</l>
.<l n="c">For a very long time he reigned,* but had no royal heir,</l>
4370<l n="d">And so, desirous of a child, he withdrew to perform austerities.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="21"><l n="a">‘When he saw how steadfast was the king, God Iśwara was merciful, </l>
.<l n="b">And granted to him the boon of a child, </l>
.<l n="c">And one, - and only one, - to each of his descendants too, </l>
4375<l n="d">So that, ever after, his line would reign in this kingdom.</l>
.</p>
.</div>
.<div type="canto" n="12">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">‘The cause of the difficulties we now suffer and which bring us such sorrow,</l>
4380<l n="b">Is that the deeds of his former life have come to nothing and have brought only bewilderment,</l>
.<l n="c">For I am left with a child, a most beautiful daughter,</l>
.<l n="d">Who obviously cannot continue to safeguard the weal of my subjects.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">‘Look kindly on my plea, O Prince. From you I hope for compassion.</l>
4385<l n="b">My request is for a male child,</l>
.<l n="c">A child whose destiny it would be to be my heir,</l>
.<l n="d">And be enthroned in this land. This is the bride-price.’</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">Thus he spoke. The prince, without hesitation,</l>
4390<l n="b">Vowed that any child of the princess, </l>
.<l n="c">Any fine son, would succeed to the throne.</l>
.<l n="d">With this pledge, the agreement they had deliberated was sealed.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">The king then gave directions* to all the palace officials,</l>
4395<l n="b">For the betrothal of the princess to Arjuna.</l>
.<l n="c">The army were delighted to hear of it, giving their full support,</l>
.<l n="d">For it is in the nature of those who serve to be loyal in this way.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">At once, they attended to all that would be required for the celebration of love.</l>
4400<l n="b">Preparing everything, bringing it all to the bed-chamber.</l>
.<l n="c">Laying out for them perfectly, without delay,</l>
.<l n="d">All the ritual requisites, of unequalled splendour, arranged in full measure.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">The ladies of the palace, hearing [the news], took pleasure</l>
4405<l n="b">In preparing and setting out the gifts of homage attractively.</l>
.<l n="c">Others attended to the ornaments but all were equally delighted to welcome their guest,</l>
.<l n="d">Their hearts beating wildly with pleasure* as they pictured him in their minds.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">A beautiful pavilion* had been set ready for his use.</l>
4410<l n="b">It was unequalled in its true magnificence,</l>
.<l n="c">Of unparalleled design, ringed by a moat,</l>
.<l n="d">As splendid as the Hima mountain.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">This was the place they had prepared for Dhanañjaya.</l>
4415<l n="b">Many delicious dishes were to be made and offered to him.</l>
.<l n="c">Ready to meet his every wish, some led the singing,</l>
.<l n="d">Accompanying their melody with drums and the sweet music of the <foreign>kĕtur</foreign>.*</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">As the sun set, the king withdrew,</l>
4420<l n="b">His heart no longer beset by constant worry.</l>
.<l n="c">Because of the strength of his feelings towards Dhanañjaya,</l>
.<l n="d">His joy was reflected in his radiant countenance.</l>
.</p>
.</div>
4425<div type="canto" n="13">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">The king went to his quarters and made for the queen’s apartment within,</l>
.<l n="b">Where his arrival was welcomed with smiles and he was ushered in with sweet glances.</l>
.<l n="c">He informed the queen of what he had done </l>
.<l n="d">And the reason for his plan to marry off their daughter.</l>
4430</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">The queen made no objection to the marriage of the princess.</l>
.<l n="b">The palace ladies were also all highly delighted, some even felt burgeoning desire,</l>
.<l n="c">Thinking: ‘Indeed the prince is fitting to hold power over our princess.’</l>
.<l n="d">But let us not describe that. The king then went to the princess.*</l>
4435</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">As soon as she knew of the king’s visit, the princess</l>
.<l n="b">Became very agitated, anxious to hear what he had in mind.</l>
.<l n="c">The king’s approach filled her with an anxiety that she tried to restrain,</l>
.<l n="d">Fighting back her tears, even as she came forward to greet him as he entered.</l>
4440</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">Her sorrow, so obviously hidden, filled the hearts of the palace women with pity.</l>
.<l n="b">Many of her young attendants were skilful at interpreting the outward signs of her inner feelings</l>
.<l n="c">And so they drew near to sit beside her, like a profusion of jasmine flowers to behold,</l>
.<l n="d">But the princess so outstripped their charms, that even at first sight* she seemed like the moon.</l>
4445</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">As she made her obeisance, her slender arms were like bending boughs.</l>
.<l n="b">Her waist and limbs were so supple that they seemed a collection of unsharpened <foreign>kris.</foreign>*</l>
.<l n="c">Even more beautiful was the sight of her body, aglow* in the light of the lamps.</l>
.<l n="d">Her face grew pale like the waning moon, as she was suddenly overcome with fear.</l>
4450</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">Then the king, his queen beside him,* addressed the princess:</l>
.<l n="b">‘O my child, there is none but you to whom we can turn to perform this favour for us.</l>
.<l n="c">You alone can fulfil it and ensure our well-being, O princess,</l>
.<l n="d">If only you will show compassion and be the instrument through which we may reach heaven.</l>
4455</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">‘O my darling jewel, truly* we ask much of you.</l>
.<l n="b">Please accept the inevitability of our words. How could we possibly deny* the love we have for you, my daughter?</l>
.<l n="c">But now your body is ripe, the proper place to bring* a husband without delay,</l>
.<l n="d">And so Dhanañjaya is to be your husband, for he is a fitting match for you’.</l>
4460</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">Thus said the king. As for the princess, she made no reply.</l>
.<l n="b">Despairingly she held back her tears, her heart crushed, not knowing what to do.</l>
.<l n="c">She feared to disappoint the king by disobeying his command,</l>
.<l n="d">So she merely sighed endlessly as she listened to her father and mother.</l>
4465</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">The queen spoke next: ‘My child you must heed the king,</l>
.<l n="b">As you know we have only you, my dear, to uphold our honour.</l>
.<l n="c">You will perform a great service for our lineage, if you but give life to a male grandchild,* </l>
.<l n="d">Who will reign here in Mayūra, and thus your marriage settlement* will become the source of our kingdom’s strength.</l>
4470</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">‘Come! Accept this! Do not suppose that the king would neglect his duty as ruler.</l>
.<l n="b">He who has a child or wife wishes only to dispel their troubles.</l>
.<l n="c">Unwise is he who is bound by the love of a child, for it will lead him to shame.</l>
.<l n="d">His concern is that they are not held subject* by the fortunes and misfortunes that are encountered in this world.’</l>
4475</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">Having spoken thus the king [and queen] retired and the princess was left alone.</l>
.<l n="b">So distraught was she as her maids led her away, that she felt suddenly faint, and swayed, burdened by sorrow.</l>
.<l n="c">She reached the sanctuary of the bower of creepers, bewailing the fate of maidens* who are to wed.</l>
.<l n="d">Her tears flowed unabated, as her maids tried to soothe her with words of comfort.</l>
4480</p>
.</div>
.<div type="canto" n="14">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">All the ladies of the court were dazed and wandered restlessly about, lost in dreams, becoming weak with longing,</l>
.<l n="b">Carried away by desire, overwhelmed with rapture, rendered powerless by the prince’s sweet charms that so wounded them.</l>
4485<l n="c">Feverish, burning with secret desires, overcome with the confusion of unfulfilled love, there in the moonlight that streamed in,</l>
.<l n="d">Falling silent now he, who was the very embodiment of love, had come there riding upon the moon.*</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">One girl, sitting there forlornly on the floor with her hair unbound, swooning, was pitiful in her dejection,</l>
.<l n="b">Writing of her desire on a lovely <foreign>sumanasa</foreign> flower, turning her longing to letters,</l>
4490<l n="c">As she whispered to her serving girl, telling of the pain of her love-sickness,</l>
.<l n="d">Heart-brokenly giving voice to her sorrow in a charming lament.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">Another, her <foreign>kain</foreign> in disarray,* lay on the lap of her attendant, her great ardour unabated,</l>
.<l n="b">Confused, mad with longing for a response to the rapturous delight of blissful lovers,</l>
4495<l n="c">Who are happy just to wander along the sea-shore, lost in the composition of love-poems,</l>
.<l n="d">Undaunted even when brought to a stop by the rising tide, content, though there is no shelter for the night.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">Yet another jewel among women, her charms at their peak like a flower in bud,</l>
.<l n="b">Mournfully lost in reverie, weighed down by her feelings of longing and sadness, was being gently massaged, underneath an <foreign>aśoka</foreign> tree.</l>
4500<l n="c">Her maid, assiduously devoted to her every need, attended her with words of comfort,</l>
.<l n="d">But knew full well that only in union with the prince could she find comfort for her sorrow:</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">‘How can a profusion of flower-buds* burst open, if they must risk spoiling their beauty?</l>
.<l n="b">They will wither completely if the fourth month does not come to bring its gentle rain, so that they might unfold.</l>
4505<l n="c">Their new leaves are to no avail, the spiteful wind seems only to tease them mercilessly, tossing them to and fro,</l>
.<l n="d">So that they want only to dive into those cruel clouds so long awaited, bowed down with longing.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">‘Oh what other outcome could there be but that their beautiful petals*would die?</l>
.<l n="b">The fragrance of the <foreign>asana</foreign>, the jasmine, the <foreign>suraga</foreign>, even the luxuriant* <foreign>nagapuṣpa,</foreign> would be pointless</l>
4510<l n="c">If the bees shunned them and no longer desired to caress them,</l>
.<l n="d">Just as the splendour of the moon would cease if the love-sick <foreign>cucur</foreign> bird abandoned it.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">‘My dearest mistress, you who are sister to the beauty of the fourth month,</l>
.<l n="b">I know the meaning of your words, you are the pale* <foreign>aśoka</foreign> in bud.</l>
4515<l n="c">Oh alas! How it awakens my pity, dear one, to see your sweet charms so enfeebled.</l>
.<l n="d">Indeed yours is the sad plight of a flower that withers the moment it is taken from a fragrant hair-knot.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">‘O maiden, look here, I, your servant, my jewel, will go to the prince.</l>
.<l n="b">I will take this lovely petal as a token of your homage to him, the god of the love-sick.</l>
4520<l n="c">When he beholds your sweetness, how could he not be won over and long fervently for the ocean of honey,</l>
.<l n="d">So that only in being engulfed in its centre, would he find respite for his passionate longing.’</l>
.</p>
.</div>
.<div type="canto" n="15">
4525<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">It would take too long to tell of the thoughts of these women, whose hearts ached</l>
.<l n="b">With the passion and bewilderment that engulfed them.</l>
.<l n="c">They tossed restlessly, greatly distressed,</l>
.<l n="d">Confused, carried away by desires that, though they tried to ward them off, overwhelmed them so.</l>
.</p>
4530<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">But the princess was not thus affected.</l>
.<l n="b">She was listless and dispirited, and paid no heed to her surroundings.</l>
.<l n="c">Her attendants and maids untiringly caressed her,</l>
.<l n="d">Seeking words to bring her comfort.</l>
.</p>
4535<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">Her pitiful moans became more acute,</l>
.<l n="b">For her mind was in turmoil, preoccupied.</l>
.<l n="c">Tormented and brooding, she was unable to sleep, </l>
.<l n="d">As is the way of young girls.</l>
.</p>
4540<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">The king’s decision, commanding her</l>
.<l n="b">To be married now without delay,</l>
.<l n="c">Was both the cause of her suffering</l>
.<l n="d">And the reason for her deep bewilderment.</l>
.</p>
4545<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">She could hear the music of <foreign>geṇḍing</foreign> and drums outside,</l>
.<l n="b">In merry, sweet accompaniment to the singing.</l>
.<l n="c">The lovely strains of the <foreign>curing</foreign> cymbals of the <foreign>piḍuḍukan</foreign> ceremony,*</l>
.<l n="d">Rang out the whole night long to torment her.</l>
.</p>
4550<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">But enough of that. Night soon passed,</l>
.<l n="b">And the waning moon went off to hide away.</l>
.<l n="c">The seventh hour* rang out, </l>
.<l n="d">As if inviting daylight to hasten there.</l>
.</p>
4555</div>
.<div type="canto" n="16">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">When every kind of ceremonial requisite had been prepared and laid ready,</l>
.<l n="b">The populace entered and assembled in the outer courtyard.</l>
.<l n="c">At daybreak, the sun shone bright and clear, radiating its brilliance everywhere.</l>
4560<l n="d">The city gleamed brightly, crimson-red, and the <foreign>gĕṇḍing</foreign> resounded merrily.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">There in the outer hall, the king received homage,</l>
.<l n="b">The exuberance of the court ever-increasing, like the rising ocean.</l>
.<l n="c">Great throngs of people spread everywhere, scurrying busily about, </l>
4565<l n="d">The <foreign>saragi</foreign> gongs* crashing in joyful competition, like waves breaking.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">Some people were merrily eating and drinking together, in full measure,</l>
.<l n="b">The whole day spent happily in each other’s company, completely unrestrained, everything without fault.</l>
.<l n="c">But let us tell now of the princess, in the pavilion, undergoing the <foreign>piḍuḍukan</foreign> ceremony.</l>
4570<l n="d">Her sweet charms rivalled those of Ratih, Goddess of Love, as she was adorned.*</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">As she was assiduously attended by those officiating* in the inner chamber</l>
.<l n="b">And by those who adorned her in splendour, the maiden became more and more dejected,</l>
.<l n="c">So upset at the king’s apparent disregard of her,</l>
4575<l n="d">That she could take no pleasure in the beauty of the decorations with which they adorned her.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">Although she was truly worthy to vanquish the beauty of the wondrous fourth month,</l>
.<l n="b">Her sorrow made her as lifeless as a withered flower.</l>
.<l n="c">The sun began to go down as if to hasten the wedding-night,</l>
4580<l n="d">While the awesome rumble of the thunder, with its soft and quavering sound, seemed a prelude to love-making.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">Inside that beautiful pavilion the noble princess was attended.</l>
.<l n="b">Moreover, because all the most beautiful adornments had been reserved for it,</l>
.<l n="c">The <foreign>pamiḍuḍukan</foreign> pavilion was breath-takingingly lovely, quite enchanting.*</l>
4585<l n="d">While her maid servants, all thoroughly accomplished in the arts of beauty, were like heavenly nymphs.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">So great were her charms that she was like an ornamented painting of a goddess,</l>
.<l n="b">Such an incomparable and excellent girl was she, the supreme jewel of the palace.</l>
.<l n="c">The unending molten stream of the goddess of nectar would yield before her, infatuated,</l>
4590<l n="d">By her sweetness and would be reduced to confusion to see her own beauty take on visible form.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">The setting sun had sent its rays to keep watch over her painted lips.</l>
.<l n="b">Clearly, rain-filled* clouds were in her hair-knot.</l>
.<l n="c">Darting swallows flying about seemed to have become one with her frowning brows,</l>
4595<l n="d">And the flickering lightning had lost its brightness, in service to her feet.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">Then the melodic sound of the prayers and rituals became louder,</l>
.<l n="b">Its charm enhanced by the soft murmuring of those gathered in the outer court.</l>
.<l n="c">The accompaniment of the lovely <foreign>gĕṇḍing</foreign> and <foreign>curing</foreign>* aroused feelings of longing,</l>
4600<l n="d">Their musical offering bringing to mind the tossing of the beautiful ocean.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">At sunset, the clouds shone like red silk.</l>
.<l n="b">At the fifth hour the enchanting moon goddess rose and shone brightly.</l>
.<l n="c">But, disheartened that this true incarnation of beauty mocked her </l>
4605<l n="d">And worsted her, she became pale and waited there, hidden behind the dark clouds that cast shadows across her [face].</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">The princess’s ornaments were so decoratively arranged by those waiting upon her</l>
.<l n="b">That it seemed as if the beauty of the dawn was shamed and took leave of her charms.</l>
.<l n="c">Indeed, all the sentiments of delight in a love-poem or the subtle allusions in an allegory*</l>
4610<l n="d">Were to be found in her sweetness and, if but whispered, would invoke feelings of love.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="12"><l n="a">We will say no more of the princess but tell instead of the prince.*</l>
.<l n="b">He was showered with all requisites and due ceremonies </l>
.<l n="c">By the king,* who now arranged the wedding.</l>
4615<l n="d">In due time, the bridal couple withdrew. We will now tell of them.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="13"><l n="a">They went up together into the beautiful bed-chamber.</l>
.<l n="b">That the rites of marriage* would be delightful, was plain for all to see in [the prince’s] desire.</l>
.<l n="c">It was as if he had been overwhelmed with the unconstrained delight that is treasured on a delicately-made writing board</l>
4620<l n="d">And the beautiful princess was clearly the wondrousness of gentle rain.*</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="14"><l n="a">As the princess mounted the bedstead,</l>
.<l n="b">Her heart was filled with dread and disquiet. Despondently she was led in.</l>
.<l n="c">She was truly afraid because of the sorrow that now visited her,</l>
4625<l n="d">And she could find no solace, as she felt an unremitting sadness sweep over her.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="15"><l n="a">As they sat there together, all who saw them thought them delightful:</l>
.<l n="b">‘Our princess is the image of a young banana leaf newly unfolding.</l>
.<l n="c">The prince is like a profusion of <foreign>jangga</foreign> vine, unrestrainedly caressing her.’</l>
4630<l n="d">Thus they thought, full of longing, their wounded hearts captivated.</l>
.</p>
.</div>
.<div type="canto" n="17">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">So alluring and beautiful was the scene, with moonlight enhancing the beauty</l>
4635<l n="b">Of the bright, glowing pavilion, it was truly without equal.</l>
.<l n="c">The lustrous radiance of the gold ridge-pole was augmented by jewels,</l>
.<l n="d">And the light of the moon grew pale when irradiated by their gleam, sparkling in all directions.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">The splendid draperies were like those used to curtain a grotto of love.</l>
4640<l n="b">The sun-red glowing horizon seemed to have moved there.</l>
.<l n="c">Moreover the couch within the house of creepers was spread with softest silks.*</l>
.<l n="d">Camphor and unguent gave forth their fragrance, diffusing their scent and perfumes overall.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">The prince had already been enthroned* on the couch,</l>
4645<l n="b">And had taken the girl on his lap, where she lay deprived of strength, all atremble.</l>
.<l n="c">When they were left alone there, he was just like a bee caressing a budding flower.</l>
.<l n="d">He became more and more like an intoxicated <foreign>taḍaharṣa</foreign> bird paying homage to the moon, overwhelmed by longing.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">Bewildered and wan, the beautiful girl grew ever more afraid, and sighed,</l>
4650<l n="b">Bending gracefully aside when he tried to seize her waist, moving away, warding him off.</l>
.<l n="c">Overwhelming sadness totally crushed her heart into little pieces,</l>
.<l n="d">And tears of honey suddenly welled up in her eyes, as she arched her brows threateningly.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">His heart beating wildly, the prince became more and more passionate.</l>
4655<l n="b">Clearly he was the embodiment of honey, blended with sweetest syrup,</l>
.<l n="c">Akin to the thunder of the fourth month, that lightens the suffering of those overcome by the pains of love.</l>
.<l n="d">And his words, droplets of sweet delight, were the essence of love:</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">‘O maiden! Queen of the beauty of <foreign>asanas</foreign>! Flower of the whole kingdom!</l>
4660<l n="b">You are my final destination, the very cause of my love-sick passions.</l>
.<l n="c">All joy and desire embodied in an incomparably wrought jewel are you,</l>
.<l n="d">The fulfilment of a dream, [a gift] from the God of Love, magically appearing.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">‘Therefore you have been accorded first place* by all beautiful women.</l>
4665<l n="b">Have pity on me, the one whose heart has striven to resist the dictates of the God of Love.</l>
.<l n="c">Clearly it is because of my love-sick heart that I reach for you, seeking you out.</l>
.<l n="d">And so I have come humbly to seek refuge with you, here in the bed-chamber.’</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">Thus he spoke. But the maiden he sought to woo averted her face, weeping.</l>
4670<l n="b">Her body, lithe as a tendril, seemed to wilt, as she sighed plaintively.</l>
.<l n="c">The prince’s passion was so intense,* so uncontrolled, that she grew very apprehensive</l>
.<l n="d">As his intent gaze sought to reveal her secret places.*</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">‘O my darling, why do you treat my troubles so lightly as I seek your favour?</l>
4675<l n="b">Even though you stab me with your eyebrows, how could that be reason enough for me to go away and abandon myself to longing?</l>
.<l n="c">I would think myself fortunate if I could but be pierced by your beautiful glances. What would I care if I were cut to pieces?</l>
.<l n="d">My darling, my only hope is that I, who so desire you, might now receive the gift of your love.’</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">The object of his love-struck worship, weary of resisting, sank down, weeping,</l>
4680<l n="b">Helplessly striking at him with her hands as if she would blunt her nails.</l>
.<l n="c">As he seized her waist-band, it suddenly came loose from her fragrant, slender waist.</l>
.<l n="d">And though it seemed she would die as he threatened her thus, he ignored her fear and took possession of her.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">Intent on his purpose, unable to restrain his mounting excitement, </l>
4685<l n="b">The prince abandoned himself to the overwhelming force of his boundless desire, quite without mercy.</l>
.<l n="c">For it so assailed him that, in the end, he ravished* the beautiful princess,</l>
.<l n="d">Pressing down* upon her trembling breasts, now laid bare, filling her with fear and aversion.</l>
.</p>
.</div>
4690<div type="canto" n="18">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">After being thus deflowered, the weary maiden was completely devastated,</l>
.<l n="b">Like a pale leaf that has just withered away.</l>
.<l n="c">Gasping for breath, deprived of all strength, she rose and stumbling to the foot of the couch, sank down there,</l>
.<l n="d">Her embroidered, fragrant robe stained with blood, glistening wet.</l>
4695</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">Aghast, she readjusted her clothing</l>
.<l n="b">For fear of again being forced to make love.</l>
.<l n="c">She went dejectedly from the fragrant boudoir,</l>
.<l n="d">A sudden frown on her face at seeing the blood trickling to her feet.</l>
4700</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">Her maids, taken by surprise as she came out, greeted her:</l>
.<l n="b">‘Dear mistress, pay no attention to your pain, my dear.</l>
.<l n="c">Why it is just like taking betel – the first time, it is hot to the lips,</l>
.<l n="d">But there is no doubt that the next time it, instead, becomes* delightful’.</l>
4705</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">And so the princess was urged to return at once,</l>
.<l n="b">With coaxing words as they bathed her face.</l>
.<l n="c">The fear that filled her at their insistence, was plain to see</l>
.<l n="d">As they escorted her back in soon after.</l>
4710</p>
.</div>
.<div type="canto" n="19">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">Thereupon, the heart of the lover she had abandoned in the beauty of that lovely bed-chamber became ever more inflamed.</l>
.<l n="b">His tender gaze was heart-stopping and as sweet as a beautiful lotus.</l>
4715<l n="c">As rain in the fourth month, his words set her heart aquiver.</l>
.<l n="d">He was like a yearning bee in the fragrant <foreign>asana,</foreign> intoxicated with beauty:</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">‘O maiden, jewel of all who love, enthroned in the innermost depths of my yearning heart, you hold me spell-bound with passion,</l>
.<l n="b">Bringing to me the sharpest love-pangs, your arching brows wound my shattered heart.</l>
4720<l n="c">How can I not die when your eyes shine upon me, filling me with feelings of longing?</l>
.<l n="d">And in captivating me with desire, you become the essence that forever fills my heart.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">‘But even if I, your brother, were to die, I could become your eye-black, your ear-ornaments, your breast-band, your robe.</l>
.<l n="b">What pleasure I would know in heightening the beauty of your heart-melting glance, or drawing near in homage to your fragrant ear.</l>
4725<l n="c">On the couch I could caress your breasts, marked with the scratches [of love-making] and enclose your beautiful, lustrous waist.</l>
.<l n="d">My darling, what joy would be mine if I were thus allowed to inhale the scent of your beauty.’</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">These were the prince’s loving words, telling her of the depth of his feelings, enchanting her.</l>
.<l n="b">His words of love were fit to dispel the apprehension of any* love-lorn bride and put her fear to rest.</l>
4730<l n="c">But just as the sun grows cool at twilight, the princess was sad at heart and upset,</l>
.<l n="d">And would not look at her lover’s delightful glances though, like syrup, they were sweet enough to carry her pain away.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">He found many sweet ways to alleviate the princess’s heartache.</l>
.<l n="b">In joyful ecstasy, he kissed her as she lay with her head in his lap, stroking her breasts,</l>
4735<l n="c">Striving only for harmony in their love-making, steadfastly practising the meditation of the doctrines [of love],</l>
.<l n="d">They seemed to drown in a sea of honey, caressed by the clouds of passion.</l>
.</p>
.</div>
.<div type="canto" n="20">
4740<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">After making love a second time, the princess was exhausted and deathly pale.</l>
.<l n="b">Like the moon growing dim, the sweetness of her wan face had lost its lustre.</l>
.<l n="c">Moreover the lamps shining upon her enhanced her charm, captivating</l>
.<l n="d">The prince, who because of his boundless love, became even more ardent.</l>
.</p>
4745<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">The onlookers, hiding behind the partitions there, were overcome by feelings of longing, tinged with desire,</l>
.<l n="b">On hearing the soft rustlings and whispered endearments which seemed only to enhance their love-making.</l>
.<l n="c">In time, weary of joining in love, they fell silent and slept, </l>
.<l n="d">Without a thought for the clothes and wraps that they had left abandoned there, kicked aside.</l>
.</p>
4750<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">We will not tell of them as, replete with love-making, they slept* there on the couch.</l>
.<l n="b">When day began to break, a fragrant breeze came wafting,</l>
.<l n="c">Carrying with it the perfume of the <foreign>srī gaḍing</foreign>, <foreign>asana </foreign>and <foreign>kamuning</foreign> flowers</l>
.<l n="d">And the enchantment of secret places that, like a bed chamber, conjure up visions of love.</l>
.</p>
4755<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">Delightfully, the distant call of the <foreign>kokila</foreign> could be faintly heard.</l>
.<l n="b">The peacocks, carolling joyfully on the gate-posts, were enchanting.</l>
.<l n="c">The bees, buzzing in their hives, sounded like ardent husbands* kissing each of their wives</l>
.<l n="d">In a frenzy of delight, aroused by the <foreign>asanas</foreign> and the fragrant, beautiful pandanus flowers.</l>
.</p>
4760</div>
.<div type="canto" n="21">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">The bright Lord of the Sun was just beginning to shine</l>
.<l n="b">As radiantly as a half smile that hints at passion.</l>
.<l n="c">Glowing rays of light spread sparkling on all sides,</l>
4765<l n="d">And burnished* clouds shone with brilliant streaks.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">The hand-maidens had completed their preparations,</l>
.<l n="b">And stood in readiness on the outer verandah.</l>
.<l n="c">They brought there all that they needed for bathing,</l>
4770<l n="d">With graceful* movements, full of happiness.</l>
.</p>
.</div>
.<div type="canto" n="22">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">But the loving couple, enveloped in weariness from love-making, did not know that day had come.</l>
4775<l n="b">They were surprised when they awoke to find their clothes in disarray and rearranged them.</l>
.<l n="c">They emerged, eyes blinking, from the bridal chamber,</l>
.<l n="d">And were then bathed together by their attentive maids.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">Emerging from the water,* they sat there together on the verandah outside the pavilion,</l>
4780<l n="b">Joyfully sitting so closely layered together,* with the princess on his lap,</l>
.<l n="c">They looked as beautiful as a god and goddess descending from the heavens,</l>
.<l n="d">With the serving-girls waiting upon them, each appropriately adorned,* seated below them according to rank.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">They were ill-at-ease, lingering there on the verandah,</l>
4785<l n="b">Thrown into confusion by sudden thoughts of the sweetness of the partner who had brought them such bliss.</l>
.<l n="c">The gleam in their love-filled eyes seemed to compel them to return,</l>
.<l n="d">And again they climbed up to the couch, there to discover the joy of their nakedness.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">Truly splendid was all that was used to regale them during the marriage ceremonies.*</l>
4790<l n="b">Softly, as if to soothe them, the sweet strains of the <foreign>gĕṇḍing</foreign> sang out their praises,</l>
.<l n="c">And the fragrance of the perfumes, boreh and bdellium wafted there,</l>
.<l n="d">Thus arousing their passion and making them eager for love.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">The fourth hour sounded out, a signal for them to come out of the pavilion together.</l>
4795<l n="b">Then delicious foods prepared in full measure were placed before them,</l>
.<l n="c">The elderly women keeping close watch over every detail of the offerings,</l>
.<l n="d">As lute players and graceful dancers fulfilled their every request and desire.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">They became Kāma and Ratih as they sought union in the bed-chamber.</l>
4800<l n="b">Because of their boundless mutual passion they found harmony, burgeoning together in the raptures of love.</l>
.<l n="c">Their enjoyment was that of the delighted meeting of the sap of the fruit of the betel and sharp tooth.</l>
.<l n="d">The consummation of their union awakening joy in the faces of her mother and father.</l>
.</p>
.</div>
4805<div type="canto" n="23">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">With that, the king’s mind indeed became tranquil.</l>
.<l n="b">The joy of the people throughout the kingdom returned in equal measure.*</l>
.<l n="c">Prosperity immediately brought back the might of heroes throughout the land,</l>
.<l n="d">For there was nothing to trouble their hearts, all were equally untroubled.</l>
4810</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">We will not tell of the many months that the two lovers lived in mutual delight,</l>
.<l n="b">Happy to be as one together, there in the palace.</l>
.<l n="c">Their every action touched their hearts to the core,*</l>
.<l n="d">Their love for each other like that of the <foreign>mangunĕng</foreign> flower, closely entwined with the <foreign>jangga</foreign> vine.</l>
4815</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">And so the king knew unbounded love in great measure, </l>
.<l n="b">Because the prince had caused his heart to be free of care,</l>
.<l n="c">And so he formed a deep and lasting affection for Pārtha,</l>
.<l n="d">While love for him blossomed in the hearts of his people and army.</l>
4820</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">The rumbling thunder [of the fourth month], that season that summons wanderers to surrender themselves to the pursuit of beauty, arrived.</l>
.<l n="b">The prince’s heart swelled to hear it</l>
.<l n="c">And so he made preparations to go in search of the beauty of nature, </l>
.<l n="d">His mind dwelling constantly on thoughts of bathing places, oft frequented.</l>
4825</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">Having received the consent of his beloved, he took leave</l>
.<l n="b">First, of the king and queen</l>
.<l n="c">But we will pass over that. The next day, the prince set off, </l>
.<l n="d">Accompanied by a royal escort, fully equipped, lined up in formation.</l>
4830</p>
.</div>
.<div type="canto" n="24">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">Delightful were the lovely fragrances from the flower gardens as the breeze caught them. The cry of the peacock was enchanting,</l>
.<l n="b">As the prince made his preparations to set off without delay from the royal palace and went on his way.</l>
4835<l n="c">Night had passed and the landscape came into view through a curtain of falling rain.</l>
.<l n="d">For all the world like jewels scattered everywhere, rain drops filled the fields.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">The newly-risen sun shone in the east, a shower of sparkling rays radiating down into the mountain gullies.</l>
.<l n="b">The glittering forest trees were at their best, their shimmering branches vibrant.</l>
4840<l n="c">The joyful sound of the wood-fowl* in the gorges rang out,* as male and female, in repose, called back and forth* to each other.</l>
.<l n="d">And the cuckoo’s cry sounded loudly* as if inspired by the mountain view.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">Trees that had abandoned hope and shrivelled, now bathed with dew,* put forth new leaves.</l>
.<l n="b">Delightedly, young bael creepers* opened, thrusting their tendrils out sideways.</l>
4845<l n="c">Curling fronds of <foreign>katirah</foreign> spiralled down and blended into the gold* trees,</l>
.<l n="d">Encircling the overhanging <foreign>wanañjari</foreign>* in its embrace, as if longing to form a bower* for lovers.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">Along the sides of the mountain ridges, the cultivated fields, lit by the sun’s rays, gleamed.</l>
.<l n="b">Ivory betel-nut palms, heavily laden with coconuts, their fruit ripe for picking, stood in delightful rows.</l>
4850<l n="c">On the slopes were verdant rice-fields, bananas grew abundantly in the ravines,</l>
.<l n="d">Their leaves, lying on the ground where they had fallen, like blunted styluses.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">The crops were green and lovely, freshly shining, wet with dew.</l>
.<l n="b">Millet and rattan, tuberous roots and <foreign>payanggu</foreign> were in full bloom, there were aubergines neatly planted along the small dykes.*</l>
4855<l n="c">Garden plots had been established in the near-by valleys, the glistening soil newly tilled.</l>
.<l n="d">Unfolding taro, just beginning to show its flowers,* looked like rolled-leaf ear ornaments of ivory.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">The graceful young leaves of the <foreign>lirang</foreign> looked for all the world like the naked waists of maidens.</l>
.<l n="b">As if throwing themselves down on the ground in dejection, prey to feelings of longing and sadness, the withering <foreign>jangga</foreign> vines were mad with desire.</l>
4860<l n="c">The ivory coconuts were like uncovered breasts in the fullness of their beauty,</l>
.<l n="d">Indeed, they seemed to have stolen the loveliness of a yearning maiden, secretly seeking the raptures of love.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a"><foreign>Cangkilung</foreign> birds sang sweetly in the ravines, accompanied by the answering calls of <foreign>pings</foreign>.*</l>
.<l n="b">Shyly they called out,* sobbing and yearning as they waited in the <foreign>rangin</foreign> trees.</l>
4865<l n="c">‘Ooooo’, came the soughing of the rustling wind, whistling through* the <foreign>wungwang</foreign> bamboo,* bringing delight,</l>
.<l n="d">And just to hear the heart-stopping cry of the <foreign>pakṣi kĕtur</foreign> birds seemed* to awaken emotions of love.</l>
.</p>
.</div>
.<div type="canto" n="25">
4870<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">As the prince proceeded on his journey, one splendid vista after another unfolded before his eyes.</l>
.<l n="b">Emerging from a leafy wood, he entered a peaceful valley.</l>
.<l n="c">The dry rice-fields were beautiful, their plants a balm to the eyes.*</l>
.<l n="d">What a pity they had been so neglected! Perhaps hermits who had once sought solitude* there had been rendered powerless by magical forces and worsted.*</l>
.</p>
4875<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">Along the sides of the path, well-kept fields rising up in terraces </l>
.<l n="b">Towered above the settlements located at the foot of the mountain.</l>
.<l n="c">In the bright sunlight, he could see them all clearly as he looked down,</l>
.<l n="d">But they disappeared from view as they zigzagged* in and out of the distant hollows.</l>
.</p>
4880<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">The gardens came right up to the undergrowth* which seemed intent on invading the hermitage,</l>
.<l n="b">But it seemed to hesitate uncertainly, lest in the heat of the sun, the valley road would be as [hot as] a cauldron,*</l>
.<l n="c">It kept constant guard against the wickedness* of the naughty monkeys, seeking to steal the plants and crops,</l>
.<l n="d">As well as the terrible forest boars that were treacherously determined to destroy everything,* so fierce were they.</l>
.</p>
4885<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">Stands of bending ivory coconut palms charmingly waiting there on the hill, beckoned.*</l>
.<l n="b">Delightful in their exuberance,* they lent enchantment to the haunts of poets composing verse,</l>
.<l n="c">But their invitation to the chattering lemurs, half-hidden there, seemed to no avail*</l>
.<l n="d">In the face of the incessant loud clattering of the alarms* that frightened them all away unharmed.</l>
.</p>
4890<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">Determined to convey the message of beauty, <foreign>gagarangan</foreign> trees* bedecked themselves with garlands of flower, </l>
.<l n="b">But they had forgotten their true nature - that they had no fragrance at all - and stood tall and lofty.*</l>
.<l n="c">In boldly challenging the beauty of <foreign>asanas</foreign> in the fourth month like this and trying to replace it,</l>
.<l n="d">They were quite in error, for it was quite impossible they could ever cause desire.</l>
.</p>
4895<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">The <foreign>kamwagan</foreign> diffused its fragrance to envelop the artful <foreign>pupulutan</foreign>*flowers.</l>
.<l n="b">Wanting to mingle together with them and give prominence to its own perfume,* it seemed to take delight* in such fraudulent and impudent behaviour.</l>
.<l n="c">Enhancing its beauty with red <foreign>pilapilu,</foreign>* gleefully planning to lie in wait in the gullies,</l>
.<l n="d">The <foreign>singgugu</foreign> shrub lay ready, its flowers languidly scattered and strewn about to form a mat.</l>
.</p>
4900<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">In full blossom, the <foreign>wunga tali</foreign> seemed to tremble, giving itself airs, though it seemed absurd that it could ever wound a heart.</l>
.<l n="b">Far from hiding itself away, it acted quite wrongly, showing too little self control.</l>
.<l n="c">As if maddened, it tried to discover the secrets of the <foreign>mandalīka</foreign> calling to it, though it sullenly shook its head,</l>
.<l n="d">Drawing itself up to its full height, ignoring the passion that filled it, reached outwards, and was trapped.*</l>
.</p>
4905<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">In this way, the beauties of the countryside were set before the prince on his journey.</l>
.<l n="b">The ascetics all came out according to rank to meet him as he travelled on his way,</l>
.<l n="c">Bidding him welcome, warmly offering him every efficacious herb and medicine as well as delicious fruits.</l>
.<l n="d">Joyfully, and attentive to every detail, he [in turn] presented them with the gifts due from a prince.*</l>
.</p>
4910<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">Many country people, not to mention a great number of their leaders, attended him.</l>
.<l n="b">Abundant were their gifts of delicacies: there were fruits and roots and sweet, young coconuts,</l>
.<l n="c">Palm wine and <foreign>kilang.</foreign>* All that they had in their stores, they offered humbly,</l>
.<l n="d">Pleasing the prince so much that he wished to linger there.</l>
.</p>
4915<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">By the time he was ready to set off again to visit the many beauty spots in the forest, </l>
.<l n="b">The sun had set, and so he made ready to spend the night,</l>
.<l n="c">There, in the hermitage, with his entire escort* carefully keeping watch,</l>
.<l n="d">While all the <foreign>duwan</foreign>* came forward in rank to attend to his every need.</l>
.</p>
4920</div>
.<div type="canto" n="26">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">When night had passed, the prince again went on his way in search of beauty,</l>
.<l n="b">Making his way along the edges of the ravines, along the dips and bends of the magnificent mountain.</l>
.<l n="c">He was charmed by the sound of the musical watermills, faintly audible in the distance, tinkling sweetly one after the other in the gullies.</l>
4925<l n="d">The muted roar of a waterfall, that could be heard now and then, entranced him.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">Valleys lay open to view in the curves of the hills, the forests along their slopes</l>
.<l n="b">So charmingly spread out below, but covered now with white clouds, were scarcely visible.</l>
.<l n="c">Low clouds came down, blanketing them, then dispersing again like the remnants of night,</l>
4930<l n="d">So that for a moment the <foreign>walik-aḍĕp</foreign> trees* flickered, then, as if suddenly called away, unable to wait, vanished.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">The sun now shone as radiantly as the face of a beloved in the bed-chamber.</l>
.<l n="b">Taking flight, the dew formed stripes on the grass then sought a hiding place.</l>
.<l n="c">As the mist was finally swept away, the hermitages on the hill sides, where the ascetics dwelt, </l>
4935<l n="d">Burnished brightly by the sun, were like white doves flashing past.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">Gleefully, the members of his escort* scattered, spreading out everywhere along the valleys, clinging* to the mountain ridges.</l>
.<l n="b">Some were leaping about, others made their way* to peaks north and south.</l>
.<l n="c">Merrily, joyfully, seeking out the delights of the forested hills.</l>
4940<l n="d">The reverberating sounds of their hunting* echoed as they wandered about there tumultuously.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">Content, the prince descended from his chariot and went off in search of the beauties of nature.</l>
.<l n="b">‘Indeed I will go into the woods, there I will surely find them’, he thought to himself,</l>
.<l n="c">And he went on unescorted, separating himself from the others so that there would be none to observe him.</l>
4945<l n="d">Then gradually leaving them behind, he wandered further away, ever more absorbed in beauty.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">The prince now became enthralled by the delightful ornaments that the forest held in readiness for him.</l>
.<l n="b">Far below, a small pavilion that looked like a mushroom nestling on the steep slopes of the rocky, pitted terrain, bade him welcome.</l>
.<l n="c">There the prince rested, gazing intently up at the splendid roof-beam,</l>
4950<l n="d">Where a name, faint now but still distinguishable, remained there for others to find and ponder.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">He could just make out another hermitage at the edge of the ravine which majestically towered above.</l>
.<l n="b">The penance of the ascetics who lived there must have been powerful beyond words,</l>
.<l n="c">For they were served* by female ascetics who would certainly bring failure to any who strove* to subdue their senses,</l>
4955<l n="d">Always planning to weave their charms to bewitch* the concentration of the seers.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">A gliding river of unearthly beauty appeared like a vision in a dream,</l>
.<l n="b">And from the mountain peak high above, it seemed to have formed a beach below.</l>
.<l n="c">Along the edges of its beautiful banks, rock-platforms waited invitingly,</l>
4960<l n="d">As if to decree that such beauty depicted in verse, could only be found in the poem of the prince of poets.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">In the middle of the water, he could just make out a reef, thrusting upward.</l>
.<l n="b">Even as the waves washed over it, caressing it and bespattering it with water, it stood unyielding.</l>
.<l n="c">Moreover, a veil of spray sought out the graceful pandanus draped* there,</l>
4965<l n="d">With their naked flowers trailing, as if to capture the attention of wanderers in pursuit of beauty.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">On reflection, these subtle hints of the wondrous appearance of the river-bank seemed</l>
.<l n="b">Designed to distract even the rapt attention of the one seeking the riddle of a name.</l>
.<l n="c"><foreign>Kinnara </foreign>birds* and swallows flew down to it.</l>
4970<l n="d">Some became entangled in the reeds* after bathing there, longing* to find a resting place to share.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">Herons swam in formation in the water, some standing there like mendicant monks,</l>
.<l n="b">Preening their feathers* as an excuse for looking intently* into the holes of the mud-eels.</l>
.<l n="c">Merrily, the warblers twittered incessantly, then went off together in pairs, flying into the air.</l>
4975<l n="d">The peacocks fell silent, content to go on dancing and remain in the water.</l>
.</p>
.</div>
.<div type="canto" n="27">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">The prince became more and more delighted when he saw</l>
4980<l n="b">That pure and crystal-clear mountain stream,</l>
.<l n="c">And so, drawing near to bathe his face,</l>
.<l n="d">He descended to the depths of that flawless river.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">There he performed the most excellent, paramount ritual gestures,</l>
4985<l n="b">Praying to the Lord of One Thousand Rays, the Sun.</l>
.<l n="c">Together with the recitation of esoteric formulas,* his meditation</l>
.<l n="d">Penetrated to the highest* inconceivable truth.</l>
.</p>
.</div>
4990<div type="canto" n="28">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">As the excellent Phalguṇa was praying, his mind calm and undisturbed, tranquil and pure,*</l>
.<l n="b">A gigantic, mighty crocodile, guardian of the river, suddenly appeared.</l>
.<l n="c">Its presence there was the reason that no-one* came near and that it was so deserted,</l>
.<l n="d">But now it caught the fragrant scent of the noble Pārtha. </l>
4995</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">Immediately, its ferocity awakened, for it was wild with hunger,</l>
.<l n="b">Burning with savage frenzy, so long had it been without food.</l>
.<l n="c">There it was spanning* the river, its mouth open wide, its fangs protruding sideways,</l>
.<l n="d">And protuberances* all over its face, so that it resembled the terrifying and awesome [demon] Rāhu.</l>
5000</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">It saw the prince, undaunted and confident,</l>
.<l n="b">Awaiting its attack. Swiftly it drew near,* but just as it was about to pounce,</l>
.<l n="c">He too advanced steadily, joined with it, </l>
.<l n="d">Spinning around and feinting fearlessly.</l>
5005</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">Swiftly, loudly, they clashed, keeping each other constantly in view, and as they came to grips,</l>
.<l n="b">The river seemed to open wide, its waters rising up and crashing down.</l>
.<l n="c">As if it were being stirred, it eddied in the centre, mud spewed forth,</l>
.<l n="d">As if they were scooping it up as they assailed each other, angrily attacking.</l>
5010</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">In violent commotion, they circled each other, lunging unexpectedly, grappling tirelessly, never weakening,</l>
.<l n="b">Skilfully and confidently attacking each other from all sides, without fear.</l>
.<l n="c">In turn they grabbed at each other, clawed at each other, locked in the battle of their furious assault,</l>
.<l n="d">Sometimes dancing about each other in their struggle, then joining once again in combat.</l>
5015</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">It seemed their struggle would never end, when, suddenly,* the crocodile looked to be worsted,</l>
.<l n="b">Momentarily off-guard, as Arjuna quickly seized it and spun it around as if it were weightless.</l>
.<l n="c">He dashed it down swiftly* upon a sharp rock, breaking its jaw,</l>
.<l n="d">Its neck* snapped and thus it was rendered powerless by Phalguṇa.</l>
5020</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">With that, the prince hauled it to the surface of the earth.</l>
.<l n="b">He looked in amazement upon its appearance in death.</l>
.<l n="c">For he thought himself bewitched, as he gazed upon a heavenly nymph.</l>
.<l n="d">Indeed, he could only think that this dead monster was strikingly beautiful.</l>
5025</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">An uninterrupted rain of flowers fell on the prince;</l>
.<l n="b">Buzzing bees circled him, moving from flower to flower.*</l>
.<l n="c">Such was the gift of homage that fell at the feet of Phalguṇa</l>
.<l n="d">And the prince, deeply gratified, sought an explanation.</l>
5030</p>
.</div>
.<div type="canto" n="29">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">Then the heavenly nymph spoke out.</l>
.<l n="b">‘Indeed, I, your servant, am a celestial being,</l>
5035<l n="c">An attendant of the renowned Dhanādhipa.</l>
.<l n="d">My name is none other than Sarwadā.*</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">‘I also have four beautiful sisters, nymphs all,</l>
.<l n="b">Who wandered with me in search of pleasures.</l>
5040<l n="c">We came to the district of Alakāwatī,</l>
.<l n="d">To the garden of the gods, the beautiful Amarāwatī.*</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">‘There a great seer was performing powerful yoga,</l>
.<l n="b">Undertaking religious austerities, without equal in the three worlds.</l>
5045<l n="c">But we then disturbed his meditation,</l>
.<l n="d">As if driven to it by some evil force.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">‘In his anger he cast a curse upon us: “Hey! You who scorn me!</l>
.<l n="b">May you become wicked crocodiles, desiring only to kill the creatures of the world!”</l>
5050<l n="c">Having cursed us thus, he then vanished,</l>
.<l n="d">Leaving us confused and heart-sore.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">‘We then moved swiftly off in search of a river.</l>
.<l n="b">When we came to Awindhya, we came upon him again.</l>
5055<l n="c">Together we fell at his feet and paid homage to him,</l>
.<l n="d">Begging him in his mercy to grant us a counter-curse.*</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">‘Since he cared for the welfare of others and was of patient mind,</l>
.<l n="b">Compassionate, because we had bowed down before him, expressing our submission,</l>
5060<l n="c">He bestowed upon us the blessing of his mercy and granted us the gift of a limit to the curse,</l>
.<l n="d">So that we might once again become pure beings.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">‘ “Resign yourselves! Soon it will come to pass</l>
.<l n="b">That one called Pārtha, the son of Pāṇḍu,</l>
5065<l n="c">Will come journeying here.*</l>
.<l n="d">He will draw you from the water, and you will again become divine.”</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">‘With those words he went on his way.</l>
.<l n="b">We set out together to seek a secluded place to dwell.</l>
5070<l n="c">Later we came here to the River Swabhadra</l>
.<l n="d">And became these vile crocodiles.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">‘Many ages have we spent in despair,</l>
.<l n="b">Always starving, with nothing to eat, barely alive and weakened.</l>
5075<l n="c">Deer, serpents - any that came here to drink the water -</l>
.<l n="d">Surely died, as we killed, destroyed, devoured.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">‘And so we never saw a living soul.</l>
.<l n="b">Feared by all, the enemy of all here,</l>
5080<l n="c">Becoming hungrier and hungrier in our pitiable, miserable condition*</l>
.<l n="d">Brought low by the overpowering force of our wicked, impure hearts.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">‘But now that you are here, my dream has been fulfilled.</l>
.<l n="b">Through you, I am again a nymph.</l>
5085<l n="c">Incomparable and boundless is my debt to you,</l>
.<l n="d">For you have drawn me out of the misery of hell.*</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="12"><l n="a">‘Forgive me! If you consider it proper,</l>
.<l n="b">Would you now go on to rescue my sisters,</l>
5090<l n="c">For they have been left languishing sorrowfully,</l>
.<l n="d">And are all waiting in the river?’</l>
.</p>
.</div>
.<div type="canto" n="30">
5095 <p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">Thus said the celestial woman to the noble Pārtha.</l>
.<l n="b">The prince was willing to accede to her gentle words.</l>
.<l n="c">Setting off* with the heavenly nymph,</l>
.<l n="d">They travelled swiftly, without stopping to rest.</l>
.</p>
5100<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">They came to the beautiful but inaccessible pools where the other crocodiles lived.</l>
.<l n="b">There he lifted them up and released them all.</l>
.<l n="c">They were delighted to be nymphs once again,</l>
.<l n="d">And all paid homage to the noble son of Pāṇḍu.</l>
.</p>
5105<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">‘O Lord Pārtha! Virtuously you strive for the welfare of the world.</l>
.<l n="b">You are indeed our protector, possessed of sanctifying power.</l>
.<l n="c">Truly you are Wiṣṇu incarnate</l>
.<l n="d">And the glow of your virtue fills the three worlds.’</l>
.</p>
5110<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">Thus they spoke. The prince was delighted:</l>
.<l n="b">‘O nymphs! How could I fail in my purpose?</l>
.<l n="c">It was only the proper <foreign>dharma</foreign>* of a man of virtue in this world</l>
.<l n="d">That I have followed, in taking upon myself* the burden of your sorrow.</l>
.</p>
5115<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">It was not for silver, gold, jewels or profit</l>
.<l n="b">That I rescued you from your time of trouble.</l>
.<l n="c">It befits a <foreign>kṣatriya</foreign> warrior to ensure no cruelty befalls the world.</l>
.<l n="d">He should strive only to devote himself to such meritorious deeds.’</l>
.</p>
5120<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">Thus said the excellent Pārtha in explanation.</l>
.<l n="b">It was as if the heavenly nymphs had been sprinkled with the water of life,</l>
.<l n="c">For they had received his most exalted favour,</l>
.<l n="d">And did not know how to repay such kindness that was as great as Mount Meru.</l>
.</p>
5125<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">‘We have enjoyed your unbounded favour,</l>
.<l n="b">Our debt is without limit, never can we [repay it].*</l>
.<l n="c">May you be unimpeded, my lord, in obtaining your desires and the victory you seek!</l>
.<l n="d">You are indeed the refuge of the defenceless, O protector of the earth!’</l>
.</p>
5130<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">Many were their praises of Prince Pārtha.</l>
.<l n="b">We will not tell of them. Having taken leave of him,</l>
.<l n="c">They departed without delay and, in a flash, flew away together into the sky,</l>
.<l n="d">Towards heaven. But we will say no more of this.</l>
.</p>
5135<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">Pārtha was left alone, love-lorn and weak with desire,</l>
.<l n="b">Prey to his emotions as he stared up into the heavens, totally bemused.</l>
.<l n="c">His heart missed a sudden beat as he caught the sound of distant thunder,</l>
.<l n="d">There in the west, for it seemed like the voices of those heavenly women.</l>
.</p>
5140<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">For a long time he sat in contemplation. When the sun had gone down</l>
.<l n="b">It became even more still there on the bank of the river.</l>
.<l n="c">Gently* it whispered [to him] as he watched the eddying stream. </l>
.<l n="d">‘I have been purified,’ it rippled, in proof that its waters* were free of danger.</l>
.</p>
5145<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">Now we will tell of the members of his escort who came running up at the double,</l>
.<l n="b">Competing with each other to be first there, trying to overtake each other.</l>
.<l n="c">With great merriment and in high spirits, some engaged in ferocious hand-to hand-combat,</l>
.<l n="d">So eager were they to hear about the heavenly women.</l>
.</p>
5150<p rend="stanza" n="12"><l n="a">And so the prince waited there.</l>
.<l n="b">But we will tell now of the great ascetics of the hermitage.</l>
.<l n="c">All who lived in the vicinity of the Swabhadra river</l>
.<l n="d">Had heard of the removal of the danger from their holy bathing place.</l>
.</p>
5155<p rend="stanza" n="13"><l n="a">They were so delighted to be afraid no longer,</l>
.<l n="b">That they quickly set off together to go* at once to the noble one.</l>
.<l n="c">Coming upon the excellent Pārtha resting there,</l>
.<l n="d">They were astounded by his splendid appearance.</l>
.</p>
5160<p rend="stanza" n="14"><l n="a">Arjuna greeted the arrival of the hermits with great respect</l>
.<l n="b">And sat politely, legs crossed, quiet and tranquil.</l>
.<l n="c">The sages* said: ‘How fortunate it is that you have come here now</l>
.<l n="d">To the Swabhadra, the lovely abode of we hermits.*</l>
.</p>
5165<p rend="stanza" n="15"><l n="a">‘And we say to you, O Prince, that by your actions in coming to these wooded mountains,</l>
.<l n="b">What you have accomplished is truly great.* You are the recourse of us who strive.</l>
.<l n="c">Your victory in this world is clearly ordained by the gods.</l>
.<l n="d">Indeed, we believe that you will obtain your goal and all that you strive for.’</l>
.</p>
5170<p rend="stanza" n="16"><l n="a">Thus said the seers. The prince replied sincerely,</l>
.<l n="b">‘As you look so kindly, Sirs, on one such as I, </l>
.<l n="c">May I be the sacrifice for you whose aim is to perform virtuous deeds,</l>
.<l n="d">In your wish to be free of the <foreign>karma</foreign> of the three worlds.’</l>
.</p>
5175<p rend="stanza" n="17"><l n="a">These were his words. Thereupon, in homage they brought him</l>
.<l n="b">Water to wash his feet, water to rinse his mouth, such as is due to a guest, as well as betel leaf and nut,</l>
.<l n="c">And medicinal herbs, not to mention delicious fruits and tubers.</l>
.<l n="d">All were offered to him by the anchoresses with all requisite ceremony.</l>
.</p>
5180<p rend="stanza" n="18"><l n="a">They were amazed just to look upon the noble Pārtha.</l>
.<l n="b">‘How extraordinary he is! He is the god of Love who has come here to earth,</l>
.<l n="c">With the purpose of hunting out beauty, consuming us with fire,</l>
.<l n="d">Spitefully destroying our vows and meditation,’ they thought.</l>
.</p>
5185<p rend="stanza" n="19"><l n="a">Then the groups of hermits all decreed</l>
.<l n="b">That Pārtha should immediately be honoured by the seers* themselves.</l>
.<l n="c">When he had been thus honoured,* he became even more content</l>
.<l n="d">And after a while the great abbot again spoke:</l>
.</p>
5190<p rend="stanza" n="20"><l n="a">‘O Prince! You are our most excellent refuge,</l>
.<l n="b">Protecting all the monks and their kin.</l>
.<l n="c">Because none but you has the gift of your virtuous nature*</l>
.<l n="d">We have witnessed* your triumph as you have attained your desires.</l>
.</p>
5195<p rend="stanza" n="21"><l n="a">‘And yet I will offer you my insignificant advice, if you will but listen.</l>
.<l n="b">As long as happiness increases, then difficulties will be suffered.</l>
.<l n="c">The origin of the love of others is invisible and therefore it is eternal.</l>
.<l n="d">It is thus the most important thing, the foremost embodiment of <foreign>dharma</foreign>.*</l>
.</p>
5200<p rend="stanza" n="22"><l n="a">‘For this [love] alone, you should truly search the depths of the self,*</l>
.<l n="b">Just as the foremost champion in battle always* fosters unity,</l>
.<l n="c">So that proper conduct ensues and thereby increases,</l>
.<l n="d">And his enemies, therefore, cannot attack.</l>
.</p>
5205<p rend="stanza" n="23"><l n="a">‘It is no different in the three worlds than in your body.</l>
.<l n="b">There can be no hostility because of kindness and freedom from passion. </l>
.<l n="c">Neither enemies from within nor without can assail you.</l>
.<l n="d">And you can be wholly unconstrained* and free from danger in obtaining your desires.’</l>
.</p>
5210<p rend="stanza" n="24"><l n="a">Thus was the form of the doctrine that he expounded* so properly.</l>
.<l n="b">Dhanañjaya welcomed it,</l>
.<l n="c">For indeed its sentiments were truly appropriate.</l>
.<l n="d">In short this was their discussion. But we will say no more of it.</l>
.</p>
5215<p rend="stanza" n="25"><l n="a">Night fell and the excellent and noble Pārtha spent it</l>
.<l n="b">There in the hermitage, the ascetics,*</l>
.<l n="c">Full of laughter and delight discussed* how the prosperity of the hermitage</l>
.<l n="d">Had been magically altered by the prince’s supernatural potency.</l>
.</p>
5220<p rend="stanza" n="26"><l n="a">The prince enjoyed staying there in the place that had been prepared for him</l>
.<l n="b">In an open pavilion, bright, clean and well-appointed.</l>
.<l n="c">In his private quarters, he was again fêted,</l>
.<l n="d">For the community of ascetics was not yet ready to retire.</l>
.</p>
5225<p rend="stanza" n="27"><l n="a">In every respect the enchanting hermitage, so still and lovely, was delightful,</l>
.<l n="b">With the moon adding the lustre* of its pale, gleaming rays</l>
.<l n="c">Like a lamp shining down upon the lights of the hermitage.</l>
.<l n="d">The wafting fragrance of the lovely areca blossoms permeated everywhere.</l>
.</p>
5230<p rend="stanza" n="28"><l n="a">Disturbed and stirred by the delightful sighing of the ivory bamboo swaying in the cooling breeze,</l>
.<l n="b">The bees sobbed in their holes with muffled song,</l>
.<l n="c">Beset by love-sickness now that night had come and they were separated* from the <foreign>aśoka</foreign> and <foreign>tañjung</foreign> flowers,</l>
.<l n="d">Arousing feelings of tender emotion in the prince’s heart.</l>
.</p>
5235<p rend="stanza" n="29"><l n="a">The seers discoursed happily on many matters</l>
.<l n="b">And the prince, Phalguṇa, was delighted to join in,</l>
.<l n="c">Now that the heavenly women had been restored to their true nature.</l>
.<l n="d">But we will not tell of the night. It quickly passed.</l>
.</p>
5240<p rend="stanza" n="30"><l n="a">The following morning, the prince went from there.</l>
.<l n="b">His journey along the forest paths* will not be recounted.</l>
.<l n="c">He came to Mayūra, where he was greeted with joy,</l>
.<l n="d">By all the delighted women of the palace.</l>
.</p>
5245</div>
.<div type="canto" n="31">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">On his return he lived in contentment with his wife in the palace for a long time.</l>
.<l n="b">The whole country was overwhelmed by perfect joy,</l>
.<l n="c">And the king was transported with delight because of Arjuna.</l>
5250</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">We will pass over how they came together in harmony in joyous love-making.</l>
.<l n="b">They brought into the world a child, a model of comeliness and virtue,</l>
.<l n="c">The excellent Wabhruwāhana, who was presented [to the king] by his father.*</l>
.</p>
5255<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">The king then performed the many excellent rituals prescribed, </l>
.<l n="b">Overjoyed to obtain this jewel of the ocean.</l>
.<l n="c">Such was the king’s happiness.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">None other than the prince himself occupied the hearts of the whole court, particularly those of the inner appartments.</l>
5260<l n="b">They wished to serve him alone,</l>
.<l n="c">For they looked to him to be the protector of the world.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">Their former sorrow was best described* as that of blades of grass,</l>
.<l n="b">Withering as they hoped for rain to fall from the clouds.</l>
5265<l n="c">Now, deluged with rain, they were truly bursting with new life.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">All the royal domains, even the rural districts, were perfect.</l>
.<l n="b">All were prosperous, no longer over-shadowed,</l>
.<l n="c">So radiant, they seemed to outshine the sun and the moon.</l>
5270</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">Long would be the telling of the joy throughout the land.</l>
.<l n="b">Our account now turns again to the prince,</l>
.<l n="c">Who kept constantly in mind the advice of the great ascetic.</l>
.</p>
5275<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">Furthermore, the end of the eleventh year had almost arrived,</l>
.<l n="b">And so he again prepared to move on,</l>
.<l n="c">His resolute heart unwavering.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">The prince took his beloved in his arms and addressed her with consoling words,</l>
5280<l n="b">Telling her of his certain promise,</l>
.<l n="c">That in the future he would return to serve her.*</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">The excellent princess, fully understanding his intention, was untroubled</l>
.<l n="b">Indeed, she never deviated from the teachings of highest truth,</l>
5285<l n="c">Unwilling to transgress [what is expected of] a beautiful woman.*</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">So, worthy princess that she was, she did not demur,</l>
.<l n="b">Unable to entertain evil thoughts,</l>
.<l n="c">Even if ordered to undertake lowly work.</l>
5290</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="12"><l n="a">So Dhanañjaya appeared in the presence of the king to take his leave.</l>
.<l n="b">The king offered no opposition,</l>
.<l n="c">For he was truly a virtuous and honest man, a worthy example to the world.</l>
.</p>
5295</div>
.<div type="canto" n="32">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">In short, after he had sought leave to depart he went from the palace straight away.</l>
.<l n="b">He walked without haste along the path, relaxed and totally absorbed in beauty.</l>
.<l n="c">He was filled with wonder at the sight of all the scenic beauties of the country-side, which seemed never to weary of trying to detain him, holding themselves in readiness* for him.</l>
5300<l n="d">Standing ready in the hope that they would catch sight of him, they waited overhead.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">Both sides of the path seemed to have spread out their charms for his sideways glance.</l>
.<l n="b">So astounded were they, and so oppressed with grief when he passed them by, that they could only stand there.</l>
.<l n="c">As if disturbed and despondent, the red flowers of the flame tree sighed and trembled when he ignored them.</l>
5305<l n="d">Tossing restlessly, the bamboos swayed back and forth, exhausted as the wind beat them and they knocked against each other.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">There was a settlement of great splendour, its many buildings scattered here and there, the pathways knowing how to give pleasure.</l>
