.<l n="b">Its carefully tended beauty was its gift of welcome if any should happen by.</l>
.<l n="c">Along the edge was a pure mountain stream, encircling the sides of the square,</l>
5310<l n="d">Where women went to draw water from the bathing pools, while others immersed themselves,* all were beautiful to behold.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">It certainly seemed as if they wanted to conceal themselves within an encircling ring of relatives.*</l>
.<l n="b">Their graceful movements were accompanied by the enchanting tabours, sweetly keeping tune with the <foreign>kangsi</foreign>.</l>
.<l n="c">How tantalizing* they were as they adorned themselves with flowers, the flower ornaments in their hair bands were beautifully arranged,</l>
5315<l n="d">But as they made their flower offerings, they became agitated at seeing the splendid prince as he passed by.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">How delightful were the charms that the prince beheld as he went on his way.</l>
.<l n="b">There was a row of springs, with fountains cascading down to form a crystal-clear pond,</l>
.<l n="c">A place where fresh lotuses gathered to form an encircling wall which, like the face of a beautiful girl, overflowed with sweetness,</l>
5320<l n="d">Their beauty constantly veiled by the spray of the water which covered them like fragrant powder.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">The outer walls were magnificent, perfect in design and construction.</l>
.<l n="b">The walls of the storehouses* within were made of bricks and merged into the enclosing parapet with its towering gateways.</l>
.<l n="c">Wholly unconstrained, fronds of slender <foreign>bhujanggapuṣpa</foreign> beckoned excitedly, </l>
5325<l n="d">As the wind continually pestered them wickedly, and they tossed and waved.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">As if to ornament the radiant beauty of the <foreign>jring</foreign>, the beautiful <foreign>wĕlas-harĕp</foreign> creeper was like a cloth of gold.*</l>
.<l n="b">Showing themselves in all their richness, the magnificent red lotuses* were skilled at enticing* the lovely umbrella-pandanus [to open].</l>
.<l n="c">The bees took flight as if, now they were no longer able to caress or ravish the flowers, they had come to a sudden stop, filled with great disappointment,</l>
5330<l n="d">And seemed to lose heart as the wind, telling them of charms of the jasmine, pushed them roughly aside.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">Moreover, the lovely marsh-land enhanced the splendour of the scene depicted.</l>
.<l n="b">Its charms seemed to long to accompany the prince on his journey, and reached out to draw near him.</l>
.<l n="c">Looking down, he could see the delightful banks where pandanus, pendant with flowers, grew along the edges</l>
5335<l n="d">And a rich profusion of radiant <foreign>śatapatra</foreign> lotuses opened out their shimmering petals and beckoned to the bees.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">The banks, where <foreign>surāga</foreign> and <foreign>rājasa</foreign> flowers blossomed,* were like a flower-strewn bed-chamber.</l>
.<l n="b">The <foreign>campaka</foreign> were downcast, their display* to no avail because they had not yet been plucked by a wanderer in pursuit of beauty.</l>
.<l n="c">Abandoned thus, they resigned themselves to their yearning, for no poet, eloping with his beloved, had come there to pick them,</l>
5340<l n="d">So that they were now willing to die and let their beauty slip away, by allowing their flowers to surrender their lives and float down, wilting, into the water.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">It would take too long to tell of the path or of the prince’s thoughts if we were to continue.</l>
.<l n="b">He went quickly on his way. We will not tell of the time he spent surrendering himself to beauty.</l>
.<l n="c">Soon after, he came to the shore,* where great beauty is ever to be found.</l>
5345<l n="d">So vast were its bright waters, that they seemed to merge on the horizon with the sky, then vanish from sight.</l>
.</p>
.</div>
.<div type="canto" n="33">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">The shore-line brought him transports of delight,</l>
5350<l n="b">With its beautiful inlets, so enchanting.</l>
.<l n="c">A river of clear water</l>
.<l n="d">Seemed to present its beauty as a gift to the ocean.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">Birds wandered about in search of food* on the water’s edge.</l>
5355<l n="b">Some were white, and, as they meandered everywhere,*</l>
.<l n="c">Stretching in a line, moving together in a row,</l>
.<l n="d">They were like jasmine flowers, worn in unbound tresses.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">Like the unloosened ties of a <foreign>kain</foreign> were the ripple marks of the waves on the sand.</l>
5360<l n="b">Happily, the lovely <foreign>himi-himi</foreign> crabs rested there,</l>
.<l n="c">Suddenly waving their pincers rapidly to and fro</l>
.<l n="d">As they scuttled away, burrowing down into the sand as the waves* receded.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">On an outcrop of glistening coral reef,</l>
5365<l n="b">Crabs were exposed and lay there clinging.</l>
.<l n="c">Throngs* of mussels hung there, </l>
.<l n="d">Shining emerald-green* in the sun’s radiant light.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">The many prawns, entrenched on the rocks,</l>
5370<l n="b">Frightened away the birds who were eyeing them.</l>
.<l n="c">Some came soaring through the air, wanting to land there,</l>
.<l n="d">But they tried in vain to swoop down, for they were so startled, they flew off again in a flash.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">In great numbers, fish leapt up, thrown high in the air.</l>
5375<l n="b">One after the other they burst forth, darting to and fro.</l>
.<l n="c">The porpoises and grey mullet, colliding,</l>
.<l n="d">Made the little fish dart away* as they hurtled down on top of them.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">Waves rolled in, crashing down</l>
5380<l n="b">As if they had been tossed aside and hurled away by a huge <foreign>timi</foreign> fish.*</l>
.<l n="c">Strands of seaweed* lay strewn about on all sides,</l>
.<l n="d">Like embroidered silk, decorating the wet sand.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">Wave after wave crashed onto the shore</l>
5385<l n="b">Suddenly giving off a rain-bearing mist,</l>
.<l n="c">Creating a shimmering rainbow</l>
.<l n="d">That extended, jewel-bright, as far as the eye could see.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">Shellfish and mussels* of many sorts were scattered here and there</l>
5390<l n="b">On shining fronds* spread like mats.</l>
.<l n="c">As the waves receded, they clattered,* trying to outdo each other,</l>
.<l n="d">Scraping continuously against the rocks in violent commotion.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">The foothills of the mountain were delightful.</l>
5395<l n="b">They extended far into the ocean’s maw.</l>
.<l n="c">In the deep recesses of their caves, </l>
.<l n="d">Rock swallows slipped away, flying off together.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">Far away in the distance was an island,</l>
5400<l n="b">Barely visible in the middle of the ocean.</l>
.<l n="c">How attractively it rose up,</l>
.<l n="d">A target for the veiling mist that enshrouded it so delightfully.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="12"><l n="a">A line of boats, their sails set, </l>
5405<l n="b">Dazzling white, seemed to beckon, </l>
.<l n="c">Telling of the riches they bore, </l>
.<l n="d">As they floated before the wind* on a voyage for treasure.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="13"><l n="a">Fishing boats* were everywhere, many far out in the middle of the ocean.</l>
5410<l n="b">Some, their decks at a precarious angle,* were being rowed.</l>
.<l n="c">But others had overturned and, in distress, were being spun around and around</l>
.<l n="d">By monstrous fish, as huge as mountains.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="14"><l n="a">The roaring ocean rumbled loudly</l>
5415<l n="b">As if to summon a poet to compose a poem,</l>
.<l n="c">Gracefully billowing, as if in restless torment,</l>
.<l n="d">To welcome Prince Pārtha joyfully.</l>
.</p>
.</div>
5420<div type="canto" n="34">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">All he saw on his journey along the seashore was beautiful.</l>
.<l n="b">Moreover, as the sun rode over the western mountain, it took his breath away.</l>
.<l n="c">Rising clouds of spray from the salters working on the banks of the river mouth,</l>
.<l n="d">Evaporated, merging into the ocean haze, like lovers in intimate* meeting.</l>
5425</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">There were rice fields and plantations of cotton trees in landscaped gardens.</l>
.<l n="b">As if uncertain of their charms, they presented the delights of their embankments to him.</l>
.<l n="c">A multitude of <foreign>pasung*</foreign> milled together in welcome and flew in wave upon wave into the air,</l>
.<l n="d">Leaving behind the crabs that stood so still they were hardly distinguishable in the roots of the <foreign>piḍaḍa</foreign> tree.*</l>
5430</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">Herons flying homeward* side-by-side like strings of beads across the sky,</l>
.<l n="b">Were seeking a place to roost, for it had now become gloomy and cold.</l>
.<l n="c">The sunbeams had just begun to lose their splendour in the ocean mist,</l>
.<l n="d">In a flaming, bright red-gleaming bank of wispy clouds, like showering sparks.</l>
5435</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">Then, from the inlets along the rocky coast in the distance, came the faint glow</l>
.<l n="b">Of firelight that flared up with a burst of bright sparks.</l>
.<l n="c">They looked like the reddened eyes* of a girl, languishing and forlorn, when overpowered on the couch,</l>
.<l n="d">Or perhaps they were proclaiming that there was a village there, where travellers might spend a night by the shore.</l>
5440</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">As the sun set, the trees shook visibly in the cold.</l>
.<l n="b">Now they had cast off the veiling mist of the ocean, they seemed truly downcast.</l>
.<l n="c">On the eighth day of the dark half of the moon, when, in the middle of the night, the moon came out displaying itself in its fullness,</l>
.<l n="d">He went on his journey again, after spending several nights sojourning there.</l>
5445</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">In Prabhasa, the prince came upon a flawless and pure river,</l>
.<l n="b">Its mighty waters flowing pure and bright, renowned for their purificatory powers, the very water of life.</l>
.<l n="c">This was the holy bathing place of the Yadu kingdom and none was more famous,</l>
.<l n="d">For it was as peerless as the moonstone,* the source of the world’s creation.</l>
5450</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">There the noble Dhanañjaya tarried a while and made his way along the banks.</l>
.<l n="b">Delightedly following the course of the Prabhasa, he then journeyed westward.</l>
.<l n="c">He was entranced by the sight of all its delights that so assuaged* his weary heart,</l>
.<l n="d">And ever welcomed him as he passed by, hoping he would linger.</l>
5455</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">Truly flawless was the river’s array, quite extraordinary its delights.</l>
.<l n="b">Many fallen and faded flowers,* left by those who came there to pray, had been abandoned there on the waves.</l>
.<l n="c">Because of the unguents and saffron mixed together, it was always fragrant</l>
.<l n="d">And members of the court came there daily, to bathe joyfully.</l>
5460</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">Indeed, its splendid snake-rock eclipsed the coral reefs of the ocean.</l>
.<l n="b">One rock completely covered by roots, looked like an elephant with a trunk.*</l>
.<l n="c">All who roamed about in pursuit of beauty, carried away on the tide of passion, made their way there,</l>
.<l n="d">And it was ever the destination of lovers, planning a secret rendezvous, stealing away quietly together to its banks.</l>
5465</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">On either side, pandanus blossomed delightfully along the banks.</l>
.<l n="b">Beautiful to behold were the trailing flowers, some with petals half opened.</l>
.<l n="c">When the bees sought them out, ensnared* by their fragrant pollen,</l>
.<l n="d">They, like maidens overcome by heat,* were deflowered by them at will.</l>
5470</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">No more will be said about the prince. Instead we will tell of Lord Kṛṣṇa.</l>
.<l n="b">On hearing that Pārtha, most excellent of princes, was there, he was delighted,</l>
.<l n="c">And immediately commanded the noble Sāmba to go and invite the son of Pāṇḍu to visit.</l>
.<l n="d">The Yadu warriors, mounted on horses, elephants and chariots, a strong guard attending them, provided the escort.</l>
5475</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="12"><l n="a">On his arrival, Sāmba approached the son of Pāṇḍu to greet him warmly,</l>
.<l n="b">Saying, ‘Indeed, His Majesty invites you to come* to his court.</l>
.<l n="c">Oh how happy is Kṛṣṇa and how delighted Baladewa too,</l>
.<l n="d">Not to mention the entire Yadu tribe, all are overjoyed to hear [news] of you.</l>
5480</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="13"><l n="a"> ‘The king is presently on Mount Raiwata’s peak*</l>
.<l n="b">Performing ceremonies in honour of Wiṣṇu,* holding a great feast and carrying out the royal rites.</l>
.<l n="c">Not a single Yadu has stayed behind at home, all are there, performing sacrifices and every ritual prescribed.</l>
.<l n="d">Thus may you bear patiently with him that he is not in his palace.’</l>
5485</p>
.</div>
.<div type="canto" n="35">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">Thus the excellent, noble Sāmba addressed him respectfully. Dhanañjaya accepted,</l>
.<l n="b">And they set out together, mounted in a chariot with all the Yadu hosts in attendance.</l>
5490<l n="c">Carefree and handsome were those who escorted them, all magnificent,</l>
.<l n="d">And so the excellent Phalguṇa made his way to the mountain called Raiwata[ka].</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">We will tell of the restlessness of the women throughout the land who, like flower-buds awaiting the sound of thunder,</l>
.<l n="b">Had just now heard news of the prince’s arrival, that was to them like the harbinger of the fourth month.</l>
5495<l n="c">The concealed desire of these jewel-like women of the inner court suddenly blossomed forth and now showed outwardly.</l>
.<l n="d">They did not know what to do, and unable to escape from their yearning, unable to forget what they had heard, were struck down by love.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">Smitten by the new arrival, some plotted to ready their sweetness [for him].</l>
.<l n="b">Others talked together, discussing him in soft whispers.</l>
5500<l n="c">So deeply* affected, cut to the very core of their being were they, that the mere mention of him aroused their desire,</l>
.<l n="d">And they wanted to spread* a mat of flowers from their hair-knots before him, as a token* of their love.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">There were some who were so love-sick they thought only of love-making, their thoughts directed to him alone.</l>
.<l n="b">Swooning, they longed fervently for his words of love to assuage the pain of their desire and bewilderment.</l>
5505<l n="c">So eager were they, they cast their beautiful bodies on the ground, that the sweetness of his glance might fall on them as rain,</l>
.<l n="d">Heedless of the pain if it should pierce them through, happy to face the dangers of defeat at his hands.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">It would take too long to recount the thoughts of the court ladies, suffering from love pangs.</l>
.<l n="b">Pārtha then reached King Harimūrti, there at the meeting place where the Yadu tribe had gathered.</l>
5510<l n="c">Foremost amongst them was Lord Baladewa. All were drawn up in formation, in the middle of the arena,</l>
.<l n="d">A place of perfect brilliance because of the splendour of the god-like Yadus.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">Arjuna’s arrival filled Kṛṣṇa’s heart with such elation</l>
.<l n="b">That he welcomed him accordingly with heart-warming smiles and kindly words:</l>
5515<l n="c">‘Dear brother, I can hardly believe that I may now come face to face with your world-conquering glory.</l>
.<l n="d">Receive this throne my dear brother, that I have laid ready for you in your absence.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">‘For some time I have kept watch over you, my dear, and have come to hear of your deeds as you have striven,</l>
.<l n="b">To dwell continuously on the Hima mountain. How fortunate that we now should meet.</l>
5520<l n="c">The gods decree: “Remember also the difficulties of those who know pleasure and are not afflicted with calamity.”*</l>
.<l n="d">Stay here in Dwārawatī, let it be your temporary home until the appointed time elapses and you can again return home.’</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">Thus said Lord Kṛṣṇa. The prince bowed low at his feet:</l>
.<l n="b">‘If it please you,* Your Majesty, in truth it is you who are truly the foremost bestower of favours. Hail to you,* O righteous one!’</l>
5525<l n="c">This he said. In turn Halāyudha said respectfully to him:</l>
.<l n="d">‘O my dear brother, indeed all the Yadus have certainly long awaited you.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">‘Your presence, my brother, will ensure that the rites which the Yadus now perform, will accomplish their aim perfectly.</l>
.<l n="b">Please agree to take part so that through your participation, the welfare of the world will be assured.*</l>
5530<l n="c">By this alone can our journey be considered complete and enable us to return to the palace.</l>
.<l n="d">Indeed, I will then accompany you home, my brother, as indeed will Kṛṣṇa.’*</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">Having spoken thus, Baladewa’s words were endorsed by the Yadu tribe.</l>
.<l n="b">And treated thus, the prince’s heart blossomed like a lotus at the urging of gentle rain:</l>
5535<l n="c">‘Truly your words are fitting. May I, Your Majesty’s servant, continue to receive the special favour I have obtained!</l>
.<l n="d">Indeed in your protection may I find the means by which my quest for virtue may succeed!’</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">The Yadus were all happy to agree, none was averse to Arjuna’s presence,</l>
.<l n="b">And welcomed the prince, as a guest, in every way he deserved.</l>
5540<l n="c">It would take too long to tell of this. Shortly after, as the sun set, the eighth hour* rang out.</l>
.<l n="d">The radiant glow of the clouds, coloured brightly with beams of light like golden ornaments, gave way to night.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="12"><l n="a">Lord Kṛṣṇa withdrew to his quarters, in company with the prince who loved him so.</l>
.<l n="b">Their spirits were as one, their affection deep and so they moved off to his private suite there in the camp.</l>
5545<l n="c">Shortly afterwards peace descended on all the Yadu tribe and on Dhanañjaya.</l>
.<l n="d">‘It is just as the mist reaches the waters of the ocean,’ he thought.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="13"><l n="a">Let us say no more of the kings but tell now of the palace ladies.</l>
.<l n="b">They were teased by longing now that the waning moon had altered the appearance of the night.</l>
5550<l n="c">The stars moved away to hide, just as a distressed girl, with side-long glances, turns her face away.</l>
.<l n="d">Geese in flight, distant specks in the sky, that seemed to be eloping together, came to alight on a beautiful pond.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="14"><l n="a">Abandoned, despondent and melancholy, the bees waited in their holes, distressed now that they had been robbed of their desire,</l>
.<l n="b">For the lotuses were no longer open. How cruel their actions,* for they were almost full-grown.</l>
5555<l n="c">Mournfully, the cuckoos lamented that the moon had not yet come to succour them in their love-sickness that evening,</l>
.<l n="d">Forlorn and trembling because it was the ninth day of the dark half-month and the moon had not yet risen.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="15"><l n="a">Moreover, the distant thunder seemed to summon whispered verses close to their ears.</l>
.<l n="b">The sighing breeze bearing sweet fragrance to them was like the secret messenger of one waiting to elope.</l>
5560<l n="c">Suddenly the moon shone down brightly, to reveal itself in its full glory, as it rose high over the mountain peak,</l>
.<l n="d">As if delighted to look down on the beauty of the women, happily applying powder* in the inner court.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="16"><l n="a">How lovely they were as they adorned their hair-knots with <foreign>aśoka</foreign> and <foreign>sumanasa</foreign> flowers, happily putting on their ornaments.</l>
.<l n="b">As they chatted together in the light of the moon, some were plaiting combs in their hair.</l>
5565<l n="c">Merely to speak of the pursuit of pleasure and the enjoyment of beauty, filled them with desire,</l>
.<l n="d">And because of their unrestrained longing and their sweetness, the very sight of the moon swept them away with passion.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="17"><l n="a">These beautiful women were skilled at expressing a poet’s passionate love in allusions.</l>
.<l n="b">It was only right that maidens so fair should not seek to hide the charm of their <foreign>salukat</foreign> playing in singing <foreign>kidung</foreign>.</l>
5570<l n="c">Because their skills were renowned throughout the land it seemed to enhance their sweetness as they accompanied themselves on the <foreign>kangsi</foreign>.</l>
.<l n="d">And not only that, for in their lute playing, the beauty of the ocean of honey* came surging forth.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="18"><l n="a">The women enhanced their charm and beauty by all having mastered thoroughly the art of poetry,</l>
.<l n="b">Their recitations became even more captivating, as the strummed lute accompanied* those sweet-voiced singers.</l>
5575<l n="c">Their playing seemed to be stolen liquid syrup and melted honey from a broken dish,*</l>
.<l n="d">Mixed with moonbeams, so that their <foreign>gamĕlan</foreign> playing caused utter enchantment.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="19"><l n="a">Others, filled with love, were talking quietly in sweet discussion.</l>
.<l n="b">Such easy prey for the God of Love were they, that their hearts were the target of passionate desires.</l>
5580<l n="c">Her feelings of love leaving her weak,* one girl went to lie down with a <foreign>kakawin</foreign> scribbled on a pandanus leaf.</l>
.<l n="d">As she read her poem aloud by the light of the moon, she was so painfully affected that in trying to keep secret* her longing, she fainted away.</l>
.</p>
.</div>
.<div type="canto" n="36">
5585<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">Yet the one who held sway over the subtle form of fragrant beauty, a goddess of letters in human form,</l>
.<l n="b">Was Subhadrā, the younger sister of Baladewa, now the fairest of maidens.</l>
.<l n="c">Indeed the beauty of this precious jewel of the palace was so renowned</l>
.<l n="d">That the very incarnation of liquid honey would return to seek help from her charms.</l>
.</p>
5590<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">The lovely women who lived in the royal palace were enchanting as they disported in the moonlight.</l>
.<l n="b">With a deluge of charm, as they skilfully sang songs containing allusions and played <foreign>gamĕlan</foreign>, they were indeed as beautiful as heavenly women.</l>
.<l n="c">For the princess alone, they always composed with great devotion, songs</l>
.<l n="d">That were as lively and charming as the ocean overflowing with the rains of the fourth month.</l>
.</p>
5595<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">Without doubt, these court maidens were truly possessed of the greatest sweetness,</l>
.<l n="b">But the charms of the princess were without peer, she alone held beauty.</l>
.<l n="c">Just as the alluring lotus, opening up, reflects the glow of moonbeams,</l>
.<l n="d">Her beauty was enhanced by her adornments and all who gazed upon it seemed to lose themselves in rapture.</l>
.</p>
5600<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">At the fourth stroke of midnight, the lovely women were still happily disporting there,</l>
.<l n="b">But the princess, lulled by their <foreign>gamĕlan</foreign> playing, had become sleepy.</l>
.<l n="c">A couch was arranged for her beneath a fragrant spreading <foreign>wungū</foreign> tree,</l>
.<l n="d">Beautifully entwined with the shoots of the cinnamon tree and strewn on all sides was fragrant* jasmine.</l>
.</p>
5605<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">There the princess, as beautiful as the Goddess of Love, Ratih, rested on the bed.</l>
.<l n="b">Soothed by her beautiful surroundings, sleepiness crept over her and entered unseen into her heart.</l>
.<l n="c">Blown about constantly by the wind, the boughs fluttered in the breeze, like waving fans.</l>
.<l n="d">Soothingly and affectionately* the bees in their holes called out gently.*</l>
.</p>
5610<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">The delightful murmuring of the <foreign>garantung</foreign> bamboo xylophones delightfully vied, in unbroken rhythm, with the thunder.</l>
.<l n="b">Lovely and sweet was the music of the lutes as the women gracefully and languidly sang the introductory melody,</l>
.<l n="c">As if to soothe and sing a lullaby to their lady, who slept there absorbed in dreams,</l>
.<l n="d">For all the world like an offering of a maiden,* resting on a couch, inspiring devotion.</l>
.</p>
5615</div>
.<div type="canto" n="37">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">The enchantment of the night permeated everywhere.</l>
.<l n="b">Moreover, the distant splashing of a waterfall could be heard unceasingly.</l>
.<l n="c">The hammering of bark* suddenly sounded out and seemed to inspire feelings of longing,</l>
5620<l n="d">As its relentless, incessant beat urged lovers to elope.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">Thunder rumbled softly like a lover’s sweet whispers,</l>
.<l n="b">To make the buds of the flowers of the <foreign>unĕng</foreign> creeper* split open and display themselves in their fullness.</l>
.<l n="c">The areca palm blossoms unfurled to wound the hearts of the love-lorn mercilessly,</l>
5625<l n="d">The <foreign>asanas,</foreign> buffeted by the wind, spread their fragrant perfume on the breeze.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">Such was the beauty and charm that it would fain set hearts atremble.</l>
.<l n="b">Pārtha was not yet asleep for he was completely captivated.</l>
.<l n="c">A breath of wind passing by brought him its cool freshness.</l>
5630<l n="d">He could hear the <foreign>walik</foreign> calling, its lament made him smile.*</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">Night passed and as day dawned, the world donned fresh clothing,</l>
.<l n="b">As the <foreign>asanas</foreign> in the borders of the delightful hermitage opened.</l>
.<l n="c">The sun whirled, spinning around in the water of the sea, </l>
5635<l n="d">Its golden rays shining brightly to dye the heavens in red light.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">Birds twittered* in the branches, merrily calling out* to each other for joy of the day.</l>
.<l n="b">Swarming bees buzzed backwards and forwards, resting on one flower* after another, like husbands* going from wife to wife.</l>
.<l n="c">When it became light, the son of Pāṇḍu bathed and purified himself</l>
5640<l n="d">Before invoking the sun with the recitation of mantras and the prescribed rites.*</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">Assiduously, he sought the object of his prayers.</l>
.<l n="b">His heart ever turned to the gods as he performed his worship.</l>
.<l n="c">So too, Lord Kṛṣṇa devoted himself to reciting the mantras of kingship,</l>
5645<l n="d">Unfailingly striving for tranquillity, and, having adorned himself, was even more resplendent.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">When they had both completed their ritual washing and recited their prayers,</l>
.<l n="b">They came out together, standing ready there at the gateway.</l>
.<l n="c">Their garments gleaming brightly shone like the newly-risen sun.</l>
5650<l n="d">Together, they were as resplendent as the sun riding on the highest point of the eastern mountain.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">The Yadus were already assembled, their vassals all stood ready.</l>
.<l n="b">Haladhara was bedecked with gleaming jewels.</l>
.<l n="c">Incomparable was he, clearly a hero of immense presence.</l>
5655<l n="d">All the Wṛṣṇis and Andhakas stood together in rows in close formation.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">Then they set out immediately, and came at last to the sanctuary,*</l>
.<l n="b">Where all was faultlessly arranged, in great splendour.</l>
.<l n="c">Standards fluttered gracefully on high,* a glittering mass,*</l>
5660<l n="d">Pennants swayed and pennons sparkled.*</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">As the Yadu troops noisily bustled about their tasks there in the hermitage, they filled it completely.</l>
.<l n="b">The melodies, sounding out unceasingly,* were taken up* by the many singers.</l>
.<l n="c">Then, filling every direction, - north, south, east and west, - with their sound,</l>
5665<l n="d">Drums banged and gongs and <foreign>roñji</foreign>* answered each other.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">The commotion of so many Wṛṣṇis and Yadus became more and more tumultuous.</l>
.<l n="b">They looked like an ocean of blossoming flowers in their brilliant festival attire, </l>
.<l n="c">And it was especially the lovely women who created this beautiful scene,</l>
5670<l n="d">With the movement of their shapely eyebrows as sharp as slivers of gravel.*</l>
.</p>
.</div>
.<div type="canto" n="38">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">The Yadu hosts added their increasing lustre to the radiance of the temple.</l>
5675<l n="b">It was as divine in appearance as the abode of the gods and its shrines were all-surpassing.</l>
.<l n="c"> Exquisite cloths - <foreign>dukūla, manitra</foreign> and <foreign>kairatila* </foreign>- all decoratively arranged, were draped everywhere,</l>
.<l n="d">And, as if by magic, the garlands of <foreign>cawĕli</foreign> silk seemed to be aflame.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">Songs of praise* rang out and many different bells tinkled like buzzing bees circling beautiful flowers.</l>
5680<l n="b">All was enriched by the blaring of conches, vying with the resounding <foreign>gubar</foreign> gongs,</l>
.<l n="c">As the chief priests softly and clearly recited prayers together,</l>
.<l n="d">For the prosperity of the kingdom, that it might be without conflict* and all evil-doers vanquished.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">After paying homage to the deities, the kings performed the flower-offering ceremonies at the shrine of Widhi.* </l>
5685<l n="b">The Yadus also all performed flower worship to Wiṣṇu, truly concentrating their thoughts upon him,*</l>
.<l n="c">As he now descended to the most exquisite, golden pavilion,* for he was their paramount protector,</l>
.<l n="d">Renowned on earth as the cause of the king’s most famous deeds.*</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">The festivities then took place, arranged with all-surpassing magnificence.</l>
5690<l n="b">Elated, the Yadus joined together in mock-combat, and moved into the attack, resplendently.*</l>
.<l n="c">All who took part were skilled in the use of shields and in wielding javelins and hatchets.</l>
.<l n="d">Their gleaming armour seemed ablaze as wave after wave attacked, becoming ever more dazzling.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">Some looked their opponents defiantly in the eye. All were masters at alternately pushing forward then dodging skilfully.</l>
5695<l n="b">Standing upright together they exchanged lusty shouts,* for they had been well trained in the ways of battle.</l>
.<l n="c">In their splendour, they were worthy bearers* of the gleaming jackets of honour and sparkling arm-bands.*</l>
.<l n="d">The violence of their clashing drowned out* the constant roar of thundering <foreign>gubar</foreign> and <foreign>paḍahi</foreign> drums.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">The decorations worn by those wild with drink were resplendent: their gleaming mail shone all the more fiercely.</l>
5700<l n="b">Their breasts all aglow from their clothes, some wore bright shining collars.</l>
.<l n="c">With their arms stretched sideways, they took no notice of the actions of those who shouted at them.</l>
.<l n="d">The attendants asked to bring them drinks of welcome, stopped, embarrassed by their jabbering.*</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">The spectators, the young gentlewomen and the children of the nobles who were famous for their goodness and refined manners,</l>
5705<l n="b">Though amused to see this, covered their lips with their hands demurely.*</l>
.<l n="c">Truly enchanting were the brief glimpses of their sideways glances as they opened and closed their mouths in sweet laughter,</l>
.<l n="d">And it seemed the gathering place of honey would be eclipsed by their open lips, fresh and red.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">But we will not tell of them as, at sunset, it all came to an end.</l>
5710<l n="b">A great feast was then held by all the Yadus, in the centre of the arena.*</l>
.<l n="c">Laid out in readiness were all the delicious produce of mountain, forest and sea,</l>
.<l n="d">Which they ate with relish, their enjoyment enhanced by the entertainment offered by the musicians.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">Because it had been arranged by the kings, Kṛṣṇa, Pārtha, Baladewa and Ugrasena,</l>
5715<l n="b">There seemed to be a thundering mountain torrent* of meat, drink and other delicacies.</l>
.<l n="c">The kings had catered for every conceivable taste,</l>
.<l n="d">And all became more and more intoxicated, overwhelmed with drinks of fermented spirits* and rum.</l>
.</p>
.</div>
5720<div type="canto" n="39">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">Thus was the form of the worship they performed,* most prominent amongst them* all the Wṛṣṇi heroes.</l>
.<l n="b">But we will not tell of this. After they had finished eating, all had been made content by the king’s bounty,</l>
.<l n="c">Not to mention the Wṛṣṇi troops who were replete with food and drink.</l>
.<l n="d">Becoming ever more joyful and merry, they took their leisure and caroused in their quarters.</l>
5725</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">In the cool of the evening Baladewa went off in search of beauty.</l>
.<l n="b">Lord Kṛṣṇa following behind, they set off from the royal quarters.</l>
.<l n="c">With Pārtha at his side, riding with him in the same chariot,</l>
.<l n="d">Clearly they were indeed, as splendid as Wiṣṇu* and the God of Love, both irresistible in form.</l>
5730</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">The valiant Wṛṣṇis and Andhakas also went off to seek out different pleasures,* each according to their desire.</l>
.<l n="b">There were some who headed for the hermitage to reflect on the beauty of the banks of the river* and deep craggy gullies.</l>
.<l n="c">Others went to secluded parts of the forest, in search of a place to be alone and gaze out over the distant ocean,</l>
.<l n="d">While others went hunting, gaily cooking and eating [their catch in] a floating water-pavilion.*</l>
5735</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">Even more magnificent was the princess as she departed,* indeed, she was a painting come to life.</l>
.<l n="b">Riding in a chariot on a throne of gold, she was as beautiful as the embodiment of all the deities of the month of spring,</l>
.<l n="c">Displaying charms that seemed to come forth from the realm of dreams to thrust aside all other sensory delights.</l>
.<l n="d">Her escort of warriors, standing fully-equipped on either side, was as resplendent as a foot-guard of gods. </l>
5740</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">The ladies of the court were like flower buds opening up, their joyful hearts full of high spirits.</l>
.<l n="b">Their attendants and handmaidens competed with each other to gather the largest bunches of blossoming flowers.</l>
.<l n="c">Many rode in covered palanquins of gold, others in black ones with golden parasols,</l>
.<l n="d">Which looked like bees in search of flowers, their colours muted* by a misty veil of fragrant, unfurling pandanus.</l>
5745</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">As if to restrain their tendrils from longing* to capture the hearts of the people passing by,</l>
.<l n="b">The supple creepers, newly unfurling, languidly hung down, limp with desire.</l>
.<l n="c">Lovingly, the lovely <foreign>sanggākaśa</foreign> creeper seemed to embrace the beautiful clusters of blossoms, filled with passion.</l>
.<l n="d">Moreover so thick were its tendrils that the area around was cast in shadow and gave forth fragrance to accompany them.*</l>
5750</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">Like an aigrette of gold, the <foreign>karṇnikāra</foreign>, displaying the charm of its blossom for the first time, was radiant.</l>
.<l n="b">Its young leaves* moved restlessly, stretching out in all directions as if they had no desire for the fragrant <foreign>gaḍung.</foreign></l>
.<l n="c">They seemed to sway continuously, shying away from the embrace of the young shoots growing along the ground.</l>
.<l n="d">Dallying there was a wood-cock, flapping his wings, with his wife below, his constant companion.</l>
5755</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">Then the trees rustling with expectant pleasure* in the soft breeze</l>
.<l n="b">That brings with it the rain of the fourth month, were delighted to be visited by such beautiful love-sick maidens, and invited them to come near.</l>
.<l n="c">The mango and mangosteen, <foreign>rambutan</foreign>, <foreign>wadara</foreign>,* <foreign>wuni</foreign>, and <foreign>paḍali</foreign> were heavily laden, their flowers and fruits all laid ready for them, </l>
.<l n="d">And the maids, gathering the fruits of the trees along the many paths, were delightful.</l>
5760</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">As they picnicked there, how enchanting they were. The astounding sight of such extraordinary beauty was sure to quicken the pulse,</l>
.<l n="b">For, in great delight, they had lifted their hems as they sought pleasure, enhancing their loveliness still more,</l>
.<l n="c">Exposing their slender calves, that, as they peeped from underneath their <foreign>kains</foreign>, were like ivory pandanus flowers.</l>
.<l n="d">It was only fitting that the sight of them would make the desire and passion of any lover catch in his throat,* overpower and destroy him.</l>
5765</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">The forest, carpeted with flowers, rivalled the design of a palace, its blooms drawn up in floral battle formations everywhere.</l>
.<l n="b">The women were the female warriors* attacking them together, inevitably destroying them as they seized them.</l>
.<l n="c">Indeed they were lions in battle, like bees thrusting eagerly, wanting only to be one* with the fragrant flowers.</l>
.<l n="d">And so they all joined in laying waste the flowers,* carrying them off by force, plucking them all without pause.</l>
5770</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">There were many whose thoughts had turned to love-making and, without further ado, they ornamented their beauty as they walked along.</l>
.<l n="b">Wholly unconstrained, they arranged tendrils of the <foreign>aśoka</foreign> as love-tokens* in their hair, the pollen enveloping them in its fragrance.</l>
.<l n="c"><foreign>Śridanta</foreign> and <foreign>wungu</foreign> were the ornaments they used as sashes and necklaces delightfully adorning themselves.</l>
.<l n="d">One could only surmise that in their beauty was the alluring sweetness of a sister to love* seeking out pleasure.</l>
5775</p>
.</div>
.<div type="canto" n="40">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">We will tell of Lord Kṛṣṇa and Pārtha,</l>
.<l n="b">As in leisurely manner, they made their way along the mountain ridge,</l>
5780<l n="c">Looking down on the beauty of the hill below,</l>
.<l n="d">Its charms clearly lying ready to view.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">Pure, sparkling waters splashed down over the ravine,</l>
.<l n="b">The many streams forming a pond of great beauty.</l>
5785<l n="c">The glistening water plants thus bespattered</l>
.<l n="d">Were indeed like a treasure trove of countless jewels and gems there.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">Another crystal-clear brook spilled down the hill.</l>
.<l n="b">A waterfall could be distinctly heard tumbling straight down into the ravine.</l>
5790<l n="c">There in the deep gully it roared like thunder,</l>
.<l n="d">Resounding more loudly than the <foreign>gubar</foreign> and <foreign>gĕṇḍing</foreign> drums at the great festival.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">Moreover its sparkling, glinting droplets</l>
.<l n="b">Were scattered and strewn about on every side,</l>
5795<l n="c">As if to bid them welcome with reverential salutations </l>
.<l n="d">Constantly* paying them homage, or so they thought.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">Lord Arjuna was delighted when he saw</l>
.<l n="b">How the mountain seemed to hold itself in readiness.</l>
5800<l n="c">Peacocks crowed on the hills along the mountain ridges</l>
.<l n="d">And the <foreign>kamanak</foreign>* together answered each other.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">The soft buzzing of bees, charmingly lost in contemplation of beautiful flowers,</l>
.<l n="b">Could be heard all along the path, </l>
5805<l n="c">Sipping nectar like priests</l>
.<l n="d">Conferring blessings of praise on the two of them as they passed.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">Moreover, the casuarinas blowing about in the wind, rustled,</l>
.<l n="b">Whispering gently as if to attract their attention.</l>
5810<l n="c">Faintly, softly, the turtle doves provided the accompaniment</l>
.<l n="d">In counterpoint to the melodious voices of the <foreign>pakṣi kĕtur</foreign> birds.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">The shoots of the <foreign>wĕlas-hyun</foreign> creeper were beautifully intertwined*</l>
.<l n="b">With the fragrant palms,* quite inseparable.</l>
5815<l n="c">The widely spread branches of the trees hung low,</l>
.<l n="d">And the water lilies, from kindness, seemed to keep them afloat.*</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">Moreover, there was over-hanging <foreign>prabhu sanmata</foreign> there, </l>
.<l n="b">With its creepers unfurling on all sides to screen* the thickets.</l>
5820<l n="c">Charmingly showing itself in its full richness, the ripened <foreign>wuni</foreign> </l>
.<l n="d">Skilfully split its sharp blackened points into four.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">Mount Raiwata[ka] was truly beautiful</l>
.<l n="b">And Janārdana spoke of it thus:</l>
5825<l n="c">‘Here is the fixed abode* of God Wiṣṇu,</l>
.<l n="d">None other than the place of refuge of the people of Dwārawatī.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">‘The Yadus therefore always strive</l>
.<l n="b">To ensure that proper worship flourishes and respectfully pay homage here,</l>
5830<l n="c">Sedulously intent on their aim of furthering the welfare of the realm,</l>
.<l n="d">And from its protection comes its certain prosperity.’</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="12"><l n="a">Thus said Kṛṣṇa to Dhanañjaya,</l>
.<l n="b">Filling the prince’s heart with strength.</l>
5835<l n="c">Therefore he set off happily</l>
.<l n="d">Along the winding valley path through the ravine.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="13"><l n="a">The dense bamboo that lined the narrow path,</l>
.<l n="b">Was shaken and bent back by the gentle breeze.</l>
5840<l n="c">The plants had deliberately opened up to expose their centres</l>
.<l n="d">And when they were pushed over, they seemed to sink down with a rustle.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="14"><l n="a">Steep slopes and precipices came right up to the verges. </l>
.<l n="b"><foreign>Gĕsing</foreign> and <foreign>pĕtung</foreign> bamboos rose up side by side,</l>
5845<l n="c">Sheaths unfurled to expose their half-closed eyes, blinking</l>
.<l n="d">Their scratchy shoots,* all ready for the attack.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="15"><l n="a">It would take too long to tell of them passing by the thickets.</l>
.<l n="b">With each step they encountered beauty.</l>
5850<l n="c">As they gazed up at the mountain, its splendour seemed magical,</l>
.<l n="d">Its charm as a pleasure spot quite unsurpassed.</l>
.</p>
.</div>
.<div type="canto" n="41">
5855<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">They could see the women of the inner court enjoying the scenery there, all as beautiful as figures in a painting.</l>
.<l n="b">As they delightfully cut flower-sprays, displaying their charms anew,* how resplendent they were.</l>
.<l n="c">They looked like sculpted diamonds as they abandoned themselves to the pursuit of pleasure all joyfully disporting, themselves,</l>
.<l n="d">Their charms those of the Goddess of Beauty herself, newly emerging in bodily form from a profusion of flowers.</l>
.</p>
5860<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">A garden of beautiful women were they, akin to <foreign>asana</foreign> flowers that have just come to intimate union* with the river.</l>
.<l n="b">Some were adorning themselves, looking at their reflections in the water whilst arranging their hair-knots with bouquets of flowers.</l>
.<l n="c">Others dangled their legs in the water to cool themselves, as if to avoid* the gushing torrent,</l>
.<l n="d">Attractively exposing their slender waists, fit to pierce the <foreign>kangsi</foreign>* of the God of Love.</l>
.</p>
5865<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">These beautiful ladies were like a painting come to life, their glances, when they looked sideways, sweet enough</l>
.<l n="b">To cause intense love-pangs and burning desire. Their hair bands were as perfect and smooth as dark clouds.</l>
.<l n="c">Their graceful limbs were bedecked with armlets and garlands made from <foreign>asana</foreign> flowers and <foreign>wĕlas-harĕp</foreign> creepers,</l>
.<l n="d">Like a collection of beauty created by the God of Love, glimpsed for but a moment of passion, by a poet.</l>
.</p>
5870<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">One girl, lost in rapt contemplation of* the far ocean, would awaken feelings of love</l>
.<l n="b">As if, at the decree of the Muse, her loveliness was not of this world, but must merge into the letters [of a poem].</l>
.<l n="c">Unperturbed as her waist broke free of the embrace of its bands, and suddenly loosened,</l>
.<l n="d">To expose [her breasts] like ivory coconuts a little, she was enough to inundate* even the senses of an ascetic who has already attained detachment.</l>
.</p>
5875<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">Another there was whose refined beauty was so like that of the <foreign>campaka</foreign> flower that it was only proper she be reserved for the God of Love.</l>
.<l n="b">As she held on her lap a pandanus flower, her calves seemed driven to expose themselves as if they were the reason for the rain.</l>
.<l n="c">How beautiful she was as she wrote on the doll of petals cradled in her lap, inscribing it with her sharp nails,*</l>
.<l n="d">Sitting restfully leaning on one arm on the rock, then turning her attention to the beauties of nature in the stream in the gully.</l>
.</p>
5880<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">Yet another rested charmingly on a couch of rock as she pictured in her mind the petal-doll coming to life.*</l>
.<l n="b">Fragrant leaves and jasmine were her mattress as she sat absorbed in the vastness* of the beautiful sky.</l>
.<l n="c">Her skin was golden, her uncovered waist as supple as the new shoots of the <foreign>aśoka,</foreign></l>
.<l n="d">Which would clearly wither, if she were approached on that couch by an ardent lover.</l>
.</p>
5885<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">The beautiful female attendants transported beauty there, as they amused themselves, their charms surpassing* those of flower buds.</l>
.<l n="b">Exuberantly they sought sweet delight. All had been blessed with figures of such beauty that they were fitting to be the object of longing.</l>
.<l n="c">Joyously the young girls, wearing beautiful wreaths of <foreign>wungū</foreign> flowers, picked flowers and shoots,</l>
.<l n="d">Their youthful sweetness giving them a special radiance as they moved about. </l>
.</p>
5890<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">They seemed never to tire of seeking out the beauties of nature, spreading out* the fragrant <foreign>asanas</foreign> and jasmine.</l>
.<l n="b">They wove blossoming <foreign>tañjung</foreign> and lovely <foreign>priyaka</foreign> into garlands and used them straight away as pins in their hair-knots.</l>
.<l n="c">Their ear ornaments were young <foreign>tarawarṣa</foreign> creepers,* their hair secured with clasps of <foreign>gaḍung</foreign> shoots,*</l>
.<l n="d">The fragrant pollen which fell on their beautiful breasts, they used as powder, its perfumes wafting overall.</l>
.</p>
5895<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">Although the many beautiful women there could be depicted as incarnations of Beauty,</l>
.<l n="b">They were clearly no match for the sweet beauty of her whose loveliness outshone* all at court.</l>
.<l n="c">Instead, if they entered her presence, the charms of these other jewels of the palace seemed to become useless and falter.</l>
.<l n="d">In short, Subhadrā was the essence of beauty* and the incarnation of every delight of the ocean of honey.</l>
.</p>
5900<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">Now Nature had fashioned a bower that was as beautiful as a painting.</l>
.<l n="b">Carved of coral, beautifully hung with curtains of <foreign>wĕlas-harĕp</foreign> creeper, gracefully it displayed its charms.</l>
.<l n="c">Forming a magnificent wall along each side, <foreign>jangga</foreign> vines unfurled towards the sugar palms.</l>
.<l n="d">As they reached out, shaken continually by the wind, their wafted fragrance pervaded overall.</l>
.</p>
5905<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">From there, she took pleasure in watching her maids who had mastered thoroughly the art of beautiful songs.</l>
.<l n="b">She was like a beautiful statue, lost in thought, and they came to her to present her with fragrant pandanus<foreign>.</foreign></l>
.<l n="c">Such was her due and, undoubtedly, she alone was the most exalted jewel of the court.</l>
.<l n="d">How else could she be thought of than as the beauty of molten honey in visible form?</l>
.</p>
5910<p rend="stanza" n="12"><l n="a">Truly, she was the origin* of bounteous beauty, the jewel of loveliness, the soul of the whole world.</l>
.<l n="b">Confused, the bees in the pandanus followed after her, carried away by longing, unable to resist caressing her feet.</l>
.<l n="c">Those devoted* to her care could not fail to be thrown into confusion at the sight of her resting there on the elephant rock.</l>
.<l n="d">Any who caught even a glimpse of her would think that she was the goddess of beauty, returning to her immaterial state.</l>
.</p>
5915<p rend="stanza" n="13"><l n="a">How could the beauty of the seeds of the <foreign>sumanasa</foreign>* or the blossoming pandanus not be defeated and annihilated?</l>
.<l n="b">How could even the most skilfully written <foreign>kakawin</foreign> possibly have within its orbit the words to depict* her?</l>
.<l n="c">The sharp point of the stylus of a poet composing verse would snap,* unable to go on, greatly distressed and without purpose,</l>
.<l n="d">Because in the face of her beauty, the subtle words on the writing board would cease, their blackness would simply vanish.</l>
.</p>
5920<p rend="stanza" n="14"><l n="a">The delights of the sea-shore would be destroyed, so awe-stricken at being thus rejected,* that they would leave without a backward glance.</l>
.<l n="b">The mountains would crumble, not daring to breathe, no longer able to elicit rapturous wonder because of her.</l>
.<l n="c">Taken by surprise, the beauty of the sky, even if it could be captured,* would certainly have no effect and would pine away,</l>
.<l n="d">While the charms of a beautiful garden would disappear, even though it would wrongly cause sorrow.</l>
.</p>
5925</div>
.<div type="canto" n="42">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">Pārtha came there together with Kṛṣṇa,</l>
.<l n="b">Their hearts filled with joy at seeing the beauty of the wooded hills.</l>
.<l n="c">All at once Pārtha was overcome with sharp longing.</l>
5930<l n="d">Thoughts of the princess filled his mind, throwing him into utter confusion.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">Therefore the prince questioned the king:</l>
.<l n="b">‘That girl there, Subhadrā, who is known to be the most outstanding of princesses,</l>
.<l n="c">Goddess of all enchanting beauty, </l>
5935<l n="d">The daughter of king Basudewa, is a jewel amongst maidens.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">‘Truly, on all this earth she has no equal.</l>
.<l n="b">How could any passionate man* be indifferent to her or unaffected by her?</l>
.<l n="c">Beauty* should be the only goal of a passionate man.</l>
5940<l n="d">Gold and superb jewels would easily be a fitting price for it.’</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">Thus he said. Kṛṣṇa replied:</l>
.<l n="b">‘O indeed you are mistaken in what you say, my brother.</l>
.<l n="c">Although my little sister is young and ripe for marriage,</l>
5945<l n="d">It is actually very difficult to find someone to match her.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">‘Even though it is expected* that a <foreign>swayambara</foreign> be held,</l>
.<l n="b">Only forcible abduction would suffice,</l>
.<l n="c">For a truly valiant and mighty hero </l>
5950<l n="d">Who would dare to seize her, unafraid of my presence here.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">‘Perhaps such a one could win over my sister,</l>
.<l n="b">And would not be afraid to resist the warriors of the line of Wṛṣṇi.’</l>
.<l n="c">Thus said Janārdana with asperity,*</l>
5955<l n="d">As if inflamed with ire at the words of the son of Pāṇḍu.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">The noble Pārtha was indeed resolute and knew no fear:</l>
.<l n="b">‘Were all of them able to lie in ambush, still I would crush them and destroy them all!’</l>
.<l n="c">Thus he thought and rose to his feet crying:</l>
5960<l n="d">‘I am not afraid of you Yadus!’ and immediately strode forward.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">Swiftly he seized the frightened princess,</l>
.<l n="b">Who was dazed and shocked as he clasped her to his breast,</l>
.<l n="c">And climbed into his chariot, holding her so tightly in his embrace, that, in her terror, she was powerless to resist.</l>
5965<l n="d">With that he carried her off, speeding quickly away.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">Thereupon the Yadus were filled with dejection, </l>
.<l n="b">All sadly oppressed, that he was not intimidated.</l>
.<l n="c">Despondently reflecting on their uselessness,</l>
5970<l n="d">For so contemptible were they that they had just stayed their hand and allowed him to go.</l>
.</p>
.</div>
.<div type="canto" n="43">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">We will not tell of Arjuna but of the Wṛṣṇis who fled</l>
5975<l n="b">To bow down* before Lord Haladhara and give news of Pārtha’s deed.</l>
.<l n="c">The king was then so filled with boiling, righteous rage, </l>
.<l n="d">That sparks seem to fly from the reflected glare of his livid face.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">At once, in the heat of his blazing anger, he roared loudly:</l>
5980<l n="b">‘Shame upon you, O wicked, vile Pārtha! Believe that I will see that you are destroyed and swept away!’</l>
.<l n="c">Thus said the king rising to his feet and seizing his great and powerful weapons,*</l>
.<l n="d">Looking more and more as if he would destroy the world and overturn the ocean, Rudra’s fire* in visible form.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">All the princes and particularly the kings were equally angry and eager to do battle.</l>
5985<l n="b">Moreover, all were very fierce and in their frenzy stood upright, like lions filled with fighting spirit.</l>
.<l n="c">Pradyumna and Gadā, Satyaka, Niśaṭha and Sāmba, vehement and savage.</l>
.<l n="d">All possessed of tremendous great power, thorns in the side of any lion-like warrior were they.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">And the Wṛṣṇis, their valiant allies, were all celebrated for their skill,</l>
5990<l n="b">They too were indomitable champions, victorious in battle, skilful, resolute and famed.</l>
.<l n="c">How could either advancing demon or monster not be pulverised?</l>
.<l n="d">Such was the extent of their uncontrolled anger that they ground their teeth with pent-up rage, and shouted out noisily to each other.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">It seemed that Mount Raiwata[ka] would surely be destroyed: the small animals were thrown into great commotion by the blaring of war trumpets,</l>
5995<l n="b">The thundering of the kettle-drums and the crashing of cymbals* all sounding out together.</l>
.<l n="c">Elephants trumpeted, horses neighed, shouts rang out,</l>
.<l n="d">A kaleidoscope of multi-coloured standards rose on high, a dense mass of weapons glinting everywhere.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">The hosts of warriors, with their entire forces, were fully equipped, all perfect in form.</l>
6000<l n="b">Valour lapped at their full hearts* like the ocean at the incoming tide.</l>
.<l n="c">After being ordered into their respective divisions, they stood in formation to march out against Pārtha with all their might, </l>
.<l n="d">All equally impatient, voraciously wishing to prove how eager and unafraid they were.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">Brimful with ferocity, the Yadus were fearful to behold, all shouting loudly,</l>
6005<l n="b">With but a single thought: to hunt Pārtha down, leaving no stone unturned, and kill him.</l>
.<l n="c">They took up their many bows and weapons in readiness,</l>
.<l n="d">As frenzied as the Lord of Death in their great haste to attack furiously.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">With Haladhara’s departure, these heroes set out with a great roar. The troops advanced</l>
6010<l n="b">In serried ranks, in thundering, unbroken succession, as they tried to outpace each other,</l>
.<l n="c">But as they came upon Lord Kṛṣṇa, who was quite unperturbed, they came to a halt,</l>
.<l n="d">Lord Haladhara choking to see his brother, the king, like that.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">He stepped forward quickly towards Lord Kṛṣṇa saying:</l>
6015<l n="b">‘O my brother! Fie! Do you mean to do nothing about Pārtha’s evil conduct!</l>
.<l n="c">We can no longer regard him as a brother! It is not to be contemplated!</l>
.<l n="d">In vain we have treated him with honour and entertained him regally.*</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">‘Indeed, I perceive his insult as so extreme that I am roused to anger by it.</l>
6020<l n="b">In truth, he is despicable! How can he act in such an evil, hostile, vile manner?</l>
.<l n="c">Truly he knows not the meaning of respect as set down in the Law. He shows us nothing but scorn in abducting our sister.*</l>
.<l n="d">Blind to proper conduct, treacherous, his insolence goes too far, he has insulted us beyond measure.’*</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">Thus he said harshly and Lord Kṛṣṇa answered him:</l>
6025<l n="b">‘O King such vehement talk avails you nothing!</l>
.<l n="c">You are a hero,* a world-protector, your victories are worthy of praise that resounds throughout the three worlds.</l>
.<l n="d">The depth of your power is truly an ocean, renowned for its great depths.</l>
.</p>
.</div>
6030<div type="canto" n="44">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">‘Here is the highest truth to which you should adhere.</l>
.<l n="b">It is proper that a learned man of the world be accomplished in virtue.</l>
.<l n="c">He should not half-heartedly seek discernment,</l>
.<l n="d">So that he may have mastery over both subtle and obvious* truth.</l>
6035</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">‘You must always consider the existence of enemies and friends,</l>
.<l n="b">Who are both seen and unseen. </l>
.<l n="c">It is their nature to oppose* good</l>
.<l n="d">And therefore well-being is generated.</l>
6040</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">‘You are the irreproachable ruler of the world.</l>
.<l n="b">Never do you show the least lack of discretion.</l>
.<l n="c">Like a fire blazing fierce and bright,</l>
.<l n="d">You are ever ready to vanquish any stain.</l>
6045</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">‘You are as inviolable as the water of life,</l>
.<l n="b">Sweeping before it the activities of the impure mind.</l>
.<l n="c">Living rightfully, observing right conduct, pure in body,</l>
.<l n="d">You are the authority* of all law.</l>
6050</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">‘This is why I urge you to be calm.</l>
.<l n="b">Only the despicable treat their king with contempt.</l>
.<l n="c">You say Dhanañjaya has insulted you,</l>
.<l n="d">But, on the contrary, I believe he has shown us the greatest honour.</l>
6055</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">‘Consider this O king! Is it proper for a virtuous man to think</l>
.<l n="b">That a wife should be bought for valuables -</l>
.<l n="c">For jewels, precious stones, gold and so on?</l>
.<l n="d">To do so would be to consider her no better than cattle, a base and miserable thought.</l>
6060</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">‘Where in this world would you find an honourable man who would deliberately seek</l>
.<l n="b">To sell his marriageable daughter willingly?</l>
.<l n="c">For this reason the <foreign>swayambara</foreign>, or bride’s choice is approved.</l>
.<l n="d">If a man does not attend to this, he neglects his duty to the world.</l>
6065</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">‘But see, we have not yet performed</l>
.<l n="b">This ceremony that accords with the highest <foreign>dharma</foreign>.</l>
.<l n="c">And this is the reason for Dhanañjaya’s conduct.</l>
.<l n="d">This abduction is not wrong but most excellent.</l>
6070</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">‘For he has obviously relied on his valorous might,</l>
.<l n="b">And displayed his irresistible presence.</l>
.<l n="c">He has been able to abduct Subhadrā</l>
.<l n="d">With such confidence by virtue of his prowess.</l>
6075</p>
.</div>
.<div type="canto" n="45">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">‘Your Majesty, in my opinion, to use force against him would be wrong and to no avail,</l>
.<l n="b">For we have already clearly seen how he gained the victory at a <foreign>swayambara</foreign> in the past.</l>
6080<l n="c">Even so, if put to the test, there is every chance he would prevail,</l>
.<l n="d">For there is not a man* powerful enough to challenge his powers, not even Surapati.*</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">‘Your glory as a world conqueror is already renowned.</l>
.<l n="b">If he defeated you in battle you would be put to shame.</l>
6085<l n="c">In short, I must insist that the best course would be not to become enraged.</l>
.<l n="d">You should only adhere to meritorious conduct, for such is the sole aim of a ruler who cares for the welfare of others.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">‘Now here is a course of action that may bring you a felicitous result, Your Majesty.</l>
.<l n="b">Do not hesitate* to send an envoy to invite Dhanañjaya here now, quickly,</l>
6090<l n="c">Thereafter* to be married with all appropriate ceremonies. Do not fail to exert yourself in this,</l>
.<l n="d">So that you may benefit from an alliance with all the Pāṇḍawas through such close family ties.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">‘My* heart is true and has never been otherwise.</l>
.<l n="b">These were the reasons I may have seemed indifferent and unmoved, to have paid no mind and to have taken no action.’</l>
6095<l n="c">Thus said Kṛṣṇa and the Yadus acquiesced,</l>
.<l n="d">Their burning fury extinguished like fire as the life-giving water of the king’s words showered down upon them.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">Because of Kṛṣṇa’s intervention, Lord Baladewa now became calm.</l>
.<l n="b">And so they halted and finally lay down all their arrows and weapons,</l>
6100<l n="c">Immediately preparing to invite the prince to come,</l>
.<l n="d">With the delightful sound of the merry <foreign>gĕṇḍings</foreign> heralding their departure.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">Amidst great splendour, the princes set out with their followers,</l>
.<l n="b">The noble widows* in particular competing to fill the chariots and elephants.</l>
6105<l n="c">The tramp of the many feet of that vast procession made a violent and tumultuous noise like a waterfall.*</l>
.<l n="d">In their fine adornments this entourage was indeed like a forest of trees in blossom, as they delightfully walked along.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">The many colourful banners side by side were a delight to behold,</l>
.<l n="b">A resplendent rainbow arching down into budding flowers.</l>
6110<l n="c">Like mighty rock formations* were the lines of chariots, elephants and horses.</l>
.<l n="d">The spaces between those walking along were deep ravines, and so crowded together were they, that progress became increasingly difficult.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">We will not tell of them on their journey, but will tell of Prince Pārtha.</l>
.<l n="b">He travelled slowly, embracing the beautiful princess in her unceasing despair.</l>
6115<l n="c">As she called more and more loudly upon all the Yadus.</l>
.<l n="d">It seemed she would die, as she sighed plaintively on his lap, swooning, completely overwhelmed.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">She became distraught at the sweetness of his endearments:</l>
.<l n="b">‘My jewel, my darling! Resign yourself. How could you go back now?</l>
6120<l n="c">What a pity it is that now I hold you in the palm of my hand, you think constantly of escaping!</l>
.<l n="d">Let your mind be easy, my dear. It is the fruits of our former existence that we now reap, as I carry you off.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">‘Clearly now I have found you, my precious jewel, dearest maiden,</l>
.<l n="b">It is proper that your charms be the provisions for my journey as I seek the courage to perform deeds of valour.</l>
6125<l n="c">I am resolved if beset by enemies to show no fear:</l>
.<l n="d">Indeed I am determined to meet in battle any who might come.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">‘Regard the strength of my arms as the bride-price I must pay for you.</l>
.<l n="b">In truth, you will be the witness to my heroic deeds, my dear.’</l>
6130<l n="c">Thus said Pārtha with affection, addressing her with words of endearment, </l>
.<l n="d">But the intensity of her tears only increased as she warded him off, moaning piteously. </l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="12"><l n="a">Thus, he tried in so many ways to console* the confused and suffering girl.</l>
.<l n="b">The Yadu hosts who had been sent to invite him to return, then came upon them,</l>
6135<l n="c">Bringing with them all the ritual gifts that could be desired of such a meeting.</l>
.<l n="d">All were presented for the prince’s delight as they came forward to pay homage to him.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="13"><l n="a">‘My friend, His Majesty, the King asks that you return to him,</l>
.<l n="b">The lady, too, should accompany you. Come back together now to the palace.</l>
6140<l n="c">For His Majesty is truly pleased to invite you there.</l>
.<l n="d">His nature* is as sweet as the sugar palm entwined by the <foreign>gaḍung</foreign>.’</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="14"><l n="a">Thus said all the princes, delighting Arjuna.</l>
.<l n="b">Soon after, as the sun went down, they were escorted home.</l>
6145<l n="c">Riding in a black palanquin* closely surrounded by the throngs, they were as magnificent</l>
.<l n="d">As the incomparable Śiwa and his consort descended to earth.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="15"><l n="a">Lord Kṛṣṇa and Haladhara were in the court-yard,</l>
.<l n="b">Together with the royal consorts, all of equal beauty, awaiting them as they drew near.</l>
6150<l n="c">In the glow of the many torches, it was as bright as day.</l>
.<l n="d">The whispering music of bamboo xylophones echoed, as if to proclaim the happiness of the whole kingdom.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="16"><l n="a">With his princess by his side, Dhanañjaya came forward</l>
.<l n="b">And bowed low at the feet of both kings gathered there.</l>
6155<l n="c">At this, King Baladewa’s displeasure ceased, as he joyously received them warmly. </l>
.<l n="d">Thus Kṛṣṇa’s noble teaching was brought to perfect fruition.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="17"><l n="a">After that, the kings dispatched a messenger to return to the palace compound,</l>
.<l n="b">There, at the feet of King Basudewa,* to tell of the course of events.</l>
6160<l n="c">We will not tell of his journey but again tell of Phalguṇa,</l>
.<l n="d">Joining in celebration with the Yadu tribe in their camp.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="18"><l n="a">In full measure, they regaled the prince in every way possible.</l>
.<l n="b">Many kinds of delicious food and drinks had been prepared and were set before him.</l>
6165<l n="c">The friendship of King Harimūrti as well was undiminished,</l>
.<l n="d">For it was his nature to act rightfully* and he was always dear to all.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="19"><l n="a">We will not tell of the time spent entertaining Pārtha.</l>
.<l n="b">Night came and soon the whole kingdom slept.</l>
6170<l n="c">As night ended and day came, all arose</l>
.<l n="d">And the kings went home, accompanied by the entire Yadu tribe.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="20"><l n="a">The noble Pārtha and the princess were escorted</l>
.<l n="b">There to Dwārawatī, where they were indeed* received kindly by His Majesty the King.</l>
6175<l n="c">So it was that the joining of hands, religious observances, prayers and wedding ceremonies could then be performed,</l>
.<l n="d">In accordance with the wishes expressed by Lord Kṛṣṇa.</l>
.</p>
.</div>
.<div type="canto" n="46">
6180<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">Many spectators came to welcome the arrival of the Yadus to the city,</l>
.<l n="b">All wanting to catch their first glimpse of this excellent prince of whom they had heard.</l>
.<l n="c">Because they had never seen him before, they had come immediately, running outside in great haste.</l>
.<l n="d">Young and old, even widows waited, some so decrepit with age they were bent over, but who, nevertheless, wanted to go too.</l>
.</p>
6185<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">In a flurry, they came running quickly there. Some shouted out aloud in their desire to be first,</l>
.<l n="b">Pushing against each other, bumping together, others racing neck and neck, called out noisily to those who had not come to the great square.</l>
.<l n="c">Heedless of their ornaments, many fought to be the first to catch sight of the prince,</l>
.<l n="d">Others who had been adjusting their <foreign>kains</foreign> ran out, so anxious to fly there without delay, that they were left half-dressed.</l>
.</p>
6190<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">Let us pass over the arrival of Dhanañjaya. The kings made their way towards the inner apartments.</l>
.<l n="b">There, according to rank, they prostrated themselves at the feet of King Basudewa and his queen,</l>
.<l n="c">Who swiftly and kindly accepted Dhanañjaya, for not only was he handsome but he was also a powerful hero, possessed of virtue and skill,</l>
.<l n="d">Moreover, a fitting partner for the princess, for he was none other than her close relative.</l>
.</p>
6195<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">The King spoke thus, ‘Oh my son, Pārtha, hear what I have to say to you.</l>
.<l n="b">Truly, just as Harimūrti and Karṣana,* you too are my refuge.</l>
.<l n="c">May it bring us prosperity, my son, to be united with you and to be of one purpose, without discord.*</l>
.<l n="d">For we are the branches of one family. Do not forget that you too can be said to be of my own seed.’*</l>
.</p>
6200<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">The words of the king were sincere and, like ambrosia, brought contentment to those who heard them.</l>
.<l n="b">Moreover, they were truly worthy sentiments, for he was an ancient and wise king, versed in the esoteric doctrines and practices of the welfare of others.</l>
.<l n="c">The prince thus addressed with words of honour, made an obeisance to acknowledge the felicity of the king’s words,</l>
.<l n="d">Bringing great pleasure to the depths of the hearts of the hosts of soldiers who listened with delight to this praise.</l>
.</p>
6205</div>
.<div type="canto" n="47">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">After they had discoursed thus, the most eminent officials were appointed</l>
.<l n="b">To arrange all that was needed for the performance of the <foreign>piḍuḍukan</foreign> ceremonies* and wedding offerings,</l>
.<l n="c">Because the most auspicious time for the princess to be united in marriage with Dhanañjaya</l>
6210<l n="d">Was the following day, and it was then that they would receive the king’s blessing.*</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">So* the entire Yadu tribe assembled there in complete formation and stood ready in the hall.</l>
.<l n="b">The rank and file from throughout the land were there, drawn up in their various divisions, </l>
.<l n="c">Ready to attend quickly to the king’s instructions,</l>
6215<l n="d">All firmly resolved to carry them out according to the prescriptions so that its splendour should be without flaw.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">And so all was arranged appropriately: the many offerings stood ready,</l>
.<l n="b">Brought into being by the power of the king who was the supreme and excellent Wiṣṇu.</l>
.<l n="c">Moreover, the buildings both inside and outside the palace,</l>
6220<l n="d">Were restored to their original perfect state, all richly and lavishly decorated.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">The open hall, beautifully roofed with a canopy of lovely jewels, sparkled.</l>
.<l n="b">Of equal splendour were the pillars carved with different designs.</l>
.<l n="c">Moreover, the bamboo leaves that glittered along the gleaming fences </l>
6225<l n="d">Were painted with plant motifs* that looked like masked figures.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">Even the ridges of the roof were exquisite, inlaid with patterns of precious stones.</l>
.<l n="b">The galleries along the sides, surrounded by screens, were shaped like the fins of fishes.*</l>
.<l n="c">Gleaming,* golden <foreign>jangga</foreign> vines* trailed delicately over the panels.</l>
6230<l n="d">Set with rubies, the <foreign>cawĕni</foreign> muslin had embroidered leaf-designs of shining embroidered silk.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">The land now reverberated like the crashing ocean,</l>
.<l n="b">As the music of the <foreign>mṛdangga</foreign> and <foreign>paḍahi</foreign> royal drums thundered out in unison,</l>
.<l n="c">And the great celebrations and feasting that the Yadus held</l>
6235<l n="d">Were now directed towards the preparations for the marriage celebration* of the noble Phalguṇa.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">Ugrasena had arrived in the court-yard together with the other kings,</l>
.<l n="b">Prominent amongst them was Harimūrti, their leader, and Halāyudha.</l>
.<l n="c">As Prince Pārtha was regaled magnificently in the hall,</l>
6240<l n="d">All thought he surpassed even Surapati in splendour.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">There was a beautiful bower of love, of unrivalled magnificence,</l>
.<l n="b">A creation of the God of Love himself, a building of diamonds, beautifully arranged for the pleasure of passionate lovers.</l>
.<l n="c">Its roof was set with glittering, blue <foreign>śaśarudhira</foreign> gems and an orb of sparkling rubies.</l>
6245<l n="d">Its embroidered canopy was shaped like the moon and embroidered with* <foreign>cucur</foreign> birds.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">There was a balcony on the high ledge of the front verandah* of this pavilion.</l>
.<l n="b">All the beauty of the Tāladhwaja* garden unfolding in the fourth month, had assembled there.</l>
.<l n="c">Spread out were <foreign>kalpataru</foreign> flowers,* prepared as ornaments for the bower.</l>
6250<l n="d">The fragrance of burning incense inspired pangs of love as it diffused its delightful fragrance without cease.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">Inside the princess was being attended*..............</l></p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">.......The religious rites had been performed and all was set ready</l>
.<l n="b">For the reverential salutations, auspicious ceremonies and acts of worship in the presence of the kings.</l></p>
6255<p rend="stanza" n="12"><l n="a">Many glorious prayers of offering were recited there.</l>
.<l n="b">The music of the <foreign>paḍahi</foreign> drums for their entertainment and the singing too, were delightful.</l>
.<l n="c">As night fell, this most excellent scene was suddenly bedecked in new raiment,</l>
.<l n="d">From the bright glow of lighted lamps, like an assembly of suns.</l></p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="13"><l n="a">We will not tell of this. After the completion of the wedding* ceremony, the bridal couple</l>
6260<l n="b">Came back and moved to their palanquin, like flower buds inundated by rain.</l>
.<l n="c">To the accompaniment of the lovely <foreign>gamĕlan</foreign>, sweet and soft, they set off.</l>
.<l n="d">The tramp of the people escorting them sounding like the rumbling thunder that always accompanies the month of spring.</l>
.</p>
.</div>
6265<div type="canto" n="48">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">They went up into the sapphire bower where they were to join* in sexual union.</l>
.<l n="b">How enchanting was its beauty, its covers perfumed with the seven fragrances* and scented with fragrant saffron.</l>
.<l n="c">The aroma of camphor and the perfume of the <foreign>jĕnu</foreign> were a call to love-making</l>
.<l n="d">Clearly awakening longing in the hearts of questing* lovers and bringing them pangs of love.</l>
6270</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">Within there, Pārtha, enraptured, held the princess on his lap.</l>
.<l n="b">Moreover, the whispered urgings of the God of Love aroused him and filled his being with desire.</l>
.<l n="c">He was overcome with the confusion of unrequited love and was forced to hide his feelings, as the wedding attendants* returned to the bed-chamber,</l>
.<l n="d">While his desire unfurled little by little, like the shoots of the <foreign>gaḍung</foreign> vine reaching towards the light of the moon.</l>
6275</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">The princess, goddess of love, in her confusion and distress, turned away, uneasily sighing as he tried to woo* her.</l>
.<l n="b">Sudden tears filled her eyes and, as they fell, seemed to turn to liquid honey.</l>
.<l n="c">Her arching brows drew together in a frown as the prince embraced her,</l>
.<l n="d">Her desperate heart crushed as he held her on his lap, sad and fearful as he tried to reassure her.</l>
6280</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">The prince, dejected by this, pondered deeply on how to win her affection.</l>
.<l n="b">Perplexed and agitated by his love, he passionately embraced her slender waist.</l>
