.<l n="c">Because of his joy, he felt impelled to listen* only to his heart, the seat of his strong desire,</l>
.<l n="d">With a constant flood of sweet endearments and caresses which might woo her to the delights of love:</l>
6285</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">‘My darling, you have ever been the deity of my meditation [enthroned] in my love-sick heart. You are the Goddess of Love, Ratih, in human form.</l>
.<l n="b">You are the invisible essence which arises from the immaterial state of the depths of feeling of one who longs to know the secrets of the raptures of love.*</l>
.<l n="c">You are the embodiment of honey, the goddess of flowers, the splendour of <foreign>asana </foreign>blossoms, the jewel of maidenhood,</l>
.<l n="d">The beauty of the fourth month, a bejewelled statue transformed into a girl.</l>
6290</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">‘So little sister, it seems that I have reached my goal now that I hold you on my lap and draw near to you.</l>
.<l n="b">You are the one I have longed for constantly and the reason I have sought to come to you now, to take you upon my knee.</l>
.<l n="c">You are the very jewel of my heart, wherein is set the innermost kernel of my devotion to love.</l>
.<l n="d">To achieve my purpose, I have risked all, that I might be one with you and succeed in enjoying your favour.</l>
6295</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">‘But now I* am in despair, how can you repay me with but a glance, while I suffer under my unyielding desire?</l>
.<l n="b">See how my heart breaks as I hold back my love, though you could set me free with words of love.</l>
.<l n="c">Clearly, my life must cease, for you have mortally wounded me, O jewel of the palace.</l>
.<l n="d">Indeed, I have treasured the praise* of your charms in my dreams, but I grow weary at encountering only sullenness.’*</l>
6300</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">Thus, the prince cajoled her with words sweet enough to drive away the princess’s reluctance,</l>
.<l n="b">Like a frenzied bee whispering softly to a profusion of fragrant <foreign>asana</foreign> flowers that have not yet opened.</l>
.<l n="c">Seeking to obtain happiness with soft words while inhaling her perfume, embracing her tightly,</l>
.<l n="d">Full of passion but gentle, he bent his intent gaze on her, determined to seize her waist.</l>
6305</p>
.</div>
.<div type="canto" n="49">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">But the princess turned away from the prince’s sweet words of comfort,</l>
.<l n="b">Taking no pleasure in the charm of his words as he caressed her.</l>
6310<l n="c">Full of doubt, she moved away as he whispered to her, and wept as he kissed her,</l>
.<l n="d">Drawing her <foreign>tapih</foreign> tightly around her huddled body, afraid that he would suddenly seize upon the opening of her <foreign>kain</foreign>, that he eyed so intently.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">Her angry glance, so beautiful it melted his heart, devastated her lover.</l>
.<l n="b">The frowning arch of her eyebrows wounded him and the prince, wanting only to caress her, was saddened.</l>
6315<l n="c">Her efforts to resist him were like those of the shoots of the <foreign>aśoka</foreign> battling against the wind.</l>
.<l n="d">Her movements were those of a lotus addressed with endearing names by a frenzied bee.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">The prince’s heart was intoxicated, flooded with sweet delight at the princess’s beauty.</l>
.<l n="b">Ever more passionately he caressed her, softly stroking her, though she remained indifferent.</l>
6320<l n="c">His hands crept towards her waist, aiming for her waist band,</l>
.<l n="d">And he began, once again, to assail her with sweet sound, a deluge of loving words:</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">‘My darling, you are the jewel of beauty who confuses my love-lorn heart.</l>
.<l n="b">By your actions, you only enhance your sweetness and pierce me to the core.</l>
6325<l n="c">You constantly wound my loving heart which is ever ready to welcome your words of endearment,</l>
.<l n="d">But, just like the moon, I cannot bring relief to an unopened flower bud, feverish with heat.’</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">‘You are as beautiful as the <foreign>asana</foreign> flowers found in the floral hair band of a hair-knot, so sweet and fragrant.</l>
.<l n="b">Joyfully, I long to awaken your love, but you want to hide your charming perfection.</l>
6330<l n="c">I am a bee, full of love, but weary of fighting off my passion and desire for so long,</l>
.<l n="d">Fearlessly inhaling your scent, happy to die if I already wore the marks of being the first one to taste of [the flowers in] your hair-knot.</l>
.</p>
.</div>
.<div type="canto" n="50">
6335<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">‘Oh how disappointed am I in love and so I will tell of the nature of my wistful longing.</l>
.<l n="b">It is unbearable, though my heart would beat a little faster if addressed with words of love.</l>
.<l n="c">Instead, I am full of ardent longing, because I embrace your waist and restlessly seek your approval,</l>
.<l n="d">In the mistaken belief that you might be touched by passion, when you see the suffering of one who is so filled with desire.</l>
.</p>
6340<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">‘Oh I am overpowered with longing and have lost patience because of the urgings of the God of Love.*</l>
.<l n="b">Thrown into confusion at the slightest touch of your finger tips or shapely calves, bewildered with desire,</l>
.<l n="c">My heart is flooded with desperation, I am rendered powerless by your hair-knot, I ache when your sweet eyes fall on me.</l>
.<l n="d">I know not what to do. What can I say to persuade you to accept my words?’*</l>
.</p>
6345<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">But the princess’s thoughts were sad,* as the prince continually honoured her again with words.</l>
.<l n="b">‘My darling wife, accept my care as I cradle you on my lap and hope to make love to you.</l>
.<l n="c">If you must deny me access to your smile, then scratch me instead with your sharp nails.</l>
.<l n="d">I would rather die. What is death by comparison to the dangers faced in seeking refuge in the realm of love?</l>
.</p>
6350<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">‘In short, behold the state of this lover who presents to you his words of love,</l>
.<l n="b">Hoping always that in your love I might find the place I so tirelessly seek, where I can lay down my sorrow and passion.</l>
.<l n="c">I will stop without ever reaching my goal of having you as my support, O jewel amongst maidens,</l>
.<l n="d">And it would be preferable for me to slink away in shame if you will not receive me kindly.’</l>
.</p>
6355</div>
.<div type="canto" n="51">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">Thus said the prince. The princess moaned dejectedly,</l>
.<l n="b">Powerless to resist the prince any longer, unable to ward off his persuasive words.</l>
.<l n="c">The broken points of her nails were of no use and so, her efforts to resist him were easily defeated and brushed aside,</l>
6360<l n="d">And the prince persisted in his efforts to kiss her more and more passionately.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">The princess was so confused, her resistance so ineffectual, her heart so anxious as she sighed,</l>
.<l n="b">That it truly seemed her tears should have deterred the prince.</l>
.<l n="c">But it was too much, she could no longer think of striking him, defeated, tired beyond measure,</l>
6365<l n="d">As the prince continued to shower her with words as sweet as the ocean of honey:</l>
.</p>
.</div>
.<div type="canto" n="52">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">‘Dear maiden, heart’s desire, give me the gift of your glance. Do not be cross or avert your gaze. Look at me!</l>
6370<l n="b">What a pity it is, my beloved, that in your anger, you do not care if I am suffering with desire or beset by pangs of love.</l>
.<l n="c">Oh, do not weep, do not moan or be dejected, how can I continue to serve you, if you will not speak? </l>
.<l n="d">In short, how can you disappoint me so in my quest to obtain your support* to help me draw near to you?</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">‘It would be better if you would but bestow your sweetness on me, so that I might match it with my steadfast* love.</l>
6375<l n="b">For your whimpering is in vain and only makes you weary and distresses you. How can it possibly be right?</l>
.<l n="c">Indeed, you only strike my breast and threaten me with your terrible nails and conceal the redness of your teeth.</l>
.<l n="d">Certainly, my dear, if you would but accept my approaches, I would find the proper way* to worship you.’</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">Thus, Arjuna’s love became words of such sweetness that they would vanquish liquid sugar,</l>
6380<l n="b">His heart compelled him to restrain his longing no more, though she cried out, continually pushing him away.</l>
.<l n="c">But the princess was too exhausted, deprived of all strength and her tears were to no avail as she fought him off.</l>
.<l n="d">She did not know what to do as the prince, approaching her from the side,* took her forcibly.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">In short, though the princess resisted him, she was powerless, distraught, as he took her by surprise,</l>
6385<l n="b">Undoing her clothing, releasing her fragrance as her beautiful <foreign>kris</foreign>-shaped waist was laid bare,</l>
.<l n="c">So that Dhanañjaya became even more exhilarated at this foretaste of the love-making to come,</l>
.<l n="d">Just as the bee, catching the first glimpse of the beauty of an <foreign>asana</foreign>, is suddenly driven to sip its honey.</l>
.</p>
.</div>
6390<div type="canto" n="53">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">After he had deflowered her, that most excellent of maidens was exhausted and weak.</l>
.<l n="b">The prince, desire unabated, cradled her, his heart full* of deep yearning.</l>
.<l n="c">The beautiful girl was the embodiment of the splendour of a wilted lotus,</l>
.<l n="d">But because she was so painfully affected as she sank down, he whispered sweet words to her.</l>
6395</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">The prince was even more disturbed by the princess,</l>
.<l n="b">As in the light of the lamps,* she seemed even more wan and pale.</l>
.<l n="c">Now, so exhausted was she that she lay there as still as a statue of gold,</l>
.<l n="d">As the prince gently embraced her, cradling her on his lap and rearranging her robe.</l>
6400</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">But the woebegone princess dejectedly slipped away from him.</l>
.<l n="b">She was aghast at the blood glistening on her dress.</l>
.<l n="c">So her adoring lover, not wanting to leave her side, carried her out</l>
.<l n="d">To the outer verandah, going to find attendants to bathe her.</l>
6405</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">Her maids were waiting, close at hand, with everything all prepared</l>
.<l n="b">And laid out in position for bathing her. All were skilled in understanding subtleties and giving guidance,</l>
.<l n="c">All versed in soothing and bestowing great care on her.</l>
.<l n="d">We will not tell of the goddess as she was bathed there beside her lover.</l>
6410</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">After they had both been bathed, the girl who had now just experienced the intimacy of marriage,</l>
.<l n="b">Was petted and watched over* by her loving maid:</l>
.<l n="c">‘Dear lady, resign yourself to bear a little pain,</l>
.<l n="d">For your sorrow will soon turn to desire, my dear.</l>
6415</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">‘The flowers of the fragrant lotus, jasmine and <foreign>nāgapuṣpa</foreign></l>
.<l n="b">Are nothing less than a sign* that it is appropriate</l>
.<l n="c">For passionate bees to buzz around* them and ravish them.</l>
.<l n="d">No mistress, I believe that being married is similar.</l>
6420</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">‘Little one, you should return quickly to the pavilion. Oh, do go back my dear.</l>
.<l n="b">The one who yearns for you is held in thrall, and eagerly awaits you.’</l>
.<l n="c">And she urged her so insistently that the princess was ashamed</l>
.<l n="d">And mounted slowly back into the fragrant bridal chamber.</l>
6425</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">On her return, the princess huddled in the farthest corner of the beautiful chamber.</l>
.<l n="b">The prince, with mounting joy, took her onto his lap,</l>
.<l n="c">Caressing her and looking closely at her pale, drawn face,</l>
.<l n="d">Then kissed her passionately, his sweet words falling like rain drops:</l>
6430</p>
.</div>
.<div type="canto" n="54">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">‘You are the very relative of the moon, you are the rumbling of the thunder of desire, the gentle rain of the raptures of love.</l>
.<l n="b">You bring me constant heartache, so that I burgeon with passion, and my love puts forth new shoots.</l>
6435<l n="c">Moreover,* as I embrace your charms, suddenly offering me flowers of desire,*</l>
.<l n="d">My joy knows no limit in being intertwined with you in the reality of sexual union.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">‘Now see, beloved, how fortunate I am to be your partner and share love with you.</l>
.<l n="b">You, my lady, signify the end of my earthly existence. You are the provisions I will carry to the next world as I lie next to you in repose.</l>
6440<l n="c">Indeed, in the hidden depths of your eyes, transfixed, I let myself be carried away on the tide of my yearning,</l>
.<l n="d">And I, your humble slave, will die willing, by casting myself* into the sea of honey to be as one with your sweetness.’</l>
.</p>
.</div>
.<div type="canto" n="55">
6445<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">In this way, he calmed the princess as he sought to comfort her.</l>
.<l n="b">Enchantingly, he cradled her head in his lap, giving her delicious betel-leaf, eagerly kissing her lips,</l>
.<l n="c">Brushing back her hair, skillfully bestowing great care on her,</l>
.<l n="d">Holding her hand, never wearying of resting his eyes on the fullness of her breasts.</l>
.</p>
6450<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">All the while, softly, tremulously, he murmured love poems, wave upon wave of sweet sentiments,</l>
.<l n="b">Alternating with the pleasure of passionately kissing her beautiful cheek. </l>
.<l n="c">With the sweetest expressions of love, he began all over again* to address her fondly,</l>
.<l n="d">Disturbing the newly blossoming areca flower, filling her with the constant sound.</l>
.</p>
6455<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">The union of the prince and most excellent princess, there on the bridal couch,</l>
.<l n="b">Could be likened to that of the <foreign>mangunĕng</foreign> and jasmine or the <foreign>katirah</foreign> touching the <foreign>wĕlas-harĕp</foreign> creeper,</l>
.<l n="c">As beautiful as the charming <foreign>gaḍung</foreign> entwining and merging with the <foreign>wanañjari.</foreign>*</l>
.<l n="d">Such was their union, as they shared together in the raptures of love.</l>
.</p>
6460<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">The delighted prince abandoned himself to the pursuit of erotic pleasure, there on the couch,</l>
.<l n="b">All night long, unable to sleep, so often did he caress the princess.</l>
.<l n="c">His words of love could be heard by the women hidden behind the curtains spying on them, and their sighs,</l>
.<l n="d">And the constant tinkling of their anklets, told of their penetration into the secrets of sexual intercourse.</l>
.</p>
6465</div>
.<div type="canto" n="56">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">The night passed and as day came, the bright light of the sun shone down.</l>
.<l n="b">When it was time for the <foreign>kraban</foreign> ceremonies and everything was ready,</l>
.<l n="c">Everything was so wondrous and incomparable that it seemed to have come from Indra’s heaven,</l>
6470<l n="d">For it was King Harimūrti who had ordered them to be prepared and had seen to their arrangement.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">The exquisite seven fragrances,* deer-navel musk and sandalwood spread over all,</l>
.<l n="b">Bringing enchantment to the girl who had for the first time known a man there on the couch.</l>
.<l n="c">Incense glowed, its vapour seemed to waft* there to enhance the delight,</l>
6475<l n="d">Seeking out the radiance of the <foreign>cawĕli</foreign> silk of the curtains, always so fragrant.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">The delightful melodies of <foreign>kidung,</foreign> accompanied on the lute, began to play,</l>
.<l n="b">Sounding so much like bees that everyone thought it was spring.</l>
.<l n="c">Then as these constant offerings seemed to increase in splendour, their thoughts turned again to love,</l>
6480<l n="d">An experience so wondrous that it laid to rest her fear of love-making.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">In full view, the two went out and sat side-by-side on the verandah.</l>
.<l n="b">After they had bathed and put on their jewels and ornaments,</l>
.<l n="c">They looked as sweet as the conjoined beauty of the lotus and honey,</l>
6485<l n="d">Bearing with fortitude* the presence of the maids, all of whom were beautiful and were wearing many <foreign>maṇḍaga</foreign>* ornaments.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">Finally a gentle elderly lady* from the palace charged with* their care,</l>
.<l n="b">Who was learned* in interpreting auspicious signs, summoned them to come forth.</l>
.<l n="c">And so the two then stood up and came out to the audience hall,</l>
6490<l n="d">Where the Yadu tribe was being sumptuously entertained as they feasted outside.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">To tell of all that took place would take too long. As day departed,</l>
.<l n="b">The bridal pair moved away together to the beautiful pavilion where they would spend the night.</l>
.<l n="c">People thought of them as the beautiful <foreign>asana</foreign> flower and the bee,</l>
6495<l n="d">As the two lovers devoted themselves to each other with caresses, shared comforts and sweet whisperings.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">The princess’s apprehension then ceased as her love unfolded</l>
.<l n="b">Because the sweet prince completely won over her downcast heart.</l>
.<l n="c">Like the deep joy of ivory bamboo when it comes into contact with the rain from the clouds,</l>
6500<l n="d">Desire pierced her, filling her to the core, as she became one with the prince.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">It was the same for the prince, as he sought release from passion in their sexual union,</l>
.<l n="b">A devotee of loving, that reached perfection there on the couch.</l>
.<l n="c">His languid sidelong glance was the box of sacrifical unguent he placed on her firm breasts*</l>
6505<l n="d">And his caresses were the acts of worship arising from his invocation of the presence of the god in their sexual union.*</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">Later, they ate the delicious food that lay ready.</l>
.<l n="b">The food, drink and delicacies were quite perfect.</l>
.<l n="c">Any wonderful gift, anything at all that they desired, was there</l>
6510<l n="d">Because of Kṛṣṇa, the paramount, heroic king, who was the embodiment on earth of the incarnation of the eight kingly virtues.</l>
.</p>
.</div>
.<div type="canto" n="57">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">And so it was that their union was a thing of joy.</l>
6515<l n="b">Never wearying of each other, one in spirit were they in the interchange of love and passion.</l>
.<l n="c">Many months went by. Their every action was in harmony,</l>
.<l n="d">Their happiness grew with the burgeoning of their great love.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">We will pass over the description of their marriage.</l>
6520<l n="b">The twelfth year of exile came and went.</l>
.<l n="c">Phalguṇa’s mind then turned to thoughts</l>
.<l n="d">Of those he had left behind.* How could he now abandon them?</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">It is in the nature of existence that the pain of separation cannot prevail.*</l>
6525<l n="b">Great longing then subtly takes up residence in the heart</l>
.<l n="c">So that sorrow and loss of peace of mind take possession of it,</l>
.<l n="d">And it may happen that one forgets the gifts of the wheel of existence.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">And so Pārtha’s mind was troubled</l>
6530<l n="b">And he said to his bride:</l>
.<l n="c">‘My darling wife, my little sister, you are indeed my very being.</l>
.<l n="d">O my lady, you purge my longing and put an end to my sorrow.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">‘But now increasingly my own desires defer to</l>
6535<l n="b">My great devotion to my beloved mother* and brothers.</l>
.<l n="c">Because for so long now I have left them abandoned,</l>
.<l n="d">I think only of what has become of them in the palace there.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">‘But my devotion to you, my dear is ever constant.</l>
6540<l n="b">I wish to share your love. Come with me to my own home,</l>
.<l n="c">And stay with me there in Indraprastha. My dear, have no fear.</l>
.<l n="d">Our hearts will find perfect peace in living in accordance with what is right, my darling.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">‘So here is the course we must take, my beloved.</l>
6545<l n="b">It is my duty to pay homage in the dust at the feet of the King </l>
.<l n="c">And your place is to be beside me as my faithful and beloved wife.</l>
.<l n="d">And thus you too may properly carry out the wishes of Yudhisthira, the son of Dharma.’</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">Thus said the prince, lovingly addressing her with kind and gentle words.</l>
6550<l n="b">So the princess gave him answer, her voice faltering:</l>
.<l n="c">‘O my Lord, I know what you say is virtuous and right.</l>
.<l n="d">How could I not follow the proper duty of a wife?</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">‘It is only that I am bewildered, torn in two by how I will suffer and yearn</l>
6555<l n="b">Greatly for my own mother and my lord the king, </l>
.<l n="c">Not forgetting my brothers, who call to me with longing, holding me back.</l>
.<l n="d">I cannot repay their love by bringing them grief.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">‘My devotion to my parents is beyond words</l>
6560<l n="b">Truly it as great as both the mountains, Hima and Sumeru.</l>
.<l n="c">But if I told of my love for you,</l>
.<l n="d">It would truly be wider than the widest ocean.’</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">We will say no more of their conversation</l>
6565<l n="b">After they had agreed to the prince’s resolution.</l>
.<l n="c">That night they slept in mutual delight in the fragrant bed,</l>
.<l n="d">Their hearts absorbed in joining together in desire, swept away by passion.</l>
.</p>
.</div>
6570<div type="canto" n="58">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">The next morning, the prince and his beloved awoke and came out from the bower.</l>
.<l n="b">They went to the water-spouts where they bathed joyfully together.</l>
.<l n="c">When they left the water, they gently stroked each other’s faces, blowing into each other’s eyes,*</l>
.<l n="d">Arranging flowers here and there,* he decorated the princess’s fragrant hair-knot.</l>
6575</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">After adorning themselves fittingly, they came forth hand-in-hand, strolling away together.</l>
.<l n="b">It seemed that Manmatha, the god of the love-couch, was present in his eyes and in his sweet teeth.</l>
.<l n="c">There, on the tiled verandah, they sat together with thighs touching,</l>
.<l n="d">And any who saw the princess sitting on his lap, exchanging chewed betel, thought they were the God and Goddess of Love.</l>
6580</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">‘If I were to die, how delightful it would be if I could return as a bee.</l>
.<l n="b">I could passionately enjoy your charms for ever, if they were in the fragrant <foreign>asana</foreign> flowers in the garden.</l>
.<l n="c">I would know ecstasy even if the <foreign>gaḍing</foreign> repulsed and wounded me or I were struck down by a rain of honey.</l>
.<l n="d">If I died, but bore the signs of my joy at making love to you, I would have reached heaven.’*</l>
6585</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">This was the way Pārtha spoke, his words as sweet as the incarnation of syrup.</l>
.<l n="b">Delighted and full of ardent longing, he entwined the fingers of her hand, then reached out* to encircle her waist.</l>
.<l n="c">Like the <foreign>jangga</foreign> embracing the slender young shoots of the ivory coconut, he softly directed himself to her ear,</l>
.<l n="d">But the goddess turned away sighing again, languishing as the prince caressed her.</l>
6590</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">We will not tell of their love. Finally they came forth, making their way to the inner court.</l>
.<l n="b">There the prince and the most excellent princess entered the presence of king Basudewa who was there with Halāyudha</l>
.<l n="c">And Lord Kṛṣṇa. The lovers both came there,</l>
.<l n="d">And bowed reverently at the king’s feet. He at once received Dhanañjaya benevolently.</l>
6595</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">The prince paid obeisance: ‘I beg you, O King, to hear my request.</l>
.<l n="b">I seek leave to return to my home and therefore, I, your humble servant,* kiss your feet.</l>
.<l n="c">Please do not think that I am ungrateful or indifferent, or that I wish to cast aside your favour</l>
.<l n="d">Or seem to neglect my duty, for indeed, those who would be freed from their bonds face great difficulties.’</l>
6600</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">After Dhanañjaya had begged leave, the king embraced him:</l>
.<l n="b">‘Oh my son, I understand, my boy, that your heart is firm in our cause.</l>
.<l n="c">But if you must go, then I shall divide my kingdom, lands and possessions,</l>
.<l n="d">And all the most excellent things that befit a king throughout our kingdom you will enjoy, now you are close-bound* to us.</l>
6605</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">‘Indeed always be generous, my son, when you see the worthlessness of those who have no protection, show them compassion.</l>
.<l n="b">May you never encounter difficulty, or be neglectful of the teachings, cruel in your affections, or harsh.</l>
.<l n="c">My daughter, apply yourself well, for clearly it is your duty to serve your lord and show him every care,</l>
.<l n="d">And thus you will come to know the love of Kuntī, your Lady Aunt* and elder brothers if you always bear in mind the duties of a younger person.’</l>
6610</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">Thus was his advice, and the prince, who thought it was like the water of life, then bowed* in reverent acknowledgement.</l>
.<l n="b">Lord Kṛṣṇa declared that he would accompany them home, because he loved them so.</l>
.<l n="c">Nor did Baladewa wish to be left behind, he too wanted to go with the prince</l>
.<l n="d">But resolutely the prince denied them, saying that in the future they would certainly visit.</l>
6615</p>
.</div>
.<div type="canto" n="59">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">We will not tell of their deliberation.</l>
.<l n="b">Away sped a messenger carrying the king’s words</l>
6620<l n="c">To Yudhiṣṭhira and his consort,</l>
.<l n="d">Making his way to the kingdom of Indraprastha.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">We will not tell of the departure of the royal messenger</l>
.<l n="b">But again tell of Pārtha.</l>
6625<l n="c">From the court he returned to his quarters,</l>
.<l n="d">Where many members of the Wṛṣṇi family visited him with offers of assistance.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">Their offerings as they came to pay homage were delightful.</l>
.<l n="b">All were weeping, so filled were they with love,</l>
6630<l n="c">Their affectionate natures dominating them and overwhelming them</l>
.<l n="d">With constant thoughts of love for the princess.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">And as for the princess, she too was moved to tears</l>
.<l n="b">And wept bitterly, her heart moved by compassion,</l>
6635<l n="c">Disheartened and saddened now that separation was imminent,</l>
.<l n="d">Not knowing what to think, suddenly beginning to lament.</l>
.</p>
.</div>
.<div type="canto" n="60">
6640<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">The ladies of the court who together were charged with the regulation of affairs* in the inner chamber,</l>
.<l n="b">Were frantically busy, for suddenly, not only did they have to make preparations but also apply themselves to embroidery.*</l>
.<l n="c">But we will not describe those who were to accompany them to Indraprastha, all were impatient to go.</l>
.<l n="d">All through the night came a quiet hum as they threaded strings of ornaments very carefully.*</l>
.</p>
6645</div>
.<div type="canto" n="61">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">We will not tell of this. The next morning, at the appointed time, when the countryside was fresh,</l>
.<l n="b">Pārtha bid farewell and set off with his beloved.</l>
.<l n="c">Together, all watched them climb into their seats in their chariot,</l>
6650<l n="d">As with Dāruki, their charioteer, at the ready, they left in magnificent and splendid style.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">The Wṛṣṇi troops, who would be the guard on their journey, were prepared and at the ready.</l>
.<l n="b">Immediately they too set off from the palace, in a procession of chariots,</l>
.<l n="c">Leaving those left behind so despondent that they could only stare anxiously after them,</l>
6655<l n="d">Lost in thought and grieving, as if they longed to set off after them and go too.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">Great indeed was their yearning. But we will tell now of the son of Pāṇḍu.</l>
.<l n="b">On and on he journeyed, past settlements they took their course.</l>
.<l n="c">The countryside through which they passed was beautiful, and again and again he stopped along the way so that they might disport,</l>
6660<l n="d">Thinking up all kinds of excuses* to comfort his beloved’s heartache.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">They came upon many different villages, and all were expecting them,</l>
.<l n="b">Ready to offer tribute, for indeed the prince was truly a man of distinction endowed with every good quality.</l>
.<l n="c">Thus, there was no hesitation at all because he repaid them joyfully with royal grants,</l>
6665<l n="d">And all surrendered their hearts in homage and respect to him.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">It would take too long to tell of the time they spent on the road, stopping overnight here and there.</l>
.<l n="b">They came to Indraprastha where they were welcomed by the whole court,</l>
.<l n="c">Chief amongst them Kuntī and the sons of Pāṇḍu, with Yudhisthira in first place.</l>
6670<l n="d">‘It is like a ray of light in the darkness’, thought the people throughout the land.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">Without further ado, Lady Kuntī delightedly embraced Pārtha’s bride.</l>
.<l n="b">Because she had looked forward so eagerly to their arrival,</l>
.<l n="c">All she could say was: ‘My dear daughter! My son!’ so moved that her tears began to flow</l>
6675<l n="d">And deluged the hair-knots of the two who paid her homage there before her.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">As for Dharmatanaya, he too was full of joy,</l>
.<l n="b">As were Bhīma, the heroic Nakula and his brother, all were also overjoyed</l>
.<l n="c">To see Pārtha, returning as a world conqueror to his family, </l>
6680<l n="d">Moreover, he had won the world-renowned goddess of the Yadu tribe.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">It would take so long to describe the happiness of the king and all the court.</l>
.<l n="b">The five sons of Pāṇḍu returned together to the palace,</l>
.<l n="c">Accompanied by Kuntī. Ever at the side of Subhadrā, Pārtha’s wife,</l>
6685<l n="d">Was the Lady Dropadī, who looked to her needs and was full of affection for her.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">The homage that had been prepared for them was extraordinary.</l>
.<l n="b">They were received with prayers of good fortune by the court priests and the foremost among learned religious leaders.</l>
.<l n="c">The feasting and ceremonies were perfect,</l>
6690<l n="d">And all the ladies of noble birth, overcome with love, were happy to serve them.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">And thus Phalguṇa returned, his fame yet more renowned.</l>
.<l n="b">Ever more safe and sound was that most excellent kingdom, now restored to prosperity, knowing no impediment.</l>
.<l n="c">The members of each caste and stage of life,* as well as all the common people knew good fortune once again, as they had before.</l>
6695<l n="d">Yudhistira, son of Dharma, in his most wondrous and excellent majesty, was the parasol protecting the whole world.</l>
.</p>
.</div>
.<div type="canto" n="62">
.<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">He* was as perfect as god Indra. How could his power, that so abounded in goodness, be surpassed?</l>
6700<l n="b">Shamed, the evil-doers stopped. They were destroyed and good men prospered.</l>
.<l n="c">The admonitions of the great seer were undiminished, for he had instructed them in the proper course for those cursed to rely on the senses.*</l>
.<l n="d">In short, the four brothers were the source of his strength, while the sage kept watch over the eldest among them always.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">Blameless was he, occupying himself constantly with his subjects, fostering <foreign>dharma</foreign> like a light in the darkness of the land.</l>
6705<l n="b">Renowned throughout the world for his great courage, his might ever the strong protection of the world.</l>
.<l n="c">As long as the <foreign>kṣatriya</foreign> warriors lived in righteousness, no evil could befall those who led the hermit’s life.</l>
.<l n="d">In prosperity, he was the place of refuge for the helpless, caring for them, succouring them.</l>
.</p>
.<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">And so, now here ends the story in praise of him who is the caretaker of the world.</l>
6710<l n="b">It is called <foreign>The Journeying of Pārtha</foreign>, the work of one who humbly seeks help and audaciously presumes to imitate [great poets].</l>
.<l n="c">Deficient though it is, may it be received by the most excellent of men, may he not take offence at it, even though it is without merit.</l>
.<l n="d">May His Majesty, Surawīrya, have compassion and give his blessing to my efforts to capture beauty in verse.</l>
.</p>
.</div>
6715 </div>
. <div type="commentary">
. <!-- Comment regarding your edition such as the following example -->
. <!-- <p>The asterisk * is used to flag lemmata or forms of lemmata not recorded in the <title>Old Javanese-English Dictionary</title>.</p>-->
. </div>
6720 <div type="bibliography">
. <p>Edited and translated by Creese (1998). Digital data furnished by the author processed tgo XML-TEI by Axelle Janiak and Arlo Griffiths (2025).</p>

6725<!-- <listBibl type="editions">

. </div>
. </body>
. </text>
6730</TEI>
.
ḍīpa EdC L
ḍipa L
